   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Romance languages
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">

      navigation
     </a>

      search
     </a>
    </div>

        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This article
          <b>
           may be
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_size" title="Wikipedia:Article size">
            too long
           </a>
           to read and navigate comfortably
          </b>
          . The
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:SIZERULE" title="Wikipedia:SIZERULE">
           readable prose size
          </a>
          is 96 kilobytes.
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please consider
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Splitting" title="Wikipedia:Splitting">
            splitting
           </a>
           content into sub-articles,
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style" title="Wikipedia:Summary style">
            condensing
           </a>
           it, or adding or removing
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Section#Subsections" title="Help:Section">
            subheadings
           </a>
           .
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (October 2016)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          <img alt="[]" data-file-height="100" data-file-width="75" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/30px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/45px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/60px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png 2x" width="30"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;">
         <b>
          This article contains
          <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
           IPA
          </a>
          phonetic symbols.
         </b>
         Without proper
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Fonts" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          rendering support
         </a>
         , you may see
         <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">
          question marks, boxes, or other symbols
         </a>
         instead of
         <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
          Unicode
         </a>
         characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">
          Help:IPA
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <table class="infobox" style="width:22em;width:22em;">
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;background-color:  #c9ffd9;">
         Romance
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Ethnicity
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Latin_peoples" title="Latin peoples">
          Latin peoples
         </a>
         (adopted speakers)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         Geographic
         <br/>
         distribution
        </th>
        <td>
         Originated in coastal
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">
          Mediterranean
         </a>
         and western
         <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
          Europe
         </a>
         ; now also spoken all over the
         <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
          Americas
         </a>
         , much of
         <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">
          Africa
         </a>
         and in parts of
         <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">
          Southeast Asia
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">
          Oceania
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">
          Linguistic classification
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
          Indo-European
         </a>
         <ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:15px;padding-left:0">
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Italic_languages" title="Italic languages">
            Italic
           </a>
           <ul style="line-height:100%; margin-left:5px;padding-left:0">
            <li>
             <b>
              Romance
             </b>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row">
         <div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
          Early form
         </div>
        </th>
        <td>
         <div style="text-align:left;">

           Vulgar Latin
          </a>
         </div>

           </ul>

       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
         <div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0">
          <div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:rgb(220,245,220);padding-left:0.4em;text-align:left;">
           <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_studies" title="Indo-European studies">
            Indo-European studies
           </a>
          </div>
          <div class="NavContent hlist" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             <i>
              Scholars
             </i>
            </dt>
           </dl>
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Marija_Gimbutas" title="Marija Gimbutas">
              Marija Gimbutas
             </a>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J.P._Mallory" title="J.P. Mallory">
              J.P. Mallory
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
           <dl>
            <dt>
             <i>
              Institutes
             </i>
            </dt>
           </dl>
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Studies_in_Indo-European" title="Copenhagen Studies in Indo-European">
              Copenhagen Studies in Indo-European
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
           <dl>
            <dt>
             <i>
              Publications
             </i>
            </dt>
           </dl>
           <ul>
            <li>

               Encyclopedia of Indo-European Culture
              </a>
             </i>
            </li>
            <li>
             <i>
              <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Horse,_the_Wheel_and_Language" title="The Horse, the Wheel and Language">
               The Horse, the Wheel and Language
              </a>
             </i>
            </li>
            <li>

       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:Indo-European_topics" title="Template:Indo-European topics">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Indo-European_topics" title="Template talk:Indo-European topics">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Indo-European_topics&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The
       <b>
        Romance languages
       </b>
       (sometimes called the
       <b>
        Romanic languages
       </b>
       ,
       <b>
        Latin languages
       </b>
       , or
       <b>
        Neo-Latin languages
       </b>
       ) are the modern languages that evolved from
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       between the sixth and ninth centuries and that thus form a branch of the
       <a href="/wiki/Italic_languages" title="Italic languages">
        Italic languages
       </a>
       within the
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
        Indo-European language family
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Today, around 800 million people are native speakers worldwide, mainly in
       <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
        Europe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">
        Africa
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
        Americas
       </a>
       , but also elsewhere. Additionally, the major Romance languages have many non-native speakers and are in widespread use as
       <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">
        lingua francas
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnologue.com_2-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ethnologue.com-2">
         [2]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is especially the case for French, which is in widespread use throughout
       <a href="/wiki/African_French" title="African French">
        Central and West Africa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">
        Madagascar
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">
        Mauritius
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">
        Maghreb
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The five
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
        most widely spoken Romance languages
       </a>
       by number of native speakers are
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       (470 million),
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       (250 million),
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       (150 million),
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       (60 million), and
       <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
        Romanian
       </a>
       (25 million).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-3">
         [3]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Because of the difficulty of imposing boundaries on a continuum, various counts of the modern Romance languages are given; for example, Dalby lists 23 based on
       <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">
        mutual intelligibility
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The following, more extensive list
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       , includes 35 current, living languages, and one recently extinct language,
       <a href="/wiki/Dalmatian_language" title="Dalmatian language">
        Dalmatian
       </a>
       :
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibero-Romance_languages" title="Ibero-Romance languages">
         Iberian Romance
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
         Portuguese
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
         Galician
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Mirandese_language" title="Mirandese language">
         Mirandese
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese_languages" title="Astur-Leonese languages">
         Asturian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese_languages" title="Astur-Leonese languages">
         Leonese
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
         Spanish (Castilian)
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">
         Aragonese
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ladino_language" title="Ladino language">
         Ladino
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Occitano-Romance_languages" title="Occitano-Romance languages">
         Occitano-Romance
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
         Catalan/Valencian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
         Occitan (langue d'oc)
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Gascon_language" title="Gascon language">
         Gascon
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
         Gallo-Romance
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
         French
        </a>
        /
        <a href="/wiki/Langues_d%27o%C3%AFl" title="Langues d'oïl">
         Oïl languages
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Franco-Proven%C3%A7al_language" title="Franco-Provençal language">
         Franco-Provençal (Arpitan)
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
         Rhaeto-Romance
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Romansh_language" title="Romansh language">
         Romansh
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">
         Ladin
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Friulian_language" title="Friulian language">
         Friulian
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Italic_languages" title="Gallo-Italic languages">
         Gallo-Italic
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Piedmontese_language" title="Piedmontese language">
         Piedmontese
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Ligurian_(Romance_language)" title="Ligurian (Romance language)">
         Ligurian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Lombard_language" title="Lombard language">
         Lombard
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Emilian-Romagnol_language" title="Emilian-Romagnol language">
         Emilian-Romagnol
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">
         Venetian
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Istriot_language" title="Istriot language">
         Istriot
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Italo-Dalmatian_languages" title="Italo-Dalmatian languages">
         Italo-Dalmatian
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
         Italian
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuscan_language" title="Tuscan language">
         Tuscan
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Corsican_language" title="Corsican language">
         Corsican
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Sassarese_language" title="Sassarese language">
         Sassarese
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_language" title="Sicilian language">
         Sicilian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Neapolitan_language" title="Neapolitan language">
         Neapolitan
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Dalmatian_language" title="Dalmatian language">
         Dalmatian
        </a>
        (extinct in 1898);
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
         Sardinian
        </a>
        ;
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Romance_languages" title="Eastern Romance languages">
         Eastern Romance
        </a>
        :
        <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
         Daco-Romanian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Istro-Romanian_language" title="Istro-Romanian language">
         Istro-Romanian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Aromanian_language" title="Aromanian language">
         Aromanian
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Megleno-Romanian_language" title="Megleno-Romanian language">
         Megleno-Romanian
        </a>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en" xml:lang="en">

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">
        Origins
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Origins">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Romance languages are the continuation of
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       , the popular and colloquial
       <a href="/wiki/Sociolect" title="Sociolect">
        sociolect
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
        Latin
       </a>
       spoken by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soldiers" title="Soldiers">
        soldiers
       </a>
       , settlers, and
       <a href="/wiki/Merchant" title="Merchant">
        merchants
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       , as distinguished from the
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
        classical form of the language
       </a>
       spoken by the
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">
        Roman
       </a>
       upper classes, the form in which the language was generally written.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_5-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:0-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 350 BC and 150 AD,
       <a href="/wiki/Campaign_history_of_the_Roman_military" title="Campaign history of the Roman military">
        the expansion of the Empire
       </a>
       , together with its administrative and educational policies, made Latin the dominant native language in continental Western Europe. Latin also exerted a strong influence in
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">
        southeastern Britain
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Africa_(Roman_province)" title="Africa (Roman province)">
        the Roman province of Africa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Moselle_Romance" title="Moselle Romance">
        western Germany
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Romance" title="Pannonian Romance">
        Pannonia
       </a>
       and the Balkans north of the
       <a href="/wiki/Jire%C4%8Dek_Line" title="Jireček Line">
        Jireček Line
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       During the Empire's decline, and after its fragmentation and collapse in the fifth century, varieties of Latin began to diverge within each local area at an accelerated rate and eventually evolved into a continuum of recognizably different typologies. The colonial empires established by
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">
        Portugal
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spain
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">
        France
       </a>
       from the fifteenth century onward spread their languages to the other continents to such an extent that about two-thirds of all Romance language speakers today live outside Europe.
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite other influences (e.g.
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Substratum" title="Substratum">
         substratum
        </a>
       </i>
       from pre-Roman languages, especially
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_Celtic_languages" title="Continental Celtic languages">
        Continental Celtic languages
       </a>
       ; and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superstratum" title="Superstratum">
         superstratum
        </a>
       </i>
       from later
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">
        Slavic
       </a>
       invasions), the
       <a href="/wiki/Phonology" title="Phonology">
        phonology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Morphology_(linguistics)" title="Morphology (linguistics)">
        morphology
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Lexicon" title="Lexicon">
        lexicon
       </a>
       of all Romance languages consist mainly of evolved forms of Vulgar Latin. However, some notable differences occur between today's Romance languages and their Roman ancestor. With only one or two exceptions, Romance languages have lost the
       <a href="/wiki/Declension" title="Declension">
        declension
       </a>
       system of Latin and, as a result, have
       <a href="/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object" title="Subject–verb–object">
        SVO
       </a>
       sentence structure and make extensive use of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prepositions" title="Prepositions">
        prepositions
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Name">
        Name
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Name">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The term
       <i>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Romance" title="wikt:Romance">
         Romance
        </a>
       </i>
       comes from the Vulgar Latin adverb
       <i>
        romanice
       </i>
       , "in Roman", derived from
       <i>
        Romanicus
       </i>
       : for instance, in the expression
       <i>
        romanice loqui
       </i>
       , "to speak in Roman" (that is, the Latin
       <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">
        vernacular
       </a>
       ), contrasted with
       <i>
        latine loqui
       </i>
       , "to speak in Latin" (
       <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">
        Medieval Latin
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Conservative_(language)" title="Conservative (language)">
        conservative
       </a>
       version of the language used in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ausbausprache_%E2%80%93_Abstandsprache_%E2%80%93_Dachsprache#Dachsprache" title="Ausbausprache – Abstandsprache – Dachsprache">
        writing and formal contexts
       </a>
       or as a lingua franca), and with
       <i>
        barbarice loqui
       </i>
       , "to speak in
       <a href="/wiki/Barbarian" title="Barbarian">
        Barbarian
       </a>
       " (the non-Latin languages of the peoples living outside the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ilari_6-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ilari-6">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From this adverb the noun
       <i>
        romance
       </i>
       originated, which applied initially to anything written
       <i>
        romanice
       </i>
       , or "in the Roman vernacular".
      </p>
      <p>
       The word 'romance' with the modern sense of
       <a href="/wiki/Romance_novel" title="Romance novel">
        romance novel
       </a>
       or love affair has the same origin. In the
       <a href="/wiki/Medieval_literature" title="Medieval literature">
        medieval literature
       </a>
       of Western Europe, serious writing was usually in Latin, while popular tales, often focusing on love, were composed in the vernacular and came to be called "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romance_(heroic_literature)" title="Romance (heroic literature)">
        romances
       </a>
       ".
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Samples">
        Samples
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Samples">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Lexical and grammatical similarities among the Romance languages, and between Latin and each of them, are apparent from the following examples having the same meaning in various Romance
       <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">
        lects
       </a>
       :
      </p>
      <p>
       English: She always
       <b>
        closes
       </b>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-7">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the window before she
       <b>
        dines
       </b>
       / before
       <b>
        dining
       </b>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-8">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <table cellspacing="3px">
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
            Latin
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            (Ea) semper antequam cenat fenestram claudit.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
            Vulgar Latin
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            (Ea) claudi[t] semper illa fenestra antequam de cenare
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Bari_dialect" title="Bari dialect">
            Apulian
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>

            (Jèdde) akjude sèmbe la fenèstre prime de mangè.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>

            (Ella) zarra siempre a finestra antes de cenar.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>

         <tr>
          <td>

           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">

           </a>
          </td>

           <i>
            (Ella/Lei) chiude sempre la finestra prima di cenare.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">
            Judaeo-Spanish
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <span class="script-hebrew" dir="rtl" style="font-size: 115%; font-family: 'Ezra SIL', 'Ezra SIL SR', 'Keter Aram Tsova', 'Taamey Ashkenaz', 'Taamey David CLM', 'Taamey Frank CLM', 'Frenk Ruehl CLM', 'Keter YG', 'Shofar', 'David CLM', 'Hadasim CLM', 'Simple CLM', 'Nachlieli', 'SBL BibLit', 'SBL Hebrew', Cardo, Alef, 'Noto Serif Hebrew', 'Noto Sans Hebrew', 'David Libre', David, 'Times New Roman', Gisha, Arial, FreeSerif, FreeSans;">
            .אֵלייה סֵירּה סײֵמפּרֵי לה בֵֿינטאנה אנטֵיס דֵי סֵינאר
           </span>
           ‬;

            Ella cerra siempre la ventana antes de cenar.
           </i>

            (Ëra) stlüj dagnora la finestra impröma de cenè.
           </i>
           (badiot)

            (Ëila) stluj for l viere dan maië da cëina.
           </i>
           (gherdëina)
           <p>
            Centro Cadore:
            <i>
             La sera sempre la fenestra gnante de disna.
            </i>

           </p>
          </td>

       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <b>
        Romance-based creoles and pidgins
       </b>
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <table cellspacing="3px">
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Haitian_Creole" title="Haitian Creole">
            Haitian Creole
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            Li toujou' fèmen fenêt'-la avant li manger.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Mauritian_Creole" title="Mauritian Creole">
            Mauritian Creole
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            Li touzour pou ferm lafnet la avan (li) manze.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Seychellois_Creole" title="Seychellois Creole">
            Seychellois Creole
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            Y pou touzour ferm lafnet aven y manze.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">
            Chavacano
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            Ta cerrá él con el puerta antes de cená.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Papiamento" title="Papiamento">
            Papiamento
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            E muhe closes e porta promé na dine.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td>
           <a href="/wiki/Cape_Verdean_Creole" title="Cape Verdean Creole">
            Cape Verdean Creole
           </a>
          </td>
          <td>
           <i>
            Êl fechâ porta antes de jantâ.
           </i>
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       <br/>
       Some of the divergence comes from
       <a href="/wiki/Semantic_change" title="Semantic change">
        semantic change
       </a>
       : where the same root word has developed different meanings. For example, the Portuguese word
       <i>
        fresta
       </i>
       is descended from Latin
       <i>
        fenestra
       </i>
       "window" (and is thus
       <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">
        cognate
       </a>
       to French
       <i>
        fenêtre
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        finestra
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        fereastră
       </i>
       and so on), but now means "skylight" and "slit". Cognates may exist but have become rare, such as
       <i>
        finiestra
       </i>
       in Spanish, or dropped out of use entirely. The Spanish and Portuguese terms
       <i>
        defenestrar
       </i>
       meaning "to
       <a href="/wiki/Defenestration" title="Defenestration">
        throw through a window
       </a>
       " and
       <i>
        fenestrado
       </i>
       meaning "replete with windows" also have the same root, but are later borrowings from Latin.
      </p>
      <p>
       Likewise, Portuguese also has the word
       <i>
        cear
       </i>
       , a cognate of Italian
       <i>
        cenare
       </i>
       and Spanish
       <i>
        cenar
       </i>
       , but uses it in the sense of "to have a late supper" in most varieties, while the preferred word for "to dine" is
       <i>
        jantar
       </i>
       (related to archaic Spanish
       <i>
        yantar
       </i>
       "to eat") because of semantic changes in the 19th century. Galician has both
       <i>
        fiestra
       </i>
       (from medieval
       <i>
        fẽestra
       </i>
       , the ancestor of standard Portuguese
       <i>
        fresta
       </i>
       ) and the less frequently used
       <i>
        ventá
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        xanela
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       As an alternative to
       <i>
        lei
       </i>
       (originally the genitive form), Italian has the pronoun
       <i>
        ella
       </i>
       , a cognate of the other words for "she", but it is hardly ever used in speaking.
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish, Asturian, and Leonese
       <i>
        ventana
       </i>
       and Mirandese and Sardinian
       <i>
        bentana
       </i>
       come from Latin
       <i>
        ventus
       </i>
       "wind" (cf. English
       <i>
        window
       </i>
       , etymologically 'wind eye'), and Portuguese
       <i>
        janela
       </i>
       , Galician
       <i>
        xanela
       </i>
       , Mirandese
       <i>
        jinela
       </i>
       from Latin *
       <i>
        ianuella
       </i>
       "small opening", a derivative of
       <i>
        ianua
       </i>
       "door".
      </p>
      <p>
       Sardinian
       <i>
        balcone
       </i>
       (alternative for
       <i>
        ventàna
       </i>
       /
       <i>
        bentàna
       </i>
       ) comes from Old Italian and is similar to other Romance languages such as French
       <i>
        balcon
       </i>
       (from Italian
       <i>
        balcone
       </i>
       ), Portuguese
       <i>
        balcão
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        balcon
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        balcón
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        balcó
       </i>
       and Corsican
       <i>
        balconi
       </i>
       (alternative for
       <i>
        purtellu
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Vulgar_Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Vulgar Latin">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Latin_Europe.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1103" data-file-width="1187" height="325" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Latin_Europe.png/350px-Latin_Europe.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Latin_Europe.png/525px-Latin_Europe.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Latin_Europe.png/700px-Latin_Europe.png 2x" width="350"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Latin_Europe.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Romance languages in Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Documentary evidence is limited about Vulgar Latin for the purposes of comprehensive research, and the literature is often hard to interpret or generalize. Many of its speakers were soldiers, slaves, displaced peoples, and forced resettlers, more likely to be natives of conquered lands than natives of Rome. In Western Europe, Latin gradually replaced
       <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">
        Celtic
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Italic_languages" title="Italic languages">
        Italic languages
       </a>
       , which were related to it by a shared Indo-European origin. Commonalities in syntax and vocabulary facilitated the adoption of Latin.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
        <a href="#cite_note-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-curchin_11-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-curchin-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Vulgar Latin is believed to have already had most of the features shared by all Romance languages, which distinguish them from Classical Latin, such as the almost complete loss of the Latin
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_case" title="Grammatical case">
        grammatical case
       </a>
       system and its replacement by
       <a href="/wiki/Preposition_and_postposition" title="Preposition and postposition">
        prepositions
       </a>
       ; the loss of the neuter
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
        grammatical gender
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_declension#Comparison_and_superlative_forms_of_adjectives" title="Latin declension">
        comparative inflections
       </a>
       ; replacement of some
       <a href="/wiki/Verb" title="Verb">
        verb
       </a>
       paradigms by innovations (e.g. the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synthetic_(linguistics)" title="Synthetic (linguistics)">
        synthetic
       </a>
       future gave way to an originally
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Analytic_(linguistics)" title="Analytic (linguistics)">
        analytic
       </a>
       strategy now typically formed by infinitive + evolved present indicative forms of 'have'); the use of
       <a href="/wiki/Article_(grammar)" title="Article (grammar)">
        articles
       </a>
       ; and the initial stages of the
       <a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)" title="Palatalization (sound change)">
        palatalization
       </a>
       of the plosives /k/, /g/, and /t/.
      </p>
      <p>
       To some scholars, this suggests the form of Vulgar Latin that evolved into the Romance languages was around during the time of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       (from the end of the first century BC), and was spoken alongside the written Classical Latin which was reserved for official and formal occasions. Other scholars argue that the distinctions are more rightly viewed as indicative of sociolinguistic and register differences normally found within any language. Both were mutually intelligible as one and the same language, which was true until very approximately the second half of the 7th century. However, within two hundred years Latin became a
       <a href="/wiki/Language_death" title="Language death">
        dead language
       </a>
       since "the Romanized people of Europe could no longer understand texts that were read aloud or recited to them,"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       i.e. Latin had ceased to be a
       <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">
        first language
       </a>
       and became a foreign language that had to be learned, if the label Latin is constrained to refer to a state of the language frozen in past time and restricted to linguistic features for the most part typical of higher registers.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire">
        Fall of the Western Roman Empire
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Fall of the Western Roman Empire">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       During the political
       <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">
        decline of the Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       in the fifth century, there were large-scale
       <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">
        migrations
       </a>
       into the empire, and the Latin-speaking world was fragmented into several independent states. Central Europe and the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
        Balkans
       </a>
       were occupied by the Germanic and
       <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">
        Slavic
       </a>
       tribes, as well as by the
       <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">
        Huns
       </a>
       , which isolated the
       <a href="/wiki/Vlachs" title="Vlachs">
        Vlachs
       </a>
       from the rest of
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Romance-speaking_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Romance-speaking Europe (page does not exist)">
        Romance-speaking Europe
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/British_Latin" title="British Latin">
        British
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/African_Romance" title="African Romance">
        African Romance
       </a>
       , the forms of Vulgar Latin used in
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">
        southeastern Britain
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Africa_(Roman_province)" title="Africa (Roman province)">
        the Roman province of Africa
       </a>
       , where it had been spoken by much of the urban population, disappeared in the Middle Ages (as did
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pannonian_Romance" title="Pannonian Romance">
        Pannonian Romance
       </a>
       in what is now Hungary and
       <a href="/wiki/Moselle_Romance" title="Moselle Romance">
        Moselle Romance
       </a>
       in Germany). But the Germanic tribes that had penetrated
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Italy" title="Roman Italy">
        Roman Italy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">
        Gaul
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hispania" title="Hispania">
        Hispania
       </a>
       eventually adopted Latin/Romance and the remnants of the
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rome" title="Culture of ancient Rome">
        culture of ancient Rome
       </a>
       alongside existing inhabitants of those regions, and so Latin remained the dominant language there.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Romance">
        Early Romance
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Early Romance">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Over the course of the fourth to eighth centuries, Vulgar Latin, by this time highly dialectalized, broke up into discrete languages that were no longer mutually intelligible.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-price_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-price-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute">
          <span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (July 2017)">
           dubious
          </span>
         </a>
         <span class="metadata">
          –
          <a href="/wiki/Talk:Romance_languages#Dubious" title="Talk:Romance languages">
           discuss
          </a>
         </span>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         5
        </span>
       </sup>
       Clear evidence of Latin change comes from the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Reichenau_Glosses" title="Reichenau Glosses">
         Reichenau Glosses
        </a>
       </i>
       , an eighth-century compilation of about 1,200 words from the fourth-century
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgate" title="Vulgate">
        Vulgate
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Jerome" title="Jerome">
        Jerome
       </a>
       ) that were no longer intelligible along with their eighth-century equivalents in proto-
       <a href="/wiki/Franco-Proven%C3%A7al_language" title="Franco-Provençal language">
        Franco-Provençal
       </a>
       . The following are some examples with reflexes in several modern, closely related Romance languages for comparison:
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <th>
         English
        </th>

         <i>

         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">

          </a>

         <i>

         </i>
        </td>

         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         winter
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>

         </i>
        </td>
