         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          hìvern
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          hiver
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          inviern
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          inverno
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          invierno
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          inverno
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          iarnă
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          hivern
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          ierru
         </i>
         /
         <i>
          iberru
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       In all of the above examples, the words appearing in the fourth century Vulgate are the same words as would have been used in
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
        Classical Latin
       </a>
       of c. 50 BC. It is likely that some of these words had already disappeared from casual speech; but if so, they must have been still widely understood, as there is no recorded evidence that the common people of the time had difficulty understanding the language.
      </p>
      <p>
       By the 8th century, the situation was very different. During the late 8th century,
       <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">
        Charlemagne
       </a>
       , holding that "Latin of his age was by classical standards intolerably corrupt",
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-price_13-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-price-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         6
        </span>
       </sup>
       successfully imposed
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
        Classical Latin
       </a>
       as an artificial written vernacular for
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">
        Western Europe
       </a>
       . Unfortunately, this meant that parishioners could no longer understand the sermons of their priests, forcing the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Tours" title="Council of Tours">
        Council of Tours
       </a>
       in 813 to issue an edict that priests needed to translate their speeches into the
       <i>
        rustica romana lingua
       </i>
       , an explicit acknowledgement of the reality of the Romance languages as separate languages from Latin.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-price_13-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-price-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         6
        </span>
       </sup>
       By this time, and possibly as early as the 6th century according to Price (1984),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-price_13-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-price-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         6
        </span>
       </sup>
       the Romance
       <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">
        lects
       </a>
       had split apart enough to be able to speak of separate
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
        Gallo-Romance
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Romance_languages" title="Iberian Romance languages">
        Ibero-Romance
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italo-Dalmatian_languages" title="Italo-Dalmatian languages">
        Italo-Romance
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Romance_languages" title="Eastern Romance languages">
        Eastern Romance languages
       </a>
       . Some researchers
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch">
          <span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (June 2017)">
           who?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       have postulated that the major divergences in the spoken dialects began in the 5th century, as the formerly widespread and efficient communication networks of the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
        Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       rapidly broke down, leading to the total disappearance of the Western Roman Empire by the end of the century. The critical period between the 5th–10th centuries AD is poorly documented because little or no writing from the chaotic "
       <a href="/wiki/Dark_Ages_(historiography)" title="Dark Ages (historiography)">
        Dark Ages
       </a>
       " of the 5th–8th centuries has survived, and writing after that time was in consciously classicized
       <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">
        Medieval Latin
       </a>
       , with vernacular writing only beginning in earnest in the 11th or 12th centuries.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Recognition_of_the_vernaculars">
        Recognition of the vernaculars
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Recognition of the vernaculars">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Between the 10th and 13th centuries, some local
       <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">
        vernaculars
       </a>
       developed a written form and began to supplant Latin in many of its roles. In some countries, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">
        Portugal
       </a>
       , this transition was expedited by force of law; whereas in others, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       , many prominent poets and writers used the vernacular of their own accord – some of the most famous in Italy being
       <a href="/wiki/Giacomo_da_Lentini" title="Giacomo da Lentini">
        Giacomo da Lentini
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dante_Alighieri" title="Dante Alighieri">
        Dante Alighieri
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Uniformization_and_standardization">
        Uniformization and standardization
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Uniformization and standardization">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The invention of the
       <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">
        printing press
       </a>
       brought a tendency towards greater uniformity of
       <a href="/wiki/Standard_language" title="Standard language">
        standard languages
       </a>
       within political boundaries, at the expense of other Romance languages and
       <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">
        dialects
       </a>
       less favored politically. In France, for instance, the dialect spoken in the region of Paris gradually spread to the entire country, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
        Occitan
       </a>
       of the south lost ground.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_status">
        Modern status
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Modern status">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Romance-speaking_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Romance-speaking Europe (page does not exist)">
        Romance-speaking Europe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
        Latin America
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_Union" title="Latin Union">
        Latin Union
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romance-speaking_Africa" title="Romance-speaking Africa">
        Romance-speaking Africa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Romance-speaking_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Romance-speaking Asia (page does not exist)">
        Romance-speaking Asia
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Romance-speaking_world" title="Romance-speaking world">
        Romance-speaking world
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Romance_20c_en.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2372" data-file-width="3355" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Romance_20c_en.png/300px-Romance_20c_en.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Romance_20c_en.png/450px-Romance_20c_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Romance_20c_en.png/600px-Romance_20c_en.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Romance_20c_en.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Romance languages, 20th-century
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Romance-procents.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="374" data-file-width="449" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Romance-procents.png/300px-Romance-procents.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/58/Romance-procents.png 1.5x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Romance-procents.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Number of native speakers of each Romance language, as fractions of the total 690 million (2007)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Romance language
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Languages_by_speakers" title="Languages by speakers">
        most widely spoken natively
       </a>
       today is
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       (Castilian), followed by
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
        Romanian
       </a>
       , which together cover a vast territory in Europe and beyond, and work as
       <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
        official
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/National_language" title="National language">
        national languages
       </a>
       in dozens of countries.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map-Romance_Language_World.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="1357" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Map-Romance_Language_World.png/350px-Map-Romance_Language_World.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Map-Romance_Language_World.png/525px-Map-Romance_Language_World.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Map-Romance_Language_World.png/700px-Map-Romance_Language_World.png 2x" width="350"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map-Romance_Language_World.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Romance languages in the World
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, and Romanian are also official languages of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       . Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, Romanian, and Catalan are the official languages of the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_Union" title="Latin Union">
        Latin Union
       </a>
       ; and French and Spanish are two of the six official languages of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       . Outside Europe,
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       are spoken and enjoy official status in various countries that emerged from the respective
       <a href="/wiki/Colonial_empire" title="Colonial empire">
        colonial empires
       </a>
       . Spanish is an official language in nine countries of
       <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
        South America
       </a>
       , home to about half that continent's population; in six countries of
       <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">
        Central America
       </a>
       (all except
       <a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">
        Belize
       </a>
       ); and in
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       . In the
       <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">
        Caribbean
       </a>
       , it is official in
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">
        Cuba
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">
        Dominican Republic
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">
        Puerto Rico
       </a>
       . In all these countries,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_American_Spanish" title="Latin American Spanish">
        Latin American Spanish
       </a>
       is the vernacular language of the majority of the population, giving Spanish the most native speakers of any Romance language. In Africa it is the official language of
       <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       , but has few native speakers there.
      </p>
      <p>
       Portuguese, in its original homeland,
       <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">
        Portugal
       </a>
       , is spoken by virtually the entire population of 10 million. As the official language of
       <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
        Brazil
       </a>
       , it is spoken by more than 200 million people in that country, as well as by neighboring residents of
       <a href="/wiki/Brasiguayos" title="Brasiguayos">
        eastern Paraguay
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Riverense_Portu%C3%B1ol_language" title="Riverense Portuñol language">
        northern Uruguay
       </a>
       , accounting for a little more than half the population of South America. It is the official language of six African countries (
       <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">
        Angola
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cape_Verde" title="Cape Verde">
        Cape Verde
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guinea-Bissau" title="Guinea-Bissau">
        Guinea-Bissau
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mozambique" title="Mozambique">
        Mozambique
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe" title="São Tomé and Príncipe">
        São Tomé and Príncipe
       </a>
       ), and is spoken as a first language by perhaps 30 million residents of that continent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In Asia, Portuguese is co-official with other languages in
       <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">
        East Timor
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">
        Macau
       </a>
       , while most Portuguese-speakers in Asia—some 400,000
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       —are in
       <a href="/wiki/Japan#Demographics" title="Japan">
        Japan
       </a>
       due to
       <a href="/wiki/Dekasegi" title="Dekasegi">
        return immigration
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" title="Japanese Brazilian">
        Japanese Brazilians
       </a>
       . In North America 1,000,000 people speak Portuguese as their home language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In Oceania, Portuguese is the second most spoken Romance language, after French, due mainly to the number of speakers in
       <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">
        East Timor
       </a>
       . Its closest relative, Galician, has official status in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autonomous_communities_in_Spain" title="Autonomous communities in Spain">
        autonomous community
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">
        Galicia
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       , together with Spanish.
      </p>
      <p>
       Outside Europe, French is spoken natively most in the Canadian province of
       <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">
        Quebec
       </a>
       , and in parts of
       <a href="/wiki/New_Brunswick" title="New Brunswick">
        New Brunswick
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ontario" title="Ontario">
        Ontario
       </a>
       . Canada is officially bilingual, with French and English being the official languages. In parts of the Caribbean, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">
        Haiti
       </a>
       , French has official status, but most people speak creoles such as
       <a href="/wiki/Haitian_Creole" title="Haitian Creole">
        Haitian Creole
       </a>
       as their native language. French also has official status in much of Africa, but relatively few native speakers. In France's overseas possessions, native use of French is increasing.
      </p>
      <p>
       Although
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       also had some colonial possessions before
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       , its language did not remain official after the end of the colonial domination. As a result,
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       outside of Italy and Switzerland is now spoken only as a minority language by immigrant communities in
       <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">
        North
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">
        South America
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">
        Australia
       </a>
       . In some former Italian colonies in Africa—namely
       <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">
        Libya
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">
        Eritrea
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">
        Somalia
       </a>
       —it is spoken by a few educated people in commerce and government.
       <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
        Romania
       </a>
       did not establish a colonial empire, but beyond its native territory in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" title="Southeastern Europe">
        Southeastern Europe
       </a>
       , it also spread to other countries on the Mediterranean (especially the other Romance countries, most notably
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       ), and elsewhere such as
       <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">
        Israel
       </a>
       , where it is the native language of five percent of the population,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and is spoken by many more as a secondary language; this is due to the large numbers of Romanian-born
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jews
       </a>
       who moved to Israel after
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some 2.6 million people in the former Soviet republic of
       <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">
        Moldova
       </a>
       speak a variety of Romanian, called variously
       <a href="/wiki/Moldovan_language" title="Moldovan language">
        Moldovan
       </a>
       or Romanian by them.
      </p>
      <p>
       The total native speakers of Romance languages are divided as follows (with their ranking within the languages of the world in brackets):
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_21-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Encarta-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnologue1_22-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ethnologue1-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
         Spanish
        </a>
        (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hispanosphere" title="Hispanosphere">
         Hispanosphere
        </a>
        ) 49% (
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
         2nd
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
         Portuguese
        </a>
        (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lusosphere" title="Lusosphere">
         Lusosphere
        </a>
        ) 26% (
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
         6th
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
         French
        </a>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/Francophonie" title="Francophonie">
         Francophonie
        </a>
        ) 8.6% (
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
         18th
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
         Italian
        </a>
        7.7% (
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
         23rd
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
         Romanian
        </a>
        3.0% (
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
         49th
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
         Catalan
        </a>
        0.9% (
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
         not in the top 100
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        Others 3.6%
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Catalan is the official language of
       <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">
        Andorra
       </a>
       . In Spain, it is co-official with Spanish (Castilian) in
       <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">
        Catalonia
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Valencian_Community" title="Valencian Community">
        Valencian Community
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Balearic_Islands" title="Balearic Islands">
        Balearic Islands
       </a>
       , and it is recognized, but not official, in
       <a href="/wiki/La_Franja" title="La Franja">
        La Franja
       </a>
       , in
       <a href="/wiki/Aragon" title="Aragon">
        Aragon
       </a>
       . In addition, it is spoken by many residents of
       <a href="/wiki/Alghero" title="Alghero">
        Alghero
       </a>
       , on the island of
       <a href="/wiki/Sardinia" title="Sardinia">
        Sardinia
       </a>
       , and it is co-official in that city.
       <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
        Galician
       </a>
       , with more than a million native speakers, is official together with Spanish in
       <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Spain)" title="Galicia (Spain)">
        Galicia
       </a>
       , and has legal recognition in neighbouring territories in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Castilla_y_Le%C3%B3n" title="Castilla y León">
        Castilla y León
       </a>
       . A few other languages have official recognition on a regional or otherwise limited level; for instance,
       <a href="/wiki/Asturian_language" title="Asturian language">
        Asturian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">
        Aragonese
       </a>
       in Spain;
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mirandese" title="Mirandese">
        Mirandese
       </a>
       in Portugal;
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Friulan" title="Friulan">
        Friulan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
        Sardinian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Franco-Proven%C3%A7al_language" title="Franco-Provençal language">
        Franco-Provençal
       </a>
       in Italy; and
       <a href="/wiki/Romansh_language" title="Romansh language">
        Romansh
       </a>
       in Switzerland.
      </p>
      <p>
       The remaining Romance languages survive mostly as spoken languages for informal contact. National governments have historically viewed linguistic diversity as an economic, administrative or military liability, as well as a potential source of
       <a href="/wiki/Separatism" title="Separatism">
        separatist
       </a>
       movements; therefore, they have generally fought to eliminate it, by extensively promoting the use of the official language, restricting the use of the "other" languages in the media, characterizing them as mere "dialects", or even persecuting them. As a result, all of these languages are considered endangered to varying degrees according to the UNESCO
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Book_of_Endangered_Languages" title="Red Book of Endangered Languages">
        Red Book of Endangered Languages
       </a>
       , ranging from "vulnerable" (e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_language" title="Sicilian language">
        Sicilian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">
        Venetian
       </a>
       ) to "severely endangered" (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arpitan" title="Arpitan">
        Arpitan
       </a>
       , most of the
       <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
        Occitan
       </a>
       varieties). Since the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries, increased sensitivity to the rights of minorities has allowed some of these languages to start recovering their prestige and lost rights. Yet it is unclear whether these political changes will be enough to reverse the decline of minority Romance languages.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Classification_and_related_languages">
        Classification and related languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Classification and related languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Romance-lg-classification-en.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="556" data-file-width="1011" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Romance-lg-classification-en.svg/300px-Romance-lg-classification-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Romance-lg-classification-en.svg/450px-Romance-lg-classification-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Romance-lg-classification-en.svg/600px-Romance-lg-classification-en.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Romance-lg-classification-en.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Chart of Romance languages based on structural and comparative criteria, not on socio-functional ones. FP: Franco-Provençal, IR: Istro-Romanian.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="816" data-file-width="1032" height="237" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG/300px-Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG/450px-Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG/600px-Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Western_and_Eastern_Romania.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Eastern and Western Romance areas split by the
         <a href="/wiki/La_Spezia%E2%80%93Rimini_Line" title="La Spezia–Rimini Line">
          La Spezia–Rimini Line
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Classification_of_Romance_languages" title="Classification of Romance languages">
        Classification of Romance languages
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The classification of the Romance languages is inherently difficult, because most of the linguistic area is a
       <a href="/wiki/Dialect_continuum" title="Dialect continuum">
        dialect continuum
       </a>
       , and in some cases political biases can come into play. Along with Latin (which is not included among the Romance languages) and a few extinct languages of ancient Italy, they make up the
       <a href="/wiki/Italic_languages" title="Italic languages">
        Italic branch
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
        Indo-European family
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <br/>
      </p>

        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr style="height: 1px; text-align: center;">
        <td style="border-right:1px solid black">

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Proposed_divisions">
        Proposed divisions
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Proposed divisions">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        Extent of variation in development (very conservative to very innovative)
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Form
         <br/>
         ("to sing")
        </th>
        <th>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
          Latin
         </a>
        </th>
        <th>
         <a href="/wiki/Logudorese_dialect" title="Logudorese dialect">
          Nuorese
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
          Sardinian
         </a>
        </th>
        <th>
         <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
          Italian
         </a>
        </th>

        </th>

          Portuguese
         </a>

          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">

           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alveolar_trill" title="Alveolar trill">
            r̥
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_retroflex_fricative" title="Voiceless retroflex fricative">
            ɻ̝̊
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_velar_fricative" title="Voiceless velar fricative">
            x
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_uvular_fricative" title="Voiceless uvular fricative">
            χ
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_pharyngeal_fricative" title="Voiceless pharyngeal fricative">
            ħ
           </a>
          </span>
          ]
         </span>
         are all possible allophones of
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          [ɾ]
         </span>
         in this position.
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <p>
       There are various schemes used to subdivide the Romance languages. Three of the most common schemes are as follows:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Italo-Western vs. Eastern vs. Southern. This is the scheme followed by
        <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">
         Ethnologue
        </a>
        , and is based primarily on the outcome of the ten
        <a href="/wiki/Monophthong" title="Monophthong">
         monophthong
        </a>
        vowels in Classical Latin. This is discussed more
        <a href="#Italo-Western_vs._Eastern_vs._Southern">
         below
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        West vs. East. This scheme divides the various languages along the
        <a href="/wiki/La_Spezia%E2%80%93Rimini_Line" title="La Spezia–Rimini Line">
         La Spezia–Rimini Line
        </a>
        , which runs across north-central Italy just to the north of the city of
        <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">
         Florence
        </a>
        (whose speech forms the basis of standard Italian). In this scheme, "East" includes the languages of central and southern Italy, and the
        <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Romance_languages" title="Eastern Romance languages">
         Balkan Romance
        </a>
        (or "Eastern Romance") languages in Romania, Greece, and elsewhere in the Balkans; "West" includes the languages of Portugal, Spain, France, northern Italy and Switzerland.
        <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
         Sardinian
        </a>
        does not easily fit in this scheme.
       </li>
       <li>
        "
        <a href="/wiki/Conservative_(language)" title="Conservative (language)">
         Conservative
        </a>
        " vs. "innovatory". This is a non-genetic division whose precise boundaries are subject to debate. Generally, the
        <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
         Gallo-Romance languages
        </a>
        (discussed further below) form the core "innovatory" languages, with standard French generally considered the most innovatory of all, while the languages near the periphery (which include Spanish, Portuguese, Italian and Romanian) are "conservative".
        <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
         Sardinian
        </a>
        is generally acknowledged the most conservative Romance language, and was also the first language to split off genetically from the rest, possibly as early as the first century BC.
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dante" title="Dante">
         Dante
        </a>
        famously denigrated the
        <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_people" title="Sardinian people">
         Sardinians
        </a>
        for the conservativeness of their speech, remarking that they imitate Latin "like monkeys imitate men".
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
         <a href="#cite_note-24">
          [24]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Italo-Western_vs._Eastern_vs._Sardinian">
        Italo-Western vs. Eastern vs. Sardinian
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Italo-Western vs. Eastern vs. Sardinian">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The main subfamilies that have been proposed by
       <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">
        Ethnologue
       </a>
       within the various classification schemes for Romance languages are:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Italo-Western_languages" title="Italo-Western languages">
         Italo-Western
        </a>
        , the largest group, which includes languages such as Catalan, Portuguese, Italian, Spanish, and French.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Romance_languages" title="Eastern Romance languages">
         Eastern Romance
        </a>
        , which includes the Romance languages of Eastern Europe, such as Romanian.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Southern_Romance_languages" title="Southern Romance languages">
         Southern Romance
        </a>
        , which includes a few languages with particularly archaic features, such as Sardinian and, partially, Corsican. This family is thought to have included the now-vanished Romance languages of Africa (or at least, they appear to have evolved their vowels in the same way).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       This controversial three-way division is made primarily based on the outcome of Vulgar Latin (Proto-Romance) vowels:
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; margin:10px;">
       <caption>
        Outcome of Classical Latin vowels
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Classical Latin
        </th>
        <th>
         Proto-Romance
        </th>
        <th>
         Sardinian
        </th>
        <th>
         Eastern Romance
        </th>
        <th>
         Italo-Western
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         short A
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         long A
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         short E
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɛ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɛ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɛ/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         long E
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         short I
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɪ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         long I
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         short O
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɔ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɔ/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         long O
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         short U
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ʊ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         long U
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <br/>
       Italo-Western is in turn split along the so-called
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/La_Spezia%E2%80%93Rimini_Line" title="La Spezia–Rimini Line">
         La Spezia–Rimini Line
        </a>
       </i>
       in northern Italy, which divides the central and southern Italian languages from the so-called
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Romance_languages" title="Western Romance languages">
        Western Romance languages
       </a>
       to the north and west. The primary characteristics dividing the two are:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Phonemic
        <a href="/wiki/Lenition" title="Lenition">
         lenition
        </a>
        of intervocalic stops, which happens to the northwest but not to the southeast.
       </li>
       <li>
        Degemination of geminate stops (producing new intervocalic single voiceless stops, after the old ones were lenited), which again happens to the northwest but not to the southeast.
       </li>
       <li>
        Deletion of intertonic vowels (between the stressed syllable and either the first or last syllable), again in the northwest but not the southeast.
       </li>
       <li>
        Use of plurals in /s/ in the northwest vs. plurals using vowel change in the southeast.
       </li>
       <li>
        Development of palatalized /k/ before /e,i/ to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /(t)s/
        </span>
        in the northwest vs.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        in the southeast.
       </li>
       <li>
        Development of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /kt/
        </span>
        , which develops to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /xt/
        </span>
        &gt;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /it/
        </span>
        (sometimes progressing further to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        ) in the northwest but
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tt/
        </span>
        in the southeast.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       In fact, the reality is somewhat more complex. All of the "southeast" characteristics apply to all languages southeast of the line, and all of the "northwest" characteristics apply to all languages in France and (most of) Spain. However, the
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Italic_languages" title="Gallo-Italic languages">
        Gallo-Italic languages
       </a>
       are somewhere in between. All of these languages do have the "northwest" characteristics of lenition and loss of gemination. However:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The Gallo‒Italic languages have vowel-changing plurals rather than /s/ plurals.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Lombard_language" title="Lombard language">
         Lombard language
        </a>
        in north-central Italy and the Rhaeto-Romance languages have the "southeast" characteristic of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        instead of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /(t)s/
        </span>
        for palatalized /k/.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">
         Venetian language
        </a>
        in northeast Italy and some of the Rhaeto-Romance languages have the "southeast" characteristic of developing
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /kt/
        </span>
        to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tt/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Lenition of post-vocalic /p t k/ is widespread as an allophonic phonetic realization in Italy below the La Spezia-Rimini line, including Corsica and most of Sardinia.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       On top of this, the ancient
       <a href="/wiki/Mozarabic_language" title="Mozarabic language">
        Mozarabic language
       </a>
       in southern Spain, at the far end of the "northwest" group, had the "southeast" characteristics of lack of lenition and palatalization of /k/ to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       . Certain languages around the
       <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">
        Pyrenees
       </a>
       (e.g. some highland
       <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">
        Aragonese
       </a>
       dialects) also lack lenition, and northern French dialects such as
       <a href="/wiki/Norman_language" title="Norman language">
        Norman
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
        Picard
       </a>
       have palatalization of /k/ to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       (although this is possibly an independent, secondary development, since /k/ between vowels, i.e. when subject to lenition, developed to /dz/ rather than
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /dʒ/
       </span>
       , as would be expected for a primary development).
      </p>
      <p>
       The usual solution to these issues is to create various nested subgroups. Western Romance is split into the Gallo-Iberian languages, in which lenition happens and which include nearly all the Western Romance languages, and the Pyrenean-Mozarabic group, which includes the remaining languages without lenition (and is unlikely to be a valid
       <a href="/wiki/Clade" title="Clade">
        clade
       </a>
       ; probably at least two clades, one for Mozarabic and one for Pyrenean). Gallo-Iberian is split in turn into the Iberian languages (e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       ), and the larger
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
        Gallo-Romance languages
       </a>
       (stretching from eastern Spain to northeast Italy).
      </p>
      <p>
       Probably a more accurate description, however, would be to say that there was a focal point of innovation located in central France, from which a series of innovations spread out as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Areal_change" title="Areal change">
        areal changes
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/La_Spezia%E2%80%93Rimini_Line" title="La Spezia–Rimini Line">
        La Spezia–Rimini Line
       </a>
       represents the farthest point to the southeast that these innovations reached, corresponding to the northern chain of the
       <a href="/wiki/Apennine_Mountains" title="Apennine Mountains">
        Apennine Mountains
       </a>
       , which cuts straight across northern Italy and forms a major geographic barrier to further language spread.
      </p>
      <p>
       This would explain why some of the "northwest" features (almost all of which can be characterized as innovations) end at differing points in northern Italy, and why some of the languages in geographically remote parts of Spain (in the south, and high in the Pyrenees) are lacking some of these features. It also explains why the languages in France (especially standard French) seem to have innovated earlier and more completely than other Western Romance languages.
      </p>
      <p>
       Many of the "southeast" features also apply to the Eastern Romance languages (particularly, Romanian), despite the geographic discontinuity. Examples are lack of lenition, maintenance of intertonic vowels, use of vowel-changing plurals, and palatalization of /k/ to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       . (Gemination is missing, which may be an independent development, and /kt/ develops into /pt/ rather than either of the normal Italo-Western developments.) This has led some researchers to postulate a basic two-way East-West division, with the "Eastern" languages including Romanian and central and southern Italian.
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite being the first romance language to evolve from Vulgar Latin,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_5-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-:0-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
        Sardinian
       </a>
       does not fit well at all into this sort of division. It is clear that Sardinian became linguistically independent from the remainder of the Romance languages at an extremely early date, possibly already by the first century BC. Sardinian contains a large number of archaic features, including total lack of palatalization of /k/ and /g/ and a large amount of vocabulary preserved nowhere else, including some items already archaic by the time of Classical Latin (first century BC). Sardinian has plurals in /s/ but post-vocalic lenition of voiceless consonants is normally limited to the status of an allophonic rule (e.g. [k]
       <i>
        ane
       </i>
       'dog' but
       <i>
        su
       </i>
       [g]
       <i>
        ane
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        su
       </i>
       [ɣ]
       <i>
        ane
       </i>
       'the dog'), and there are a few innovations unseen elsewhere, such as a change of /au/ to /a/. Use of
       <i>
        su
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        ipsum
       </i>
       as an article is a retained archaic feature that also exists in the Catalan of the
       <a href="/wiki/Balearic_Islands" title="Balearic Islands">
        Balearic Islands
       </a>
       and that used to be more widespread in Occitano-Romance, and is known as
       <i>
        article salat
       </i>
       (literally the "salted article"), while Sardinia shares delabialization of earlier /kw/ and /gw/ with Romania: Sard.
       <i>
        abba
       </i>
       , Rum.
       <i>
        apă
       </i>
       'water'; Sard.
       <i>
        limba
       </i>
       , Rom.
       <i>
        limbă
       </i>
       'language' (cf. Italian
       <i>
        acqua
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        lingua
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Gallo-Romance_languages">
        Gallo-Romance languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Gallo-Romance languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
        Gallo-Romance languages
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Gallo-Romance can be divided into the following subgroups:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Langues_d%27o%C3%AFl" title="Langues d'oïl">
         Langues d'oïl
        </a>
        , including
        <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
         French
        </a>
        and closely related languages.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franco-Proven%C3%A7al" title="Franco-Provençal">
         Franco-Provençal
        </a>
        language (also known as Arpitan) of southeastern France, western Switzerland, and
        <a href="/wiki/Aosta_Valley" title="Aosta Valley">
         Aosta Valley
        </a>
        region of northwestern Italy.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       The following groups are also sometimes considered part of Gallo-Romance:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Occitano-Romance_languages" title="Occitano-Romance languages">
         Occitano-Romance languages
        </a>
        of southern France namely,
        <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
         Occitan
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Gascon_language" title="Gascon language">
         Gascon
        </a>
        .
        <ul>
         <li>
          The
          <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
           Catalan
          </a>
          language of eastern Iberia is also sometimes included in Gallo-romance. This is however disputed by some linguists who prefer to group it with
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibero-Romance_languages" title="Ibero-Romance languages">
           Iberian Romance
          </a>
          , since although Old Catalan is close to Old Occitan, it later adjusted its lexicon to some degree to align with Spanish. In general however, modern Catalan, especially grammatically, remains closer to modern Occitan than to either Spanish or Portuguese.
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallo-Italian_languages" title="Gallo-Italian languages">
         Gallo-Italian languages
        </a>
        of northern Italy, including
        <a href="/wiki/Piedmontese_language" title="Piedmontese language">
         Piedmontese
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ligurian_language_(Romance)" title="Ligurian language (Romance)">
         Ligurian
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Lombard" title="Western Lombard">
         Western Lombard
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Lombard" title="Eastern Lombard">
         Eastern Lombard
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emilian_language" title="Emilian language">
         Emilian
        </a>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romagnol_language" title="Romagnol language">
         Romagnol
        </a>
        . Ligurian and Eastern Lombard retain the final -o, being the exception in Gallo-Romance.
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
         Rhaeto-Romance languages
        </a>
        , including
        <a href="/wiki/Romansh_language" title="Romansh language">
         Romansh
        </a>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/Friulian_language" title="Friulian language">
         Friulian
        </a>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">
         Ladin
        </a>
        dialects.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       The Gallo-Romance languages are generally considered the most innovative (least conservative) among the Romance languages. Characteristic Gallo-Romance features generally developed earliest and appear in their most extreme manifestation in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Langue_d%27o%C3%AFl" title="Langue d'oïl">
        Langue d'oïl
       </a>
       , gradually spreading out along riverways and transalpine roads.
      </p>
      <p>
       In some ways, however, the Gallo-Romance languages are conservative. The older stages of many of the languages preserved a two-case system consisting of nominative and oblique, fully marked on nouns, adjectives and determiners, inherited almost directly from the Latin nominative and accusative and preserving a number of different declensional classes and irregular forms. The languages closest to the oïl epicenter preserve the case system the best, while languages at the periphery lose it early.
      </p>
      <p>
       Notable characteristics of the Gallo-Romance languages are:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Early loss of unstressed final vowels other than
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a/
        </span>
        —a defining characteristic of the group.
        <ul>
         <li>
          Further reductions of final vowels in
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Langue_d%27o%C3%AFl" title="Langue d'oïl">
           Langue d'oïl
          </a>
          and many
          <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Italic_languages" title="Gallo-Italic languages">
           Gallo-Italic languages
          </a>
          , with the feminine
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /a/
          </span>
          and
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prop_vowel" title="Prop vowel">
           prop vowel
          </a>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /e/
          </span>
          merging into
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /ə/
          </span>
          , which is often subsequently dropped.
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        Early, heavy reduction
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
           <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (July 2017)">
            clarification needed
           </span>
          </a>
          – reduction to what?
         </i>
         ]
        </sup>
        of unstressed vowels in the interior of a word (another defining characteristic).
       </li>
       <li>
        Loss of final vowels phonemicized the long vowels that used to be automatic concomitants of stressed open syllables. These phonemic long vowels are maintained directly in many Northern Italian dialects; elsewhere, phonemic length was lost, but in the meantime many of the long vowels diphthongized, resulting in a maintenance of the original distinction. The langue d'oïl branch is again at the forefront of innovation, with no less than five of the seven long vowels diphthongizing (only high vowels were spared).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Front_rounded_vowel" title="Front rounded vowel">
         Front rounded vowels
        </a>
        are present in all four branches.
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
           <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (November 2015)">
            clarification needed
           </span>
          </a>
          – branches of what?
         </i>
         ]
        </sup>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /u/
        </span>
        usually fronts to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /y/
        </span>
        , and secondary mid front rounded vowels often develop from long
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /oː/
        </span>
        or
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɔː/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Extreme lenition (i.e. multiple rounds of lenition) occurs in many languages especially in
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Langue_d%27o%C3%AFl" title="Langue d'oïl">
         Langue d'oïl
        </a>
        and many
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallo-Italian_languages" title="Gallo-Italian languages">
         Gallo-Italian languages
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Langue_d%27o%C3%AFl" title="Langue d'oïl">
         Langue d'oïl
        </a>
        , Swiss
        <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
         Rhaeto-Romance languages
        </a>
        and many of the northern dialects of Occitan have a secondary
        <a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)" title="Palatalization (sound change)">
         palatalization
        </a>
        of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /k/
        </span>
        and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɡ/
        </span>
        before
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a/
        </span>
        , producing different results from the primary Romance palatalization: e.g.
        <i>
         centum
        </i>
        "hundred" &gt;
        <i>
         cent
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /sɑ̃/
        </span>
        ,
        <i>
         cantum
        </i>
        "song" &gt;
        <i>
         chant
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʃɑ̃/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Other than the
        <a href="/wiki/Occitano-Romance_languages" title="Occitano-Romance languages">
         Occitano-Romance languages
        </a>
        , most Gallo-Romance languages are subject-obligatory (whereas all the rest of the Romance languages are
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pro-drop" title="Pro-drop">
         pro-drop
        </a>
        languages). This is a late development triggered by progressive phonetic erosion: Old French was still a null-subject language, and this only changed upon loss of secondarily final consonants in Middle French.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span id="Pidgins.2C_creoles.2C_and_mixed_languages">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Pidgins,_creoles,_and_mixed_languages">
        Pidgins, creoles, and mixed languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Pidgins, creoles, and mixed languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Some Romance languages have developed varieties which seem dramatically restructured as to their grammars or to be mixtures with other languages. It is not always clear whether they should be classified as Romance,
       <a href="/wiki/Pidgin" title="Pidgin">
        pidgins
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Creole_language" title="Creole language">
        creole languages
       </a>
       , or
       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_language" title="Mixed language">
        mixed languages
       </a>
       . Some other languages, such as
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        Modern English
       </a>
       , are
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_English_creole_hypothesis" title="Middle English creole hypothesis">
        sometimes thought of as creoles
       </a>
       of semi-Romance ancestry. There are several dozens of creoles of
       <a href="/wiki/French-based_creole_languages" title="French-based creole languages">
        French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish-based_creole_languages" title="Spanish-based creole languages">
        Spanish
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese-based_creole_languages" title="Portuguese-based creole languages">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       origin, some of them spoken as
       <a href="/wiki/National_language" title="National language">
        national languages
       </a>
       in former European colonies.
      </p>
      <p>
       <b>
        Creoles of French:
       </b>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antillean_Creole_French" title="Antillean Creole French">
         Antillean
        </a>
        (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Antilles" title="French Antilles">
         French Antilles
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Saint_Lucian_Creole_French" title="Saint Lucian Creole French">
         Saint Lucia
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Creole_French" title="Dominican Creole French">
         Dominica
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Haitian_Creole" title="Haitian Creole">
         Haitian
        </a>
        (one of
        <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">
         Haiti
        </a>
        's two official languages)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louisiana_Creole_French" title="Louisiana Creole French">
         Louisiana
        </a>
        (US)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Mauritian_Creole" title="Mauritian Creole">
         Mauritian
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">
          lingua franca
         </a>
        </i>
        of
        <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">
         Mauritius
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union_Creole" title="Réunion Creole">
         Réunion
        </a>
        (native language of
        <a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">
         Réunion
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Seychellois_Creole" title="Seychellois Creole">
         Seychellois
        </a>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/Seychelles" title="Seychelles">
         Seychelles
        </a>
        ' official language)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       <b>
        Creoles of Spanish:
       </b>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">
         Chavacano
        </a>
        (in part of Philippines)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Palenquero" title="Palenquero">
         Palenquero
        </a>
        (in part of Colombia)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       <b>
        Creoles of Portuguese:
       </b>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Angolar_Creole" title="Angolar Creole">
         Angolar
        </a>
        (regional language in São Tomé and Principe)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Cape_Verdean_Creole" title="Cape Verdean Creole">
         Cape Verdean
        </a>
        (Cape Verde's national language; includes several distinct languages)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Forro_Creole" title="Forro Creole">
         Forro
        </a>
        (regional language in São Tomé and Príncipe)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Kristang_language" title="Kristang language">
         Kristang
        </a>
        (Malaysia)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Macanese_Patois" title="Macanese Patois">
         Macanese
        </a>
        (Macau)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Papiamento" title="Papiamento">
         Papiamento
        </a>
        (Dutch Antilles official language)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upper_Guinea_Creole" title="Upper Guinea Creole">
         Upper Guinea
        </a>
        (Guinea-Bissau's national language)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Auxiliary_and_constructed_languages">
        Auxiliary and constructed languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Auxiliary and constructed languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Constructed_language" title="Constructed language">
        Constructed language
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/International_auxiliary_language" title="International auxiliary language">
        International auxiliary language
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Latin and the Romance languages have also served as the inspiration and basis of numerous auxiliary and constructed languages, so-called "neo-romantic languages".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The concept was first developed in 1903 by Italian mathematician
       <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Peano" title="Giuseppe Peano">
        Giuseppe Peano
       </a>
       , under the title
       <a href="/wiki/Latino_sine_flexione" title="Latino sine flexione">
        Latino sine flexione
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He wanted to create a
       <i>
        naturalistic
       </i>
       international language, as opposed to an autonomous constructed language like
       <a href="/wiki/Esperanto" title="Esperanto">
        Esperanto
       </a>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volapuk" title="Volapuk">
        Volapuk
       </a>
       which were designed for maximal simplicity of lexicon and derivation of words. Peano used Latin as the base of his language, because at the time of his flourishing it was the
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       international language of scientific communication.
      </p>
      <p>
       Other languages developed since include
       <a href="/wiki/Idiom_Neutral" title="Idiom Neutral">
        Idiom Neutral
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Occidental_language" title="Occidental language">
        Occidental
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lingua_Franca_Nova" title="Lingua Franca Nova">
        Lingua Franca Nova
       </a>
       , and most famously and successfully,
       <a href="/wiki/Interlingua" title="Interlingua">
        Interlingua
       </a>
       . Each of these languages has attempted to varying degrees to achieve a pseudo-Latin vocabulary as common as possible to living Romance languages.
      </p>
      <p>
       There are also languages created for artistic purposes only, such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Talossan_language" title="Talossan language">
        Talossan
       </a>
       . Because Latin is a very well attested ancient language, some amateur linguists have even constructed Romance languages that mirror real languages that developed from other ancestral languages. These include
       <a href="/wiki/Brithenig" title="Brithenig">
        Brithenig
       </a>
       (which mirrors
       <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">
        Welsh
       </a>
       ), Breathanach
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (mirrors
       <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">
        Irish
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Wenedyk" title="Wenedyk">
        Wenedyk
       </a>
       (mirrors
       <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">
        Polish
       </a>
       ), Þrjótrunn (mirrors
       <a href="/wiki/Icelandic_language" title="Icelandic language">
        Icelandic
       </a>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and Helvetian (mirrors
       <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">
        German
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Linguistic_features">
        Linguistic features
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
