        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Linguistic features">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Basic_features">
        Basic features
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Basic features">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Romance languages have a number of shared features across all languages:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Romance languages are moderately
        <a href="/wiki/Inflection" title="Inflection">
         inflecting
        </a>
        , i.e. there is a moderately complex system of
        <a href="/wiki/Affix" title="Affix">
         affixes
        </a>
        (primarily
        <a href="/wiki/Suffix" title="Suffix">
         suffixes
        </a>
        ) that are attached to words to convey grammatical information such as
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
         number
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
         gender
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">
         person
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_tense" title="Grammatical tense">
         tense
        </a>
        , etc. Verbs have much more inflection than nouns. The amount of
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_language" title="Synthetic language">
          synthesis
         </a>
        </i>
        is significantly more than
        <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
         English
        </a>
        , but less than
        <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
         Classical Latin
        </a>
        and much less than the oldest
        <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">
         Indo-European languages
        </a>
        (e.g.
        <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">
         Ancient Greek
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">
         Sanskrit
        </a>
        ). Inflection is
        <a href="/wiki/Fusional_language" title="Fusional language">
         fusional
        </a>
        , with a single affix representing multiple features (as contrasted with
        <a href="/wiki/Agglutinative_language" title="Agglutinative language">
         agglutinative languages
        </a>
        such as
        <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
         Turkish
        </a>
        or
        <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">
         Japanese
        </a>
        ). For example, Portuguese
        <i>
         amei
        </i>
        "I loved" is composed of
        <i>
         am-
        </i>
        "love" and the fusional suffix
        <i>
         -ei
        </i>
        "first-person singular
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Preterite_tense" title="Preterite tense">
         preterite
        </a>
        indicative".
       </li>
       <li>
        Romance languages have a fairly strict
        <a href="/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object" title="Subject–verb–object">
         subject–verb–object
        </a>
        word order, with predominant use of head-first (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Right-branching" title="Right-branching">
         right-branching
        </a>
        ) constructions. Adjectives, genitives and relative clauses all follow their head noun, although (except in
        <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
         Romanian
        </a>
        ) determiners usually precede.
       </li>
       <li>
        In general, nouns, adjectives and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Determiner_(linguistics)" title="Determiner (linguistics)">
         determiners
        </a>
        inflect only according to
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
         grammatical gender
        </a>
        (masculine or feminine) and
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
         grammatical number
        </a>
        (singular or plural).
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_case" title="Grammatical case">
         Grammatical case
        </a>
        is marked only on pronouns, as in English; case marking, as in English, is of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominative%E2%80%93accusative" title="Nominative–accusative">
         nominative–accusative
        </a>
        type (rather than e.g. the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ergative%E2%80%93absolutive" title="Ergative–absolutive">
         ergative–absolutive
        </a>
        marking of
        <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">
         Basque
        </a>
        or the
        <a href="/wiki/Split_ergativity" title="Split ergativity">
         split ergativity
        </a>
        of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindi_language" title="Hindi language">
         Hindi
        </a>
        ). A significant exception, however, is
        <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
         Romanian
        </a>
        , with two-case marking (nominative/accusative vs. genitive/dative) on nominal elements.
       </li>
       <li>
        Verbs are inflected according to a complex morphology that marks
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">
         person
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
         number
        </a>
        (singular or plural),
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_tense" title="Grammatical tense">
         tense
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_mood" title="Grammatical mood">
         mood
        </a>
        (indicative, subjunctive, imperative), and sometimes
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_aspect" title="Grammatical aspect">
         aspect
        </a>
        or
        <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
         gender
        </a>
        .
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammatical_voice" title="Grammatical voice">
         Grammatical voice
        </a>
        (active, passive, middle/reflexive) and some grammatical aspects (in particular, the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perfect_aspect" title="Perfect aspect">
         perfect aspect
        </a>
        ) are expressed using
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Periphrastic" title="Periphrastic">
         periphrastic
        </a>
        constructions, as in the Italian present perfect (
        <i>
         passato prossimo
        </i>
        )
        <i>
         io ho amato
        </i>
        /
        <i>
         io sono stato amato
        </i>
        "I have loved/I have been loved".
       </li>
       <li>
        Most Romance languages are
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Null_subject_language" title="Null subject language">
         null subject languages
        </a>
        (but modern French is not, as a result of the phonetic decay of verb endings).
       </li>
       <li>
        All Romance languages have two articles (
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Definite_article" title="Definite article">
         definite
        </a>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indefinite_article" title="Indefinite article">
         indefinite
        </a>
        ), and many have in addition a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partitive_article" title="Partitive article">
         partitive article
        </a>
        (expressing the concept of "some"). In some languages (notably,
        <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
         French
        </a>
        ), the use of an article with a noun is nearly obligatory; it serves to express grammatical number (no longer marked on most nouns) and to cope with the extreme
        <a href="/wiki/Homophone" title="Homophone">
         homophony
        </a>
        of French vocabulary as a result of extensive sound reductions.
       </li>
       <li>
        The phonology of most Romance languages is of moderate size with few unusual phonemes. Phonemic vowel length is uncommon. Some languages have developed
        <a href="/wiki/Nasal_vowel" title="Nasal vowel">
         nasal vowels
        </a>
        or
        <a href="/wiki/Front_rounded_vowel" title="Front rounded vowel">
         front rounded vowels
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Word accent is of the
        <a href="/wiki/Stress_(linguistics)" title="Stress (linguistics)">
         stress
        </a>
        (dynamic) type, rather than making use of pitch (as in
        <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">
         Ancient Greek
        </a>
        and some modern Slavic languages), and is free, occurring more or less unpredictably on one of the last three syllables. In practice, the stress is largely predictable, due to the many morphological and phonological stress-related patterns.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Changes_from_Classical_Latin">
        Changes from Classical Latin
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Changes from Classical Latin">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Loss of the case system
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <p>
       The most significant changes between
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
        Classical Latin
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Romance" title="Proto-Romance">
        Proto-Romance
       </a>
       (and hence all the modern Romance languages) relate to the reduction or loss of the Latin
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_case" title="Grammatical case">
        case system
       </a>
       , and the corresponding syntactic changes that were triggered.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:1-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The case system was drastically reduced from the vigorous six-case system of Latin. Although four cases can be constructed for Proto-Romance nouns (nominative, accusative, combined genitive/dative, and vocative), the vocative is marginal and present only in Romanian (where it may be an outright innovation), and of the remaining cases, no more than two are present in any one language. Romanian is the only modern Romance language with case marking on nouns, with a two-way opposition between nominative/accusative and genitive/dative. Some of the older
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
        Gallo-Romance languages
       </a>
       (in particular,
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Occitan" title="Old Occitan">
        Old Occitan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sursilvan_dialects_(Romansh)" title="Sursilvan dialects (Romansh)">
        Old Sursilvan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Friulian_language" title="Friulian language">
        Old Friulian
       </a>
       , and in traces
       <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
        Old Catalan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">
        Old Venetian
       </a>
       ) had an opposition between nominative and general oblique, and in Ibero-Romance languages, such as Spanish and Portuguese, as well as in Italian (see under
       <a href="#Case">
        Case
       </a>
       ), a couple of examples are found which preserve the old nominative. As in English, case is preserved better on pronouns.
      </p>
      <p>
       Concomitant with the loss of cases, freedom of word order was greatly reduced. Classical Latin had a generally verb-final (SOV) but overall quite free word order, with a significant amount of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scrambling_(syntax)" title="Scrambling (syntax)">
        word scrambling
       </a>
       and mixing of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Left-branching" title="Left-branching">
        left-branching
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Right-branching" title="Right-branching">
        right-branching
       </a>
       constructions. The Romance languages eliminated word scrambling and nearly all left-branching constructions, with most languages developing a rigid SVO, right-branching syntax. (
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       , however, had a freer word order due to the two-case system still present, as well as a predominantly
       <a href="/wiki/V2_word_order" title="V2 word order">
        verb-second word order
       </a>
       developed under the influence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic languages
       </a>
       .) Some freedom, however, is allowed in the placement of adjectives relative to their head noun. In addition, some languages (e.g. Spanish, Romanian) have an "accusative preposition" (Romanian
       <i>
        pe
       </i>
       , Spanish "personal
       <i>
        a
       </i>
       ") along with
       <a href="/wiki/Clitic_doubling" title="Clitic doubling">
        clitic doubling
       </a>
       , which allows for some freedom in ordering the arguments of a verb.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Romance languages developed
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammatical_article" title="Grammatical article">
        grammatical articles
       </a>
       where Latin had none. Articles are often introduced around the time a robust case system falls apart in order to disambiguate the remaining case markers (which are usually too ambiguous by themselves) and to serve as parsing clues that signal the presence of a noun (a function that used to beserved by the case endings themselves).
      </p>
      <p>
       This was the pattern followed by the Romance languages: In the Romance languages that still preserved a functioning nominal case system (e.g., Romanian and Old French), only the combination of article and case ending serves to uniquely identify number and case (compare the similar situation in modern
       <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">
        German
       </a>
       ). All Romance languages have a definite article (originally developed from
       <i>
        ipse
       </i>
       "self" but replaced in nearly all languages by
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       "that (over there)") and an indefinite article (developed from
       <i>
        ūnus
       </i>
       "one"). Many also have a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partitive_article" title="Partitive article">
        partitive article
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        dē
       </i>
       "of" + definite article).
      </p>
      <p>
       Latin had a large number of syntactic constructions expressed through infinitives, participles, and similar nominal constructs. Examples are the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ablative_absolute" title="Ablative absolute">
        ablative absolute
       </a>
       , the accusative-plus-infinitive construction used for
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reported_speech" title="Reported speech">
        reported speech
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gerundive" title="Gerundive">
        gerundive
       </a>
       constructions, and the common use of
       <a href="/wiki/Reduced_relative_clause" title="Reduced relative clause">
        reduced relative clauses
       </a>
       expressed through participles. All of these are replaced in the Romance languages by subordinate clauses expressed with finite verbs, making the Romance languages much more "verbal" and less "nominal" than Latin. Under the influence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkan_sprachbund" title="Balkan sprachbund">
        Balkan sprachbund
       </a>
       , Romanian has progressed the furthest, largely eliminating the infinitive. (It is being revived, however, due to the increasing influence of other Romance languages.)
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dt>
        Other changes
       </dt>
      </dl>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Loss of phonemic
        <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
         vowel length
        </a>
        , and change into a free-stressed language. Classical Latin had an automatically determined stress on the second or third syllable from the end, conditioned by vowel length; once vowel length was neutralized, stress was no longer predictable so long as it remained where it was (which it mostly did).
       </li>
       <li>
        Development of a series of palatal consonants as a result of
        <a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)" title="Palatalization (sound change)">
         palatalization
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Loss of most traces of the neuter gender.
       </li>
       <li>
        Development of a series of analytic
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perfect_tense" title="Perfect tense">
         perfect tenses
        </a>
        , comparable to English "I have done, I had done, I will have done".
       </li>
       <li>
        Loss of the Latin synthetic passive voice, replaced by an analytic construction comparable to English "it is/was done".
       </li>
       <li>
        Loss of
        <a href="/wiki/Deponent_verb" title="Deponent verb">
         deponent verbs
        </a>
        , replaced by active-voice verbs.
       </li>
       <li>
        Replacement of the Latin future tense with a new tense formed (usually) by a
        <a href="/wiki/Periphrasis" title="Periphrasis">
         periphrasis
        </a>
        of infinitive + present tense of
        <i>
         habēre
        </i>
        "have", which usually contracts into a new synthetic tense. A corresponding
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conditional_tense" title="Conditional tense">
         conditional tense
        </a>
        is formed in the same way but using one of the past-tense forms of
        <i>
         habēre
        </i>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Numerous lexical changes. A number of words were borrowed from the
        <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
         Germanic languages
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">
         Celtic languages
        </a>
        . Many basic nouns and verbs, especially those that were short or had irregular morphology, were replaced by longer derived forms with regular morphology. Throughout the medieval period, words were borrowed from Classical Latin in their original form (
        <i>
         learned words
        </i>
        ) or in something approaching the original form (
        <i>
         semi-learned words
        </i>
        ), often replacing the popular forms of the same words.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Phonology">
        Phonology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Phonology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Vowels">
        Vowels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Vowels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Every language has a different set of vowels from every other. Common characteristics are as follows:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Most languages have at least five
        <a href="/wiki/Monophthong" title="Monophthong">
         monophthongs
        </a>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e i o u/
        </span>
        . The parent language of most of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italo-Western_Romance" title="Italo-Western Romance">
         Italo-Western Romance
        </a>
        languages (which includes the vast majority) actually had a seven-vowel system
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a ɛ e i ɔ o u/
        </span>
        , which is kept in most Italo-Western languages. In some languages, like Spanish and Romanian, the phonemic status and difference between open-mid and close-mid vowels was lost. French has probably the largest inventory of monophthongs, with conservative varieties having 12
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oral_vowel" title="Oral vowel">
         oral vowels
        </a>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a ɑ ɛ e i ɔ o u œ ø y ə/
        </span>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
         <a href="#cite_note-32">
          [32]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and 4
        <a href="/wiki/Nasal_vowel" title="Nasal vowel">
         nasal vowels
        </a>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɑ̃ ɛ̃ ɔ̃ œ̃/
        </span>
        .
        <a href="/wiki/European_Portuguese" title="European Portuguese">
         European Portuguese
        </a>
        also has a large inventory, with 9 oral monophthongs
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a ɐ ɛ e i ɔ o u ɨ/
        </span>
        , 5 nasal monophthongs
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɐ̃ ẽ ĩ õ ũ/
        </span>
        , and a large number of oral and nasal diphthongs (see below). (The phonemic status of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɐ ɨ/
        </span>
        is somewhat doubtful, however, and neither phoneme exists in
        <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">
         Brazilian Portuguese
        </a>
        ).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
         <a href="#cite_note-33">
          [33]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Some languages have a large inventory of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Falling_diphthong" title="Falling diphthong">
         falling diphthongs
        </a>
        . These may or may not be considered as phonemic units (rather than sequences of vowel+glide or vowel+vowel), depending on their behavior. As an example, French, Spanish and Italian have occasional instances of putative falling diphthongs formed from a vowel plus a non-syllabic
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /i/
        </span>
        or
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /u/
        </span>
        (e.g. Spanish
        <i>
         veinte
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ˈbejn̪te]
        </span>
        "twenty",
        <i>
         deuda
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ˈdewða]
        </span>
        "debt"; French
        <i>
         paille
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [pɑj]
        </span>
        "straw",
        <i>
         caoutchouc
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [kawˈtʃu]
        </span>
        "rubber"; Italian
        <i>
         lui
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ˈluj]
        </span>
        "he",
        <i>
         potei
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [poˈtej]
        </span>
        "I could"), but these are normally analyzed as sequences of vowel and glide.
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
           <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2017)">
            citation needed
           </span>
          </a>
         </i>
         ]
        </sup>
        The diphthongs in Romanian, Portuguese, Catalan and Occitan, however, have various properties suggesting that they are better analyzed as unit phonemes. Portuguese, for example, has the diphthongs
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /aj ɐj ɛj ej ɔj oj uj aw ɛw ew iw (ow)/
        </span>
        , where
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ow/
        </span>
        (and to a lesser extent
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ej/
        </span>
        ) appear only in some dialects. All except
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /aw ɛw/
        </span>
        appear frequently in verb or noun inflections. (Portuguese also has nasal diphthongs; see below.)
       </li>
       <li>
        Among the major Romance languages, Portuguese and French have
        <a href="/wiki/Nasal_vowel" title="Nasal vowel">
         nasal vowel
        </a>
        phonemes, stemming from nasalization before a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nasal_stop" title="Nasal stop">
         nasal consonant
        </a>
        followed by loss of the consonant (this occurred especially when the nasal consonant was not directly followed by a vowel). Originally, vowels in both languages were nasalized before
        <i>
         all
        </i>
        nasal consonants, but have subsequently become denasalized before nasal consonants that still remain (except in
        <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">
         Brazilian Portuguese
        </a>
        , where the pre-nasal vowels in words such as
        <i>
         cama
        </i>
        "bed",
        <i>
         menos
        </i>
        "less" remain highly nasalized). In Portuguese, nasal vowels are sometimes analyzed as phonemic sequences of oral vowels plus an underlying nasal consonant, but such an analysis is difficult in French because of the existence of minimal pairs such as
        <i>
         bon
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /bɔ̃/
        </span>
        "good (masc.)",
        <i>
         bonne
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /bɔn/
        </span>
        "good (fem.)". In both languages, there are fewer nasal than oral vowels. Nasalization triggered vowel lowering in French, producing the 4 nasal vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɑ̃ ɛ̃ ɔ̃ œ̃/
        </span>
        (although most speakers in France nowadays pronounce
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /œ̃/
        </span>
        as
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ̃/
        </span>
        ). Vowel raising was triggered in Portuguese, however, producing the 5 nasal vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɐ̃ ẽ ĩ õ ũ/
        </span>
        . Vowel contraction and other changes also resulted in the Portuguese nasal diphthongs
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɐ̃w̃ õw̃ ɐ̃j̃ ẽj̃ õj̃ ũj̃/
        </span>
        (of which
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ũj̃/
        </span>
        occurs in only two words,
        <i>
         muito
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /mũj̃tu/
        </span>
        "much, many, very", and
        <i>
         mui
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /mũj̃/
        </span>
        "very"; and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ẽj̃ õw̃/
        </span>
        are actually final-syllable allophones of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ẽ õ/
        </span>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        Most languages have fewer vowels in unstressed syllables than stressed syllables. This again reflects the Italo-Western Romance parent language, which had a seven-vowel system in stressed syllables (as described above) but only
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e i o u/
        </span>
        (with no low-mid vowels) in unstressed syllables. Some languages have seen further reductions: e.g. Standard Catalan has only
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ə i u]
        </span>
        in unstressed syllables. In French, on the other hand, any vowel may take prosodic stress.
       </li>
       <li>
        Most languages have even fewer vowels in word-final unstressed syllables than elsewhere. For example, Old Italian allowed only
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e i o/
        </span>
        , while the early stages of most Western Romance languages allowed only
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e o/
        </span>
        . The
        <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
         Gallo-Romance languages
        </a>
        went even farther, deleting all final vowels except
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a/
        </span>
        . Of these languages, French has carried things to the extreme by deleting all vowels after the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Accented_syllable" title="Accented syllable">
         accented syllable
        </a>
        and uniformly accenting the final syllable (except for a more-or-less non-phonemic final unstressed
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ə]
        </span>
        that occasionally appears). Modern Spanish now allows final unstressed
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /i u/
        </span>
        , and modern Italian allows final unstressed
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /u/
        </span>
        , but they tend to occur largely in borrowed or
        <a href="/wiki/Onomatopoeia" title="Onomatopoeia">
         onomatopoeic
        </a>
        words, e.g.
        <i>
         guru
        </i>
        "guru",
        <i>
         taxi
        </i>
        "taxi", Spanish
        <i>
         tribu
        </i>
        "tribe" and
        <i>
         espíritu
        </i>
        "spirit" (loanwords from
        <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
         Classical Latin
        </a>
        ), Italian
        <i>
         babau
        </i>
        "bogeyman" (onomatopoeic, cf. English "boo!"). The apparent Spanish exception
        <i>
         casi
        </i>
        "almost" originates from Latin
        <i>
         quasi
        </i>
        "as if" &lt;
        <i>
         quam sī
        </i>
        , and was probably influenced by
        <i>
         si
        </i>
        "if".
       </li>
       <li>
        Phonemic vowel length is uncommon. Vulgar Latin lost the phonemic vowel length of Classical Latin and replaced it with a non-phonemic length system where stressed vowels in
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_syllable" title="Open syllable">
         open syllables
        </a>
        were long, and all other vowels were short. Standard Italian still maintains this system, and it was rephonemicized in the
        <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
         Gallo-Romance languages
        </a>
        (including the
        <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
         Rhaeto-Romance languages
        </a>
        ) as a result of the deletion of many final vowels. Some northern Italian languages (e.g.
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Friulan_language" title="Friulan language">
         Friulan
        </a>
        ) still maintain this secondary phonemic length, but in most languages the new long vowels were either diphthongized or shortened again, in the process eliminating phonemic length. French is again the odd man out: Although it followed a normal Gallo-Romance path by diphthongizing five of the seven long vowels and shortening the remaining two, it phonemicized a third vowel length system around 1300 AD in syllables that had been closed with an
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /s/
        </span>
        (still marked with a circumflex accent), and now is phonemicizing a fourth system as a result of lengthening before final voiced fricatives.
       </li>
       <li>
        In modern spoken and literary Romanian, Slavic influences are evident in phonetics and morphology. Phonetic Slavicisms include the
        <a href="/wiki/Iotation" title="Iotation">
         iotation
        </a>
        of the initial
        <i>
         e
        </i>
        in words such as
        <i>
         el
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         ea
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         este
        </i>
        pronounced
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [jel], [ja], [jeste]
        </span>
        (compare
        <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
         Spanish
        </a>
        :
        <i>
         <span lang="es" xml:lang="es">
          el, ella, estamos
         </span>
        </i>
        , without the Slavic iotation effect).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Consonants">
        Consonants
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Consonants">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Most Romance languages have similar sets of consonants. The following is a combined table of the consonants of the five major Romance languages (French, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian).
      </p>
      <p>
       Key:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <b>
         bold
        </b>
        : Appears in all 5 languages.
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         italic
        </i>
        : Appears in 3–4 languages.
       </li>
       <li>
        (parentheses): Appears in 2 languages.
       </li>
       <li>
        ((double parentheses)): Appears in only 1 language.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Notable changes:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Spanish has no phonemic voiced fricatives (however,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [β ð ɣ]
        </span>
        occur as allophones of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /b d ɡ/
        </span>
        after a vowel and after certain consonants). The equivalent of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /v/
        </span>
        merged with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /b/
        </span>
        , and all the rest became voiceless. It also lost
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʃ/
        </span>
        , which became
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /x/
        </span>
        or
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /h/
        </span>
        in some other dialects.
       </li>
       <li>
        The western languages (French, Spanish, Portuguese) all used to have the affricates
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ts/
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dz/
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dʒ/
        </span>
        . By the fourteenth century or so, these all turned into fricatives except for Spanish and dialectal Portuguese
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        . (Spanish
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ts/
        </span>
        ended up becoming
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /θ/
        </span>
        , at least in Northern and Central Spain; elsewhere, it merged with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /s/
        </span>
        , as in the other languages.) Romanian
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dz/
        </span>
        likewise became
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /z/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        French, and most varieties of Spanish, have lost
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʎ/
        </span>
        (which merged with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /j/
        </span>
        ). Romanian merged both
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʎ/
        </span>
        and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɲ/
        </span>
        into
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /j/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Romanian was influenced by Slavic phonology, mostly the palatalization of consonants in the plural form (for example
        <i>
         pom-pomi
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         lup-lupi
        </i>
        , pronounced
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [pomʲ]
        </span>
        and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [lupʲ]
        </span>
        ) and changing of /l/ to /r/, for instance Latin
        <i>
         schola/scola
        </i>
        &gt; Slav. школа,
        <i>
         școla
        </i>
        &gt; modern Romanian
        <i>
         școală
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ˈʃko̯alə]
        </span>
        "school".
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Most instances of most of the sounds below that occur (or used to occur, as described above) in all of the languages are cognate. However:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Although all of the languages have or used to have
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        , almost none of these sounds are cognate between pairs of languages. The only real exception is many
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        between Italian and Romanian, stemming from Latin C- before E or I. Italian also has
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        from Vulgar Latin -CY-, and from -TY- following a consonant (elsewhere
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ts/
        </span>
        ). Former French
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        is from Latin C- before A, either word-initial or following a consonant; Spanish
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        is from Latin -CT-, or from PL, CL following a consonant; former Portuguese
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /tʃ/
        </span>
        is from Latin PL, CL, FL, either word-initial or following a consonant.
       </li>
       <li>
        Italian and former Romanian
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dz/
        </span>
        (from some instances of Vulgar Latin -DY-) are not cognate with former western
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dz/
        </span>
        (from
        <a href="/wiki/Lenition" title="Lenition">
         lenition
        </a>
        of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ts/
        </span>
        ).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%;">

       </tr>
      </table>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lexical_stress">
        Lexical stress
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Lexical stress">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Word
       <a href="/wiki/Stress_(linguistics)" title="Stress (linguistics)">
        stress
       </a>
       was rigorously predictable in classical Latin except in a very few exceptional cases, either on the
       <a href="/wiki/Penult" title="Penult">
        penultimate
       </a>
       syllable (second from last) or antepenultimate syllable (third from last), according to the
       <a href="/wiki/Syllable_weight" title="Syllable weight">
        syllable weight
       </a>
       of the penultimate syllable. Stress in the Romance Languages mostly remains on the same syllable as in Latin, but various sound changes have made it no longer so predictable. Minimal pairs distinguished only by stress exist in some languages, e.g. Italian
       <i>
        Papa
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈpa.pa]
       </span>
       "Pope" vs.
       <i>
        papà
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [pa.ˈpa]
       </span>
       "daddy", or Spanish
       <i>
        límite
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈli.mi.te]
       </span>
       "[a] limit", present subjunctive
       <i>
        limite
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [li.ˈmi.te]
       </span>
       "[that] [I/he] limit" and preterite
       <i>
        limité
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [li.mi.ˈte]
       </span>
       "[I] limited".
      </p>
      <p>
       Erosion of unstressed syllables following the stress has caused most Spanish and Portuguese words to have either penultimate or ultimate stress: e.g. Latin
       <i>
        <u>
         trē
        </u>
        decim
       </i>
       "thirteen" &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        <u>
         tre
        </u>
        ce
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        <u>
         tre
        </u>
        ze
       </i>
       ; Latin
       <i>
        a
        <u>
         mā
        </u>
        re
       </i>
       "to love" &gt; Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        a
        <u>
         mar
        </u>
       </i>
       . Most words with antepenultimate stress are learned borrowings from Latin, e.g. Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        fábrica
       </i>
       "factory" (the corresponding inherited word is Spanish
       <i>
        <u>
         fra
        </u>
        gua
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        frágua
       </i>
       "forge"). This process has gone even farther in French, with deletion of all post-stressed vowels, leading to consistent, predictable stress on the last syllable: e.g. Latin
       <i>
        <u>
         Ste
        </u>
        phanum
       </i>
       "Stephen" &gt; Old French
       <i>
        Es
        <u>
         tiev
        </u>
        ne
       </i>
       &gt; French
       <i>
        É
        <u>
         tienne
        </u>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e.ˈtjɛn/
       </span>
       ; Latin
       <i>
        <u>
         ju
        </u>
        venis
       </i>
       "young" &gt; Old French
       <i>
        <u>
         juev
        </u>
        ne
       </i>
       &gt; French
       <i>
        jeune
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʒœn/
       </span>
       . This applies even to borrowings: e.g. Latin
       <i>
        <u>
         fa
        </u>
        brica
       </i>
       &gt; French borrowing
       <i>
        fa
        <u>
         brique
        </u>
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fa.ˈbʀik/
       </span>
       (the inherited word in this case being monosyllabic
       <i>
        forge
       </i>
       &lt; Pre-French *
       <i>
        fauriga
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Other than French (with consistent final stress), the position of the stressed
       <a href="/wiki/Syllable" title="Syllable">
        syllable
       </a>
       generally falls on one of the last three syllables. Exceptions may be caused by
       <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
        clitics
       </a>
       or (in Italian) certain verb endings, e.g. Italian
       <i>
        te
        <u>
         le
        </u>
        fonano
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [teˈlɛ.fo.na.no]
       </span>
       "they telephone"; Spanish
       <i>
        entregándomelo
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [en.tɾe.ˈɣan.do.me.lo]
       </span>
       "delivering it to me"; Italian
       <i>
        met
        <u>
         tia
        </u>
        mocene
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [meˈtːjaː.mo.tʃe.ne]
       </span>
       "let's put some of it in there"; Portuguese
       <i>
        dávamo-vo-lo
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈda.vɐ.mu.vu.lu]
       </span>
       "we were giving it to you". Stress on verbs is almost completely predictable in Spanish and Portuguese, but less so in Italian.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Nominal_morphology">
        Nominal morphology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Nominal morphology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Nouns, adjectives, and pronouns can be marked for
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
        gender
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
        number
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_case" title="Grammatical case">
        case
       </a>
       . Adjectives and pronouns must agree in all features with the noun they are bound to.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Number">
        Number
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Number">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Romance languages inherited from Latin two grammatical numbers, singular and plural; the only trace of a
       <a href="/wiki/Dual_(grammatical_number)" title="Dual (grammatical number)">
        dual
       </a>
       number comes from Latin
       <i>
        ambō
       </i>
       &gt; Spanish and Portuguese
       <i>
        ambos
       </i>
       , Old Romanian
       <i>
        îmbi
       </i>
       &gt; Romanian
       <i>
        ambii
       </i>
       , Old French
       <i>
        ambe
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        ambedue, entrambi
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Gender">
        Gender
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Gender">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Most Romance languages have two
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
        grammatical genders
       </a>
       , masculine and feminine. The gender of animate nouns is generally natural (i.e. nouns referring to men are generally masculine, and vice versa), but for nonanimate nouns it is arbitrary.
      </p>
      <p>
       Although Latin had a third gender (neuter), there is little trace of this in most languages. The biggest exception is
       <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
        Romanian
       </a>
       , where there is a productive class of "neuter" nouns, which include the descendants of many Latin neuter nouns and which behave like masculines in the singular and feminines in the plural, both in the endings used and in the agreement of adjectives and pronouns (e.g.
       <i>
        un deget
       </i>
       "one finger" vs.
       <i>
        două degete
       </i>
       "two fingers", cf. Latin
       <i>
        digitus
       </i>
       , pl.
       <i>
        digiti
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Such nouns arose because of the identity of the Latin neuter singular
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       with the masculine singular, and the identity of the Latin neuter plural
       <i>
        -a
       </i>
       with the feminine singular. A similar class exists in Italian, although it is no longer productive (e.g.
       <i>
        il dito
       </i>
       "the finger" vs.
       <i>
        le dita
       </i>
       "the fingers",
       <i>
        l'uovo
       </i>
       "the egg" vs.
       <i>
        le uova
       </i>
       "the eggs"). A similar phenomenon may be observed in
       <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">
        Albanian
       </a>
       (which is heavily Romance-influenced), and the category remains highly productive with a number of new words loaned or coined in the neuter (
       <i>
        (një) hotel
       </i>
       one hotel(m) vs.
       <i>
        (tri) hotele
       </i>
       three hotels (f)). (A few isolated nouns in Latin had different genders in the singular and plural, but this was an unrelated phenomenon; this is similarly the case with a few French nouns, such as
       <i>
        amour
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        délice
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        orgue
       </i>
       .)
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish also has vestiges of the neuter in the demonstrative adjectives:
       <i>
        esto
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        eso
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        aquello
       </i>
       , the pronoun
       <i>
        ello
       </i>
       (meaning "it") and the article
       <i>
        lo
       </i>
       (used to intensify adjectives). Portuguese also has neuter demonstrative adjectives: "isto", "isso", "aquilo" (meaning "this [near me]", "this/that [near you]", "that [far from the both of us]").
      </p>
      <p>
       Remnants of the neuter, interpretable now as "a sub-class of the non-feminine gender" (Haase 2000:233), are vigorous in Italy in an area running roughly from Ancona to Matera and just north of Rome to Naples. Oppositions with masculine typically have been recategorized, so that neuter signifies the referent in general, while masculine indicates a more specific instance, with the distinction marked by the definite article. In Southeast
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Umbrian_dialect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Umbrian dialect (page does not exist)">
        Umbrian
       </a>
       , for example, neuter
       <i>
        lo pane
       </i>
       is 'the bread', while masculine
       <i>
        lu pane
       </i>
       refers to an individual piece or loaf of bread. Similarly, neuter
       <i>
        lo vinu
       </i>
       is wine in general, while masculine
       <i>
        lu vinu
       </i>
       is a specific sort of wine, with the consequence that mass
       <i>
        lo vinu
       </i>
       has no plural counterpart, but
       <i>
        lu vinu
       </i>
       can take a
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sortal_plural&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Sortal plural (page does not exist)">
        sortal plural
       </a>
       form
       <i>
        li vini
       </i>
       , referring to different types of wine. Phonological forms of articles vary by locale.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Case">
        Case
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Case">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Latin had an extensive case system, where all nouns were declined in six cases (
       <a href="/wiki/Nominative_case" title="Nominative case">
        nominative
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vocative_case" title="Vocative case">
        vocative
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Accusative_case" title="Accusative case">
        accusative
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dative_case" title="Dative case">
        dative
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Genitive_case" title="Genitive case">
        genitive
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Ablative_case" title="Ablative case">
        ablative
       </a>
       ) and two numbers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_31-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-:1-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many adjectives were additionally declined in three genders, leading to a possible 6 × 2 × 3 = 36 endings per adjective (although this was rarely the case). In practice, some category combinations had identical endings to other combinations, but a basic adjective like
       <i>
        bonus
       </i>
       "good" still had 14 distinct endings.
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin:10px">
       <caption>
        Spanish pronoun inflections
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Case
        </th>
        <th>

        </th>
        <th>
         "thou"
        </th>
        <th>
         "oneself"
        </th>
        <th>
         "he"
        </th>
        <th>
         "she"
        </th>
        <th colspan="2">
         "we"
        </th>
        <th colspan="2">
         "ye"
        </th>
        <th colspan="2">
         "they"
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Nominative
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          yo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          tú
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         —
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          él
         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          ella
         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          nosotros
         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          nosotras
         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>

        </td>

         <i>
          vosotras
         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">

        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          ellas
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Disjunctive
        </th>

         </i>
        </td>

         </i>
        </td>

          sí
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>

        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
