         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          te
         </i>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <i>
          se
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          lo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          la
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <i>
          nos
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <i>
          os
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          los
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          las
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Dative
        </th>
        <td colspan="2">
         <i>
          le
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2">
         <i>
          les
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          mío
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          tuyo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          suyo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          suyo; de él
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          suyo; de ella
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <i>
          nuestro
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <i>
          vuestro
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          suyo; de ellos
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          suyo; de ellas
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Possessive
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          mi
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          tu
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="3">
         <i>
          su
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2">
         <i>
          su
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         With
         <i>
          con
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          conmigo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          contigo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          consigo
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con él
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con ella
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con nosotros
         </i>
         <br/>
         (archaic
         <i>
          connosco
         </i>
         )
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con nosotras
         </i>
         <br/>
         (archaic
         <i>
          connosco
         </i>
         )
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con vosotros
         </i>
         <br/>
         (archaic
         <i>
          convosco
         </i>
         )
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con vosotras
         </i>
         <br/>
         (archaic
         <i>
          convosco
         </i>
         )
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con ellos
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          con ellas
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       In all Romance languages, this system was drastically reduced. In most modern Romance languages, in fact, case is no longer marked at all on nouns, adjectives and determiners, and most forms are derived from the Latin accusative case. Much like English, however, case has survived somewhat better on pronouns.
      </p>
      <p>
       Most pronouns have distinct nominative, accusative, genitive and possessive forms (cf. English "I, me, mine, my"). Many also have a separate dative form, a
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Disjunctive_pronoun" title="Disjunctive pronoun">
         disjunctive
        </a>
       </i>
       form used after prepositions, and (in some languages) a special form used with the preposition
       <i>
        con
       </i>
       "with" (a conservative feature inherited from Latin forms such as
       <i>
        mēcum
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        tēcum
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        nōbīscum
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; clear: right; margin:10px">
       <caption>
        Spanish inflectional classes
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
        </th>
        <th>
         "boy"
        </th>
        <th>
         "girl"
        </th>
        <th>
         "man"
        </th>
        <th>
         "woman"
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Singular
        </th>
        <td>
         chico
        </td>
        <td>
         chica
        </td>
        <td>
         hombre
        </td>
        <td>
         mujer
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Plural
        </th>
        <td>
         chicos
        </td>
        <td>
         chicas
        </td>
        <td>
         hombres
        </td>
        <td>
         mujeres
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The system of inflectional classes is also drastically reduced. The basic system is most clearly indicated in Spanish, where there are only three classes, corresponding to the first, second and third declensions in Latin: plural in
       <i>
        -as
       </i>
       (feminine), plural in
       <i>
        -os
       </i>
       (masculine), plural in
       <i>
        -es
       </i>
       (either masculine or feminine). The singular endings exactly track the plural, except the singular
       <i>
        -e
       </i>
       is dropped after certain consonants.
      </p>
      <p>
       The same system underlines many other modern Romance languages, such as Portuguese, French and Catalan. In these languages, however, further sound changes have resulted in various irregularities. In Portuguese, for example, loss of /l/ and /n/ between vowels (with nasalization in the latter case) produces various irregular plurals (
       <i>
        nação – nações
       </i>
       "nation(s)";
       <i>
        hotel – hotéis
       </i>
       "hotel(s)").
      </p>
      <p>
       In French and Catalan, loss of /o/ and /e/ in most unstressed final syllables has caused the
       <i>
        -os
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        -es
       </i>
       classes to merge. In French, merger of remaining /e/ with final /a/ into
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ə]
       </span>
       , and its subsequent loss, has completely obscured the original Romance system, and loss of final /s/ has caused most nouns to have identical pronunciation in singular and plural, although they are still marked differently in spelling (e.g.
       <i>
        femme – femmes
       </i>
       "woman – women", both pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fam/
       </span>
       ).
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; clear: right; margin:10px">
       <caption>
        Romanian noun inflections
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="2">
         Definiteness
        </th>
        <th rowspan="2">
         Case
        </th>
        <th colspan="2">
         "boy"
        </th>
        <th colspan="2">
         "girl"
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Singular
        </th>
        <th>
         Plural
        </th>
        <th>
         Singular
        </th>
        <th>
         Plural
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="3">
         Indefinite
        </th>
        <th>
         Nominative
         <br/>
         Accusative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         băiat
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         băieți
        </td>
        <td>
         fată
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         fete
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
         <br/>
         Dative
        </th>
        <td>
         fete
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Vocative
        </th>
        <td>
         băiatule, băiete
        </td>
        <td>
         băietilor
        </td>
        <td>
         fato (fată)
        </td>
        <td>
         fetelor
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="2">
         Definite
        </th>
        <th>
         Nominative
         <br/>
         Accusative
        </th>
        <td>
         băiatul
        </td>
        <td>
         băieții
        </td>
        <td>
         fata
        </td>
        <td>
         fetele
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
         <br/>
         Dative
        </th>
        <td>
         băiatului
        </td>
        <td>
         băieților
        </td>
        <td>
         fetei
        </td>
        <td>
         fetelor
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Noun inflection has survived in Romanian somewhat better than elsewhere.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-harris-vincent-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         399
        </span>
       </sup>
       Determiners are still marked for two cases (nominative/accusative and genitive/dative) in both singular and plural, and feminine singular nouns have separate endings for the two cases. In addition, there is a separate vocative case, enriched with native development and Slavic borrowings (see some examples
       <a href="/wiki/Vocative_case#Romanian" title="Vocative case">
        here
       </a>
       ) and the combination of noun with a following
       <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
        clitic
       </a>
       definite article produces a separate set of "definite" inflections for nouns.
      </p>
      <p>
       The inflectional classes of Latin have also survived more in Romanian than elsewhere, e.g.
       <i>
        om – oameni
       </i>
       "man – men" (Latin
       <i>
        homo
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        homines
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        corp – corpuri
       </i>
       "body – bodies" (Latin
       <i>
        corpus
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        corpora
       </i>
       ). (Many other exceptional forms, however, are due to later sound changes or analogy, e.g.
       <i>
        casă – case
       </i>
       "house(s)" vs.
       <i>
        lună – luni
       </i>
       "moon(s)";
       <i>
        frate – fraţi
       </i>
       "brother(s)" vs.
       <i>
        carte – cărţi
       </i>
       "book(s)" vs.
       <i>
        vale – văi
       </i>
       "valley(s)".)
      </p>
      <p>
       In Italian, the situation is somewhere in between Spanish and Romanian. There are no case endings and relatively few classes, as in Spanish, but noun endings are generally formed with vowels instead of /s/, as in Romanian:
       <i>
        amico – amici
       </i>
       "friend(s) (masc.)",
       <i>
        amica – amiche
       </i>
       "friend(s) (fem.)";
       <i>
        cane – cani
       </i>
       "dog(s)". The masculine plural
       <i>
        amici
       </i>
       is thought to reflect the Latin nominative plural
       <i>
        -ī
       </i>
       rather than accusative plural
       <i>
        -ōs
       </i>
       (Spanish
       <i>
        -os
       </i>
       ); however, the other plurals are thought to stem from special developments of Latin
       <i>
        -ās
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        -ēs
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; clear: right; margin:10px">
       <caption>
        Evolution of case in various Romance languages (Latin
        <i>
         bonus
        </i>
        "good")
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th>
        </th>
        <th>
         Case
        </th>
        <th>
         Latin
        </th>
        <th>
         Spanish
        </th>
        <th>
         Old French
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-price_13-4">
          <a href="#cite_note-price-13">
           [13]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
          :
          <span>
           100
          </span>
         </sup>
        </th>
        <th>
         Old Sursilvan
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-harris-vincent-35">
           [35]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
          :
          <span>
           367
          </span>
         </sup>
        </th>
        <th>
         Romanian
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-2">
          <a href="#cite_note-harris-vincent-35">
           [35]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
          :
          <span>
           402
          </span>
         </sup>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="6">
         Masculine singular
        </th>
        <th>
         Nominative
        </th>
        <td>
         bonus
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         bueno
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         buens
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         buns
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         bun
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Vocative
        </th>
        <td>
         bone
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Accusative
        </th>
        <td>
         bonum
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         buen
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         biVn
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
        </th>
        <td>
         bonī
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Dative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bonō
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Ablative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="6">
         Masculine plural
        </th>
        <th>
         Nominative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bonī
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buenos
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         buen
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         biVni
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buni
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Vocative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Accusative
        </th>
        <td>
         bonōs
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         buens
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         buns
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
        </th>
        <td>
         bonōrum
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Dative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bonīs
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Ablative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="6">
         Feminine singular
        </th>
        <th>
         Nominative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bona
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buena
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buene
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buna
        </td>
        <td rowspan="3">
         bună
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Vocative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Accusative
        </th>
        <td>
         bonam
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bonae
        </td>
        <td rowspan="3">
         bune
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Dative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Ablative
        </th>
        <td>
         bonā
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th rowspan="6">
         Feminine plural
        </th>
        <th>
         Nominative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bonae
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buenas
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         buenes
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         bunas
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         bune
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Vocative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Accusative
        </th>
        <td>
         bonās
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Genitive
        </th>
        <td>
         bonārum
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Dative
        </th>
        <td rowspan="2">
         bonīs
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Ablative
        </th>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       A different type of noun inflection survived into the medieval period in a number of western Romance languages (
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Occitan" title="Old Occitan">
        Old Occitan
       </a>
       , and the older forms of a number of
       <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
        Rhaeto-Romance languages
       </a>
       ). This inflection distinguished nominative from oblique, grouping the accusative case with the oblique, rather than with the nominative as in Romanian.
      </p>
      <p>
       The oblique case in these languages generally inherits from the Latin accusative; as a result, masculine nouns have distinct endings in the two cases while most feminine nouns do not.
      </p>
      <p>
       A number of different inflectional classes are still represented at this stage. For example, the difference in the nominative case between masculine
       <i>
        li voisins
       </i>
       "the neighbor" and
       <i>
        li pere
       </i>
       "the father", and feminine
       <i>
        la riens
       </i>
       "the thing" vs.
       <i>
        la fame
       </i>
       "the woman", faithfully reflects the corresponding Latin inflectional differences (
       <i>
        vicīnus
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        pater
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        fēmina
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        rēs
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       A number of synchronically quite irregular differences between nominative and oblique reflect direct inheritances of Latin third-declension nouns with two different stems (one for the nominative singular, one for all other forms), most with of which had a stress shift between nominative and the other forms:
       <i>
        li ber – le baron
       </i>
       "baron" (
       <i>
        <u>
         ba
        </u>
        rō
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        ba
        <u>
         rō
        </u>
        nem
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        la suer – la seror
       </i>
       "sister" (
       <i>
        <u>
         so
        </u>
        ror
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        so
        <u>
         rō
        </u>
        rem
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        li prestre – le prevoire
       </i>
       "priest" (
       <i>
        <u>
         pres
        </u>
        byter
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        pres
        <u>
         by
        </u>
        terem
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        li sire – le seigneur
       </i>
       "lord" (
       <i>
        <u>
         se
        </u>
        nior
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        se
        <u>
         niōr
        </u>
        em
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        li enfes – l'enfant
       </i>
       "child" (
       <i>
        <u>
         in
        </u>
        fāns
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        in
        <u>
         fan
        </u>
        tem
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kibler_36-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-kibler-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         36–39
        </span>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A few of these multi-stem nouns derive from Latin forms without stress shift, e.g.
       <i>
        li om – le ome
       </i>
       "man" (
       <i>
        <u>
         ho
        </u>
        mō
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        <u>
         ho
        </u>
        minem
       </i>
       ). All of these multi-stem nouns refer to people; other nouns with stress shift in Latin (e.g.
       <i>
        <u>
         a
        </u>
        mor
       </i>
       –
       <i>
        a
        <u>
         mō
        </u>
        rem
       </i>
       "love") have not survived. Some of the same nouns with multiple stems in
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Occitan" title="Old Occitan">
        Old Occitan
       </a>
       have come down in Italian in the nominative rather than the accusative (e.g.
       <i>
        uomo
       </i>
       "man" &lt;
       <i>
        <u>
         ho
        </u>
        mō
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        moglie
       </i>
       "wife" &lt;
       <i>
        <u>
         mu
        </u>
        lier
       </i>
       ), suggesting that a similar system existed in pre-literary Italian.
      </p>
      <p>
       The modern situation in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sursilvan" title="Sursilvan">
        Sursilvan
       </a>
       (one of the
       <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
        Rhaeto-Romance languages
       </a>
       ) is unique in that the original nominative/oblique distinction has been reinterpreted as a predicative/attributive distinction:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-harris-vincent-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        :
        <span>
         381
        </span>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <i>
         il hotel ej vɛɲiws
         <u>
          natsionalizaws
         </u>
        </i>
        "the hotel has been nationalized"
       </li>
       <li>
        <i>
         il hotel
         <u>
          natsionalizaw
         </u>
        </i>
        "the nationalized hotel"
        <div style="clear:both;">
        </div>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span id="Pronouns.2C_determiners">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Pronouns,_determiners">
        Pronouns, determiners
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Pronouns, determiners">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       As described above, case marking on pronouns is much more extensive than for nouns.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Determiner_(linguistics)" title="Determiner (linguistics)">
        Determiners
       </a>
       (e.g. words such as "a", "the", "this") are also marked for case in Romanian.
      </p>
      <p>
       Most Romance languages have the following sets of pronouns and determiners:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Personal_pronoun" title="Personal pronoun">
         Personal pronouns
        </a>
        , in three persons and two genders.
       </li>
       <li>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Reflexive_pronoun" title="Reflexive pronoun">
         reflexive pronoun
        </a>
        , used when the object is the same as the subject. This approximately corresponds to English "-self", but separate forms exist only in the third person, with no number marking.
       </li>
       <li>
        Definite and indefinite
        <a href="/wiki/Article_(grammar)" title="Article (grammar)">
         articles
        </a>
        , and in some languages, a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partitive_article" title="Partitive article">
         partitive article
        </a>
        that expresses the concept of "some".
       </li>
       <li>
        A two-way or three-way distinction among
        <a href="/wiki/Demonstrative" title="Demonstrative">
         demonstratives
        </a>
        . Many languages have a three-way distinction of distance (near me, near you, near him) which, though not paralleled in current English, used to be present as "this/that/yon".
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Relative_pronoun" title="Relative pronoun">
         Relative pronouns
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Interrogative" title="Interrogative">
         interrogatives
        </a>
        , with the same forms used for both (similar to English "who" and "which").
       </li>
       <li>
        Various
        <a href="/wiki/Indefinite_pronoun" title="Indefinite pronoun">
         indefinite pronouns
        </a>
        and determiners (e.g. Spanish
        <i>
         algún
        </i>
        "some",
        <i>
         alguien
        </i>
        "someone",
        <i>
         algo
        </i>
        "something";
        <i>
         ningún
        </i>
        "no",
        <i>
         nadie
        </i>
        "no one";
        <i>
         todo
        </i>
        "every";
        <i>
         cada
        </i>
        "each";
        <i>
         mucho
        </i>
        "much/many/a lot",
        <i>
         poco
        </i>
        "few/little";
        <i>
         otro
        </i>
        "other/another"; etc.).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_pronouns">
        Personal pronouns
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Personal pronouns">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Unlike in English, a separate neuter personal pronoun ("it") generally does not exist, but the third-person singular and plural both distinguish masculine from feminine. Also, as described above, case is marked on pronouns even though it is not usually on nouns, similar to English. As in English, there are forms for
       <a href="/wiki/Nominative_case" title="Nominative case">
        nominative case
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Subject_pronoun" title="Subject pronoun">
        subject pronouns
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Oblique_case" title="Oblique case">
        oblique case
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Object_pronoun" title="Object pronoun">
        object pronouns
       </a>
       ), and
       <a href="/wiki/Genitive_case" title="Genitive case">
        genitive case
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Possessive_pronoun" title="Possessive pronoun">
        possessive pronouns
       </a>
       ); in addition, third-person pronouns distinguish accusative and dative. There is also an additional set of possessive determiners, distinct from the genitive case of the personal pronoun; this corresponds to the English difference between "my, your" and "mine, yours".
      </p>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Development_from_Latin">
        Development from Latin
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Development from Latin">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       The Romance languages do not retain the Latin third-person personal pronouns, but have innovated a separate set of third-person pronouns by borrowing the demonstrative
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       ("that (over there)"), and creating a separate reinforced demonstrative by attaching a variant of
       <i>
        ecce
       </i>
       "behold!" (or "here is ...") to the pronoun.
      </p>
      <p>
       Similarly, in place of the genitive of the Latin pronouns, most Romance languages adopted the reflexive possessive, which then serves indifferently as both reflexive and non-reflexive possessive. Note that the reflexive, and hence the third-person possessive, is unmarked for the gender of the person being referred to. Hence, although gendered possessive forms do exist—e.g. Portuguese
       <i>
        seu
       </i>
       (masc.) vs.
       <i>
        sua
       </i>
       (fem.)—these refer to the gender of the object possessed, not the possessor.
      </p>
      <p>
       The gender of the possessor needs to be made clear by a collocation such as French
       <i>
        la voiture à lui/elle
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        o carro dele/dela
       </i>
       , literally "the car of him/her". (In spoken
       <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">
        Brazilian Portuguese
       </a>
       , these collocations are the usual way of expressing the third-person possessive, since the former possessive
       <i>
        seu carro
       </i>
       now has the meaning "your car".)
      </p>
      <p>
       The same demonstrative
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       was borrowed to create the definite article (see below), which explains the similarity in form between personal pronoun and definite article. When the two are different, it is usually because of differing degrees of phonetic reduction. Generally, the personal pronoun is unreduced (beyond normal sound change), while the article has suffered various amounts of reduction, e.g. Spanish
       <i>
        ella
       </i>
       "she" &lt;
       <i>
        illa
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        la
       </i>
       "the (fem.)" &lt;
       <i>
        -la
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        illa
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Clitic_pronouns">
        Clitic pronouns
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Clitic pronouns">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       Object pronouns in Latin were normal words, but in the Romance languages they have become
       <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
        clitic
       </a>
       forms, which must stand adjacent to a verb and merge phonologically with it. Originally, object pronouns could come either before or after the verb; sound change would often produce different forms in these two cases, with numerous additional complications and contracted forms when multiple clitic pronouns cooccurred.
      </p>
      <p>
       Catalan still largely maintains this system with a
       <a href="/wiki/Catalan_personal_pronouns" title="Catalan personal pronouns">
        highly complex clitic pronoun system
       </a>
       . Most languages, however, have simplified this system by undoing some of the clitic mergers and requiring clitics to stand in a particular position relative to the verb (usually after imperatives, before other finite forms, and either before or after non-finite forms depending on the language).
      </p>
      <p>
       When a pronoun cannot serve as a clitic, a separate
       <a href="/wiki/Disjunctive_pronoun" title="Disjunctive pronoun">
        disjunctive
       </a>
       form is used. These result from dative object pronouns pronounced with stress (which causes them to develop differently from the equivalent unstressed pronouns), or from subject pronouns.
      </p>
      <p>
       Most Romance languages are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Null_subject_language" title="Null subject language">
        null subject languages
       </a>
       . The subject pronouns are used only for emphasis and take the stress, and as a result are not clitics. In French, however (as in
       <a href="/wiki/Friulian_language" title="Friulian language">
        Friulian
       </a>
       and in some
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallo-Italian_languages" title="Gallo-Italian languages">
        Gallo-Italian languages
       </a>
       of northern Italy), verbal agreement marking has degraded to the point that subject pronouns have become mandatory, and have turned into clitics. These forms cannot be stressed, so for emphasis the disjunctive pronouns must be used in combination with the clitic subject forms. Friulian and the Gallo-Italian languages have actually gone further than this and merged the subject pronouns onto the verb as a new type of verb agreement marking, which must be present even when there is a subject noun phrase. (Some non-standard varieties of French treat
       <a href="/wiki/Disjunctive_pronoun" title="Disjunctive pronoun">
        disjunctive pronouns
       </a>
       as arguments and
       <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
        clitic pronouns
       </a>
       as agreement markers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </p>
      <h5>
       <span id="Familiar.E2.80.93formal_distinction">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Familiar–formal_distinction">
        Familiar–formal distinction
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Familiar–formal distinction">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       In medieval times, most Romance languages developed a distinction between familiar and polite second-person pronouns (a so-called
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T-V_distinction" title="T-V distinction">
         T-V distinction
        </a>
       </i>
       ), similar to the former English distinction between familiar "thou" and polite "you". This distinction was determined by the relationship between the speakers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As in English, this generally developed by appropriating the plural second-person pronoun to serve in addition as a polite singular. French is still at this stage, with familiar singular
       <i>
        tu
       </i>
       vs. formal or plural
       <i>
        vous
       </i>
       . In cases like this, the pronoun requires plural agreement in all cases whenever a single affix marks both person and number (as in verb agreement endings and object and possessive pronouns), but singular agreement elsewhere where appropriate (e.g.
       <i>
        vous-même
       </i>
       "yourself" vs.
       <i>
        vous-mêmes
       </i>
       "yourselves").
      </p>
      <p>
       Many languages, however, innovated further in developing an even more polite pronoun, generally composed of a noun phrase (e.g. Portuguese
       <i>
        vossa mercê
       </i>
       "your mercy", progressively reduced to
       <i>
        vossemecê
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        vosmecê
       </i>
       and finally
       <i>
        você
       </i>
       ) and taking third-person singular agreement. A plural equivalent was created at the same time or soon after (Portuguese
       <i>
        vossas mercês
       </i>
       , reduced to
       <i>
        vocês
       </i>
       ), taking third-person plural agreement. Spanish innovated similarly, with
       <i>
        usted(es)
       </i>
       from earlier
       <i>
        vuestra(s) merced(es)
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In Portuguese and Spanish (as in other languages with similar forms), the "extra-polite" forms in time came to be the normal polite forms, and the former polite (or plural) second-person
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       knocked down to a familiar form, either becoming a familiar plural (as in European Spanish) or a familiar singular (as in many varieties of Latin American Spanish). In the latter case, it either competes with the original familiar singular
       <i>
        tu
       </i>
       (as in Guatemala), displaces it entirely (as in Argentina), or is itself displaced (as in Mexico, except in Chiapas). In American Spanish, the gap created by the loss of familiar plural
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       was filled by originally polite
       <i>
        ustedes
       </i>
       , with the result that there is no familiar/polite distinction in the plural, just as in the original
       <i>
        tu/vos
       </i>
       system.
      </p>
      <p>
       A similar path was followed by Italian and Romanian. Romanian uses
       <i>
        dumneavoastră
       </i>
       "your lordship", while Italian the former polite phrase
       <i>
        sua eccellenza
       </i>
       "your excellency" has simply been supplanted by the corresponding pronoun
       <i>
        Ella
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        Lei
       </i>
       (literally "she", but capitalized when meaning "you"). As in European Spanish, the original second-person plural
       <i>
        voi
       </i>
       serves as familiar plural. (In Italy, during
       <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">
        fascist
       </a>
       times leading up to
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
        World War II
       </a>
       ,
       <i>
        voi
       </i>
       was resurrected as a polite singular, and discarded again afterwards, although it remains in some southern dialects.)
      </p>
      <p>
       Portuguese innovated again in developing a new extra-polite pronoun
       <i>
        o senhor
       </i>
       "the sir", which in turn downgraded
       <i>
        você
       </i>
       . Hence, modern European Portuguese has a three-way distinction between "familiar"
       <i>
        tu
       </i>
       , "equalizing"
       <i>
        você
       </i>
       and "polite"
       <i>
        o senhor
       </i>
       . (The original second-person plural
       <i>
        vós
       </i>
       was discarded centuries ago in speech, and is used today only in translations of the Bible, where
       <i>
        tu
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        vós
       </i>
       serve as universal singular and plural pronouns, respectively.)
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">
        Brazilian Portuguese
       </a>
       , however, has diverged from this system, and most dialects simply use
       <i>
        você
       </i>
       (and plural
       <i>
        vocês
       </i>
       ) as a general-purpose second-person pronoun, combined with
       <i>
        te
       </i>
       (from
       <i>
        tu
       </i>
       ) as the clitic object pronoun. The form
       <i>
        o senhor
       </i>
       (and feminine
       <i>
        a senhora
       </i>
       ) is sometimes used in speech, but only in situations where an English speaker would say "sir" or "ma'am". The result is that second-person verb forms have disappeared, and the whole pronoun system has been radically realigned. However that is the case only in the spoken language of central and northern Brazil, with the northeastern and southern areas of the country still largely preserving the second-person verb form and the "tu" and "você" distinction.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Articles">
        Articles
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Articles">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Latin had no articles as such. The closest definite article was the non-specific demonstrative
       <i>
        is, ea, id
       </i>
       meaning approximately "this/that/the". The closest indefinite articles were the indefinite determiners
       <i>
        aliquī, aliqua, aliquod
       </i>
       "some (non-specific)" and
       <i>
        certus
       </i>
       "a certain".
      </p>
      <p>
       Romance languages have both indefinite and definite articles, but none of the above words form the basis for either of these. Usually the definite article is derived from the Latin demonstrative
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       ("that"), but some languages (e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
        Sardinian
       </a>
       , and some dialects spoken around the Pyrenees) have forms from
       <i>
        ipse
       </i>
       (emphatic, as in "I myself"). The indefinite article everywhere is derived from the number
       <i>
        ūnus
       </i>
       ("one").
      </p>
      <p>
       Some languages, e.g. French and Italian, have a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partitive_article" title="Partitive article">
        partitive article
       </a>
       that approximately translates as "some". This is used either with
       <a href="/wiki/Mass_noun" title="Mass noun">
        mass nouns
       </a>
       or with plural nouns—both cases where the indefinite article cannot occur. A partitive article is used (and in French, required) whenever a bare noun refers to specific (but unspecified or unknown) quantity of the noun, but not when a bare noun refers to a class in general. For example, the partitive would be used in both of the following sentences:
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <ul>
         <li>
          I want milk.
         </li>
         <li>
          Men arrived today.
         </li>
        </ul>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       But neither of these:
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <ul>
         <li>
          Milk is good for you.
         </li>
         <li>
          I hate men.
         </li>
        </ul>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       The sentence "Men arrived today", however, (presumably) means "some specific men arrived today" rather than "men, as a general class, arrived today" (which would mean that there were no men before today). On the other hand, "I hate men" does mean "I hate men, as a general class" rather than "I hate some specific men".
      </p>
      <p>
       As in many other cases, French has developed the farthest from Latin in its use of articles. In French, nearly all nouns, singular and plural, must be accompanied by an article (either indefinite, definite, or partitive) or demonstrative pronoun.
      </p>
      <p>
       Due to pervasive sound changes in French, most nouns are pronounced identically in the singular and plural, and there is often heavy
       <a href="/wiki/Homophony" title="Homophony">
        homophony
       </a>
       between nouns and identically pronounced words of other classes. For example, all of the following are pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /sɛ̃/
       </span>
       :
       <i>
        sain
       </i>
       "healthy";
       <i>
        saint
       </i>
       "saint, holy";
       <i>
        sein
       </i>
       "breast";
       <i>
        ceins
       </i>
       "(you) put on, gird";
       <i>
        ceint
       </i>
       "(he) puts on, girds";
       <i>
        ceint
       </i>
       "put on, girded"; and the equivalent noun and adjective plural forms
       <i>
        sains, saints, seins, ceints
       </i>
       . The article helps identify the noun forms
       <i>
        saint
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        sein
       </i>
       , and distinguish singular from plural; likewise, the mandatory subject of verbs helps identify the verb
       <i>
        ceint
       </i>
       . In more conservative Romance languages, neither articles nor subject pronouns are necessary, since all of the above words are pronounced differently. In Italian, for example, the equivalents are
       <i>
        sano, santo, seno, cingi, cinge, cinto, sani, santi, seni, cinti
       </i>
       , where all vowels and consonants are pronounced as written, and ⟨s⟩ /s/ and ⟨c⟩ /t͡ʃ/ are clearly distinct from each other.
      </p>
      <p>
       Latin, at least originally, had a three-way distinction among demonstrative pronouns distinguished by
       <a href="/wiki/Demonstrative#Distal_and_proximal_demonstratives" title="Demonstrative">
        distal
       </a>
       value:
       <i>
        hic
       </i>
       'this',
       <i>
        iste
       </i>
       'that (near you)',
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       'that (over there)', similar to the distinction that used to exist in English as "this" vs. "that" vs. "yon(der)". In urban Latin of Rome,
       <i>
        iste
       </i>
       came to have a specifically derogatory meaning, but this innovation apparently did not reach the provinces and is not reflected in the modern Romance languages. A number of these languages still have such a three-way distinction, although
       <i>
        hic
       </i>
       has been lost and the other pronouns have shifted somewhat in meaning. For example, Spanish has
       <i>
        este
       </i>
       "this" vs.
       <i>
        ese
       </i>
       "that (near you)" vs.
       <i>
        aquel
       </i>
       (fem.
       <i>
        aquella
       </i>
       ) "that (over yonder)". The Spanish pronouns derive, respectively, from Latin
       <i>
        iste
       </i>
       <i>
        ipse
       </i>
       <i>
        accu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       , where
       <i>
        accu-
       </i>
       is an emphatic prefix derived from
       <i>
        eccum
       </i>
       "behold (it!)" (still vigorous in Italy as
       <i>
        Ecco!
       </i>
       'Behold!'), possibly with influence from
       <i>
        atque
       </i>
       "and".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Reinforced demonstratives such as
       <i>
        accu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       arose as
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       came to be used as an article as well as a demonstrative. Such forms were often created even when not strictly needed to distinguish otherwise ambiguous forms. Italian, for example, has both
       <i>
        questo
       </i>
       "this" (
       <i>
        eccu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        istum
       </i>
       ) and
       <i>
        quello
       </i>
       "that" (
       <i>
        eccu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        illum
       </i>
       ), in addition to dialectal
       <i>
        codesto
       </i>
       "that (near you)" (*
       <i>
        eccu-tē-istum
       </i>
       ). French generally prefers forms derived from bare
       <i>
        ecce
       </i>
       "behold", as in the pronoun
       <i>
        ce
       </i>
       "this one/that one" (earlier
       <i>
        ço
       </i>
       , from
       <i>
        ecce
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hoc
       </i>
       ; cf. Italian
       <i>
        ciò
       </i>
       'that') and the determiner
       <i>
        ce/cet
       </i>
       "this/that" (earlier
       <i>
        cest
       </i>
       , from
       <i>
        ecce
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        istum
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Reinforced forms are likewise common in
       <a href="/wiki/Locative_adverb" title="Locative adverb">
        locative adverbs
       </a>
       (words such as English
       <i>
        here
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        there
       </i>
       ), based on related Latin forms such as
       <i>
        hic
       </i>
       "this" vs.
       <i>
        hīc
       </i>
       "here",
       <i>
        hāc
       </i>
       "this way", and
       <i>
        ille
       </i>
       "that" vs.
       <i>
        illīc
       </i>
       "there",
       <i>
        illāc
       </i>
       "that way". Here again French prefers bare
       <i>
        ecce
       </i>
       while Spanish and Italian prefer
       <i>
        eccum
       </i>
       (French
       <i>
        ici
       </i>
       "here" vs. Spanish
       <i>
        aquí
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        qui
       </i>
       ). In western languages such as Spanish, Portuguese and Catalan, doublets and triplets arose such as Portuguese
       <i>
        aqui, acá, cá
       </i>
       "(to) here" (
       <i>
        accu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hīc
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        accu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hāc
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        eccu
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hāc
       </i>
       ). From these, a prefix
       <i>
        a-
       </i>
       was extracted, from which forms like
       <i>
        aí
       </i>
       "there (near you)" (
       <i>
        a-(i)bi
       </i>
       ) and
       <i>
        ali
       </i>
       "there (over yonder)" (
       <i>
        a-(i)llīc
       </i>
       ) were created; compare Catalan neuter pronouns
       <i>
        açò
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        acce
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hoc
       </i>
       ) "this",
       <i>
        això
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        a-(i)psum
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hoc
       </i>
       ) "that (near you)",
       <i>
        allò
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        a-(i)llum
       </i>
       -
       <i>
        hoc
       </i>
       ) "that (yonder)".
      </p>
      <p>
       Subsequent changes often reduced the number of demonstrative distinctions. Standard Italian, for example, has only a two-way distinction "this" vs. "that", as in English, with second-person and third-person demonstratives combined. In Catalan, however, a former three-way distinction
       <i>
        aquest, aqueix, aquell
       </i>
       has been reduced differently, with first-person and second-person demonstratives combined. Hence
       <i>
        aquest
       </i>
       means either "this" or "that (near you)"; on the phone,
       <i>
        aquest
       </i>
       is used to refer both to speaker and addressee.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       had a similar distinction to Italian (
       <i>
        cist/cest
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        cil/cel
       </i>
       ), both of which could function as either adjectives or pronouns. Modern French, however, has no distinction between "this" and "that":
       <i>
        ce/cet, cette
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        cest, ceste
       </i>
       is only an adjective, and
       <i>
        celui, celle
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        cel lui, celle
       </i>
       is only a pronoun, and both forms indifferently mean either "this" or "that". (The distinction between "this" and "that" can be made, if necessary, by adding the suffixes
       <i>
        -ci
       </i>
       "here" or
       <i>
        -là
       </i>
       "there", e.g.
       <i>
        cette femme-ci
       </i>
       "this woman" vs.
       <i>
        cette femme-là
       </i>
       "that woman", but this is rarely done except when specifically necessary to distinguish two entities from each other.)
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Verbal_morphology">
        Verbal morphology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Verbal morphology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Romance_verbs" title="Romance verbs">
        Romance verbs
       </a>
      </div>

        </td>

       <tr>
        <th>
         Future indicative
        </th>
        <td>
         —
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          eres
         </i>
         ("you are")
        </td>
        <td>

        </td>
        <td>

        </td>

         <br/>

         </a>
        </td>

        </td>

       <tr>
        <th>
         Preterite vs. present perfect
         <br/>
         (in speech)
        </th>
        <td>
         preterite only
         <br/>
         (present perfect exists,
         <br/>
         but has different meaning)
        </td>
        <td>
         both
        </td>
        <td>
         both (but usually an analytic preterite
         <br/>
         <i>
          vado
         </i>
         +infinitive is used)
        </td>
        <td>
         ?
        </td>
        <td>
         present perfect only
        </td>
        <td>
         present perfect only
        </td>
        <td>
         both (Tuscan Standard Italian);
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-accademiadellacrusca.it_40-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-accademiadellacrusca.it-40">
           [40]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <br/>
         present perfect only
         <br/>
         (Regional Standard Italian in North);
         <br/>
         preference for preterite
         <br/>
         (Regional Standard Italian in South)
        </td>
        <td>
         present perfect only
        </td>
        <td>
         present perfect only
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Verbs have many
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_conjugation" title="Grammatical conjugation">
        conjugations
       </a>
       , including in most languages:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Present_tense" title="Present tense">
         present tense
        </a>
        , a
        <a href="/wiki/Preterite" title="Preterite">
         preterite
        </a>
        , an
        <a href="/wiki/Imperfect" title="Imperfect">
         imperfect
        </a>
        , a
        <a href="/wiki/Pluperfect" title="Pluperfect">
         pluperfect
        </a>
        , a
        <a href="/wiki/Future_tense" title="Future tense">
         future tense
        </a>
        and a
        <a href="/wiki/Future_perfect" title="Future perfect">
         future perfect
        </a>
        in the indicative mood, for statements of fact.
       </li>
       <li>
        Present and preterite
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subjunctive" title="Subjunctive">
         subjunctive
        </a>
        tenses, for hypothetical or uncertain conditions. Several languages (for example, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish) have also imperfect and pluperfect subjunctives, although it is not unusual to have just one subjunctive equivalent for preterit and imperfect (e.g. no unique subjunctive equivalent in Italian of the so-called
        <i>
         passato remoto
        </i>
        ). Portuguese and Spanish also have future and future perfect subjunctives, which have no equivalent in Latin.
       </li>
       <li>
        An imperative mood, for direct commands.
       </li>
       <li>
        Three
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-finite_verb" title="Non-finite verb">
         non-finite forms
        </a>
        : infinitive, gerund, and past participle.
       </li>
       <li>
        Distinct active and passive voices, as well as an
        <a href="/wiki/Impersonal_passive_voice" title="Impersonal passive voice">
         impersonal passive voice
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Note that, although these
        <i>
         categories
        </i>
        are largely inherited from Classical Latin, many of the
        <i>
         forms
        </i>
        are either newly constructed or inherited from different categories (e.g. the Romance imperfect subjunctive most commonly is derived from the Latin pluperfect subjunctive, while the Romance pluperfect subjunctive is derived from a new
        <a href="/wiki/Present_perfect" title="Present perfect">
         present perfect
        </a>
        tense with the auxiliary verb placed in the imperfect subjunctive).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Several tenses and aspects, especially of the indicative mood, have been preserved with little change in most languages, as shown in the following table for the Latin verb
       <i>
        dīcere
       </i>
       (to say), and its descendants.
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <table class="wikitable" style="font-size: 85%">

          </td>
          <td>
           dijo
          </td>
          <td>
           decía
          </td>
          <td>
           diga
          </td>
          <td>
           di
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td align="left">
           <b>
            <a href="/wiki/Venetian_language" title="Venetian language">
             Venetian
            </a>
           </b>
          </td>
          <td>
           dir
          </td>
          <td>
           dise
          </td>
          <td>
           –
          </td>
          <td>
           disea
          </td>
          <td>
           diga
          </td>
          <td>
           dì/disi
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td align="left">
           <b>
            <a href="/wiki/Walloon_language" title="Walloon language">
             Walloon
            </a>
           </b>
          </td>
          <td>
           dire
          </td>
          <td>
           dit
          </td>
          <td>
           a dit
          </td>
          <td>
           dijheut
          </td>
          <td>
           dixhe
          </td>
          <td>
           di
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <th>
           <b>
            Basic meaning
           </b>
          </th>
          <td>
           to say
          </td>
          <td>
           he says
          </td>
          <td>
           he said
          </td>
          <td>
           he was saying
          </td>
          <td>
           he says
          </td>
          <td>
           say [thou]
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          1
         </sup>
         The spelling is conservative. Note the pronunciations:
         <i>
          dire
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /diʁ/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          dit
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /di/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          disait
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /dizɛ/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          dise
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /diz/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          dis
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /di/
         </span>
         .
        </small>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          2
         </sup>
         Until the eighteenth century.
        </small>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          3
         </sup>
         With the disused variant
         <i>
          dize
         </i>
         .
        </small>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          4
         </sup>
         long infinitive
        </small>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          5
         </sup>
         In modern times,
         <i>
          scheva
         </i>
         .
        </small>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          6
         </sup>
         Derived from the unrelated Latin verb
         <i>
          narrāre
         </i>
         "to tell (a story)". Note also the pronunciations:
         <i>
          narrer
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ˈnarrere/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          narat
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ˈnarada/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          at naradu
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a nnaˈradu/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          naraiat
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /narˈaiada/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          nabat
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ˈnabata/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          nerzat
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ˈnertsada/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          niet
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ˈniete/
         </span>
         ,
         <i>
          nara
         </i>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ˈnara/
         </span>
         .
        </small>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <small>
         <sup>
          7
         </sup>
         Sicilian now uses imperfect subjunctive
         <i>
          dicissi
         </i>
         in place of present subjunctive.
        </small>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       The main tense and mood distinctions that were made in classical Latin are generally still present in the modern Romance languages, though many are now expressed through
       <a href="/wiki/Periphrasis" title="Periphrasis">
        compound
       </a>
       rather than simple verbs. The passive voice, which was mostly synthetic in classical Latin, has been completely replaced with compound forms.
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Owing to sound changes which made it
        <a href="/wiki/Homonym" title="Homonym">
         homophonous
        </a>
        with the preterite, the Latin future indicative tense was dropped, and replaced with a periphrasis of the form
        <a href="/wiki/Infinitive" title="Infinitive">
         infinitive
        </a>
        + present tense of
        <i>
         habēre
        </i>
        (to have). Eventually, this structure was
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammaticalisation" title="Grammaticalisation">
         reanalysed
        </a>
        as a new
        <a href="/wiki/Future_tense" title="Future tense">
         future tense
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        In a similar process, an entirely new
        <a href="/wiki/Conditional_mood#Romance_languages" title="Conditional mood">
         conditional form
        </a>
        was created.
       </li>
       <li>
        While the synthetic
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammatical_voice" title="Grammatical voice">
         passive voice
        </a>
        of classical Latin was abandoned in favour of
        <a href="/wiki/Periphrasis" title="Periphrasis">
         periphrastic
        </a>
        constructions, most of the active voice remained in use. However, several tenses have changed meaning, especially subjunctives. For example:
        <ul>
         <li>
          The Latin pluperfect indicative became a
          <a href="/wiki/Conditional_mood" title="Conditional mood">
           conditional
          </a>
          in Sicilian, and an imperfect
          <a href="/wiki/Subjunctive_mood" title="Subjunctive mood">
           subjunctive
          </a>
          in Spanish.
         </li>
         <li>
          The Latin pluperfect subjunctive developed into an imperfect subjunctive in all languages except
          <a href="/wiki/Romansh_language" title="Romansh language">
           Romansh
          </a>
          , where it became a conditional, and Romanian, where it became a
          <a href="/wiki/Pluperfect" title="Pluperfect">
           pluperfect indicative
          </a>
          .
         </li>
         <li>
          The Latin preterite subjunctive, together with the future perfect indicative, became a future subjunctive in Old Spanish, Portuguese, and
          <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
           Galician
          </a>
          .
         </li>
         <li>
          The Latin imperfect subjunctive became a personal
          <a href="/wiki/Infinitive" title="Infinitive">
           infinitive
          </a>
          in Portuguese and Galician.
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        Many Romance languages have two
        <a href="/wiki/Copula_(linguistics)" title="Copula (linguistics)">
         verbs "to be"
        </a>
        . One is derived from Vulgar Latin *
        <i>
         essere
        </i>
        &lt; Latin
        <i>
         esse
        </i>
        "to be" with an admixture of forms derived from
        <i>
         sedēre
        </i>
        "to sit", and is used mostly for essential attributes; the other is derived from
        <i>
         stāre
        </i>
        "to stand", and mostly used for temporary states. This development is most notable in Spanish, Portuguese and Catalan. In French, Italian and Romanian, the derivative of
        <i>
         stāre
        </i>
        largely preserved an earlier meaning of "to stand/to stay", although in modern Italian,
        <i>
         stare
        </i>
        is used in a few constructions where English would use "to be", as in
        <i>
         sto bene
        </i>
        "I am well". In
        <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
         Old French
        </a>
        , the derivatives of *
        <i>
         essere
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         stāre
        </i>
        were
        <i>
         estre
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         ester
        </i>
        , respectively. In modern French,
        <i>
         estre
        </i>
        persists as
        <i>
         être
        </i>
        "to be" while
        <i>
         ester
        </i>
        has been lost as a separate verb; but the former imperfect of
        <i>
         ester
        </i>
        is used as the modern imperfect of
        <i>
         être
        </i>
        (e.g.
        <i>
         il était
        </i>
        "he was"), replacing the irregular forms derived from Latin (e.g.
        <i>
         ere(t), iere(t)
        </i>
        &lt;
        <i>
         erat
        </i>
        ). In Italian, the two verbs share the same past participle,
        <i>
         stato
        </i>
        .
        <i>
         sedēre
        </i>
        persists most notably in the future of *
        <i>
         essere
        </i>
        (e.g. Spanish/Portuguese/French/etc.
        <i>
         ser-
        </i>
        , Italian
        <i>
         sar-
        </i>
        ), although in
        <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
         Old French
        </a>
        the future is a direct derivation from Latin, e.g.
        <i>
         (i)ert
        </i>
        "he will be" &lt;
        <i>
         erit
        </i>
        . See
        <a href="/wiki/Romance_copula" title="Romance copula">
         Romance copula
        </a>
        for further information.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       For a more detailed illustration of how the verbs have changed with respect to classical Latin, see
       <a href="/wiki/Romance_verbs" title="Romance verbs">
        Romance verbs
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        During the
        <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">
         Renaissance
        </a>
        , Italian, Portuguese, Spanish and a few other Romance languages developed a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Progressive_aspect" title="Progressive aspect">
         progressive aspect
        </a>
        which did not exist in Latin. In French, progressive constructions remain very limited, the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperfective" title="Imperfective">
         imperfect
        </a>
        generally being preferred, as in Latin.
       </li>
       <li>
        Many Romance languages now have a verbal construction analogous to the
        <a href="/wiki/Present_perfect" title="Present perfect">
         present perfect
        </a>
        of English. In some, it has taken the place of the old
        <a href="/wiki/Preterite" title="Preterite">
         preterite
        </a>
        (at least in the vernacular); in others, the two coexist with somewhat different meanings (cf. English
        <i>
         I did
        </i>
        vs.
        <i>
         I have done
        </i>
        ). A few examples:
        <ul>
         <li>
          preterite only: Galician, Asturian, Sicilian, Leonese, Portuguese, some dialects of Spanish;
         </li>
         <li>
          preterite and present perfect: Catalan, Occitan, standard Spanish;
         </li>
         <li>
          present perfect predominant, preterite now literary: French, Romanian, several dialects of Italian, some dialects of Spanish;
         </li>
         <li>
          present perfect only: Romansh
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Note that in
       <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
        Catalan
       </a>
       , the synthetic preterite is predominantly a literary tense, except in
       <a href="/wiki/Valencian" title="Valencian">
        Valencian
       </a>
       ; but an analytic preterite (formed using an auxiliary
       <i>
        vadō
       </i>
       , which in other languages signals the future) persists in speech, with the same meaning. In
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       , a morphological present perfect does exist but has a different meaning (closer to "I have been doing").
      </p>
      <p>
       The following are common features of the Romance languages (inherited from
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       ) that are different from Classical Latin:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Adjectives generally follow the noun they modify.
       </li>
       <li>
        The normal clause structure is
        <a href="/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object" title="Subject–verb–object">
         SVO
        </a>
        , rather than
        <a href="/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93object%E2%80%93verb" title="Subject–object–verb">
         SOV
        </a>
        , and is much less flexible than in Latin.
       </li>
       <li>
        Many Latin constructions involving nominalized verbal forms (e.g. the use of accusative plus infinitive in
        <a href="/wiki/Free_indirect_speech" title="Free indirect speech">
         indirect discourse
        </a>
        and the use of the
        <a href="/wiki/Latin_grammar" title="Latin grammar">
         ablative absolute
        </a>
        ) were dropped in favor of constructions with subordinate clause. Exceptions can be found in Italian, for example, Latin
        <i>
         tempore permittente
        </i>
        &gt; Italian
        <i>
         tempo permettendo
        </i>
        ; L.
        <i>
         hoc facto
        </i>
        &gt; I.
        <i>
         ciò fatto
        </i>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lexicon">
        Lexicon
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Lexicon">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Loanwords">
        Loanwords
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Loanwords">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Romance languages have borrowed heavily, though mostly from other Romance languages. However, some, such as Spanish, Portuguese, Romanian, and French, have borrowed heavily from other language groups. Vulgar Latin borrowed first from indigenous languages of the Roman empire, and during the
       <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">
        Germanic folk movements
       </a>
       , from
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic languages
       </a>
       , especially Gothic; for Eastern Romance languages, during
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Empire" title="Bulgarian Empire">
        Bulgarian Empires
       </a>
       , from
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">
        Slavic languages
       </a>
       , especially
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">
        Bulgarian
       </a>
       . Notable examples are *
       <i>
        blancus
       </i>
       "white", replacing native
       <i>
        albus
       </i>
       (but Romansh
       <i>
        alv
       </i>
       , Dalmatian
       <i>
        jualb
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        alb
       </i>
       ); *
       <i>
        guerra
       </i>
       "war", replacing native
       <i>
        bellum
       </i>
       ; and the words for the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardinal_directions" title="Cardinal directions">
        cardinal directions
       </a>
       , where
       <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">
        cognates
       </a>
       of English "north", "south", "east" and "west" replaced the native words
       <i>
        septentriō
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        merīdiēs
       </i>
       (also "noon; midday nap"; cf. Romanian
       <i>
        meriză
       </i>
       ),
       <i>
        oriens
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        occidens
       </i>
       . (See
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_French#The_Franks" title="History of French">
        History of French – The Franks
       </a>
       .) Some
       <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">
        Celtic
       </a>
       words were incorporated into the core vocabulary, partly for words with no Latin equivalent (
       <i>
        betulla
       </i>
       "birch",
       <i>
        camisia
       </i>
       "shirt",
       <i>
        cerevisia
       </i>
       "beer"), but in some cases replacing Latin vocabulary (
       <i>
        gladius
       </i>
       "sword", replacing
       <i>
        ensis
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        cambiāre
       </i>
       "to exchange", replacing
       <i>
        mūtāre
       </i>
       except in Romanian and Portuguese;
       <i>
        carrus
       </i>
       "cart", replacing
       <i>
        currus
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        pettia
       </i>
       "piece", largely displacing
       <i>
        pars
       </i>
       (later resurrected) and eliminating
       <i>
        frustum
       </i>
       ). Many Greek loans also entered the lexicon, e.g.
       <i>
        spatha
       </i>
       "sword" (Greek:
       <span lang="grc" xml:lang="grc">
        σπάθη
       </span>
       <i>
        spáthē
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       replacing
       <i>
        gladius
       </i>
       which shifted to "iris", cf. French
       <i>
        épée
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        espada
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        spada
       </i>
       and Romanian
       <i>
        spată
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        cara
       </i>
       "face" (Greek: κάρα
       <i>
        kára
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       partly replacing
       <i>
        faciēs
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        colpe
       </i>
       "blow" (Greek: κόλαφος
       <i>
        kólaphos
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       replacing
       <i>
        ictus
       </i>
       , cf. Spanish
       <i>
        golpe
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        coup
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        cata
       </i>
       "each" (Greek:
       <span lang="grc" xml:lang="grc">
        κατά
       </span>
       <i>
        katá
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
