        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       replacing
       <i>
        quisque
       </i>
       ); common suffixes *
       <i>
        -ijāre/-izāre
       </i>
       (Greek:
       <span lang="grc" xml:lang="grc">
        -ίζειν
       </span>
       <i>
        -izein
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
       French
       <i>
        oyer/-iser
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        -ear/-izar
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        -eggiare/-izzare
       </i>
       , etc.),
       <i>
        -ista
       </i>
       (Greek:
       <span lang="grc" xml:lang="grc">
        -ιστής
       </span>
       <i>
        -istes
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lexical_innovation">
        Lexical innovation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Lexical innovation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Many basic nouns and verbs, especially those that were short or had irregular morphology, were replaced by longer derived forms with regular morphology. Nouns, and sometimes adjectives, were often replaced by
       <a href="/wiki/Diminutive" title="Diminutive">
        diminutives
       </a>
       , e.g.
       <i>
        auris
       </i>
       "ear" &gt;
       <i>
        auricula
       </i>
       (orig. "outer ear") &gt;
       <i>
        oricla
       </i>
       (Sardinian
       <i>
        origra
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        orecchia/o
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        orelha
       </i>
       , etc.);
       <i>
        avis
       </i>
       "bird" &gt;
       <i>
        avicellus
       </i>
       (orig. "chick, nestling") &gt;
       <i>
        aucellu
       </i>
       (Occitan
       <i>
        aucèl
       </i>
       , Friulan
       <i>
        ucel
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        oiseau
       </i>
       , etc.);
       <i>
        caput
       </i>
       "head" &gt;
       <i>
        capitium
       </i>
       (Portuguese
       <i>
        cabeça
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        cabeza
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        chevet
       </i>
       "headboard"; but reflexes of
       <i>
        caput
       </i>
       were retained also, sometimes without change of meaning, as in Italian
       <i>
        capo
       </i>
       "head", alongside
       <i>
        testa
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        vetus
       </i>
       "old" &gt;
       <i>
        vetulus
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        veclus
       </i>
       (Dalmatian
       <i>
        vieklo
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        vecchio
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        velho
       </i>
       , etc.). Sometimes
       <a href="/wiki/Augmentative" title="Augmentative">
        augmentative
       </a>
       constructions were used instead:
       <i>
        piscis
       </i>
       "fish" &gt; Old French
       <i>
        peis
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        peisson
       </i>
       (orig. "big fish") &gt; French
       <i>
        poisson
       </i>
       . Verbs were often replaced by
       <a href="/wiki/Frequentative" title="Frequentative">
        frequentative
       </a>
       constructions:
       <i>
        canere
       </i>
       "to sing" &gt;
       <i>
        cantāre
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        iacere
       </i>
       "to throw" &gt;
       <i>
        iactāre
       </i>
       &gt; *
       <i>
        iectāre
       </i>
       (Italian
       <i>
        gettare
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        jeitar
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        echar
       </i>
       , etc.);
       <i>
        iuvāre
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        adiūtāre
       </i>
       (Italian
       <i>
        aiutare
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        ayudar
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        aider
       </i>
       , etc., meaning "help", alongside e.g.
       <i>
        iuvāre
       </i>
       &gt; Italian
       <i>
        giovare
       </i>
       "to be of use");
       <i>
        vēnārī
       </i>
       "hunt" (Romanian "vâna", Aromanian "avin, avinari") &gt; replaced by *
       <i>
        captiāre
       </i>
       "to hunt", frequentative of
       <i>
        capere
       </i>
       "to seize" (Italian
       <i>
        cacciare
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        caçar
       </i>
       , Romansh
       <i>
        catschar
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        chasser
       </i>
       , etc.).
      </p>
      <p>
       Many Classical Latin words became archaic or poetic and were replaced by more colloquial terms:
       <i>
        equus
       </i>
       "horse" &gt;
       <i>
        caballus
       </i>
       (orig. "nag") (but
       <i>
        equa
       </i>
       "mare" remains, cf. Spanish
       <i>
        yegua
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        égua
       </i>
       , Sardinian
       <i>
        ebba
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        iapă
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        domus
       </i>
       "house" &gt;
       <i>
        casa
       </i>
       (orig. "hut");
       <i>
        ignis
       </i>
       "fire" &gt;
       <i>
        focus
       </i>
       (orig. "hearth");
       <i>
        strāta
       </i>
       "street" &gt;
       <i>
        rūga
       </i>
       (orig. "furrow") or
       <i>
        callis
       </i>
       (orig. "footpath") (but
       <i>
        strāta
       </i>
       is continued in Italian
       <i>
        strada
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        stradă
       </i>
       and secondarily in e.g. Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        estrada
       </i>
       "causeway, paved road"). In some cases, terms from common occupations became generalized:
       <i>
        invenīre
       </i>
       "to find" replaced by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibero-Romance" title="Ibero-Romance">
        Ibero-Romance
       </a>
       <i>
        afflāre
       </i>
       (orig. "to sniff out", in hunting, cf. Spanish
       <i>
        hallar
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        achar
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        afla(to find out)
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        advenīre
       </i>
       "to arrive" gave way to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ibero-Romance" title="Ibero-Romance">
        Ibero-Romance
       </a>
       <i>
        plicāre
       </i>
       (orig. "to fold (sails; tents)", cf. Spanish
       <i>
        llegar
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        chegar
       </i>
       ; Romanian
       <i>
        pleca
       </i>
       ), elsewhere
       <i>
        arripāre
       </i>
       (orig. "to harbor at a riverbank", cf. Italian
       <i>
        arrivare
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        arriver
       </i>
       ) (
       <i>
        advenīre
       </i>
       is continued with the meaning "to achieve, manage to do" as in Middle French
       <i>
        aveindre
       </i>
       , or "to happen" in Italian
       <i>
        avvenire
       </i>
       ) . The same thing sometimes happened to religious terms, due to the pervasive influence of Christianity:
       <i>
        loquī
       </i>
       "to speak" succumbed to
       <i>
        parabolāre
       </i>
       (orig. "to tell parables", cf. Occitan
       <i>
        parlar
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        parler
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        parlare
       </i>
       ) or
       <i>
        fabulārī
       </i>
       (orig. "to tell stories", cf. Spanish
       <i>
        hablar
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        falar
       </i>
       ), based on Jesus' way of speaking in
       <a href="/wiki/Parable" title="Parable">
        parables
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Many prepositions were used as verbal particles to make new roots and verb stems, e.g. Italian
       <i>
        estrarre
       </i>
       , Aromanian
       <i>
        astragu, astradziri
       </i>
       "to extract" from Latin
       <i>
        ex-
       </i>
       "out of" and
       <i>
        trahere
       </i>
       "to pull" (Italian
       <i>
        trarre
       </i>
       "draw, pull"), or to augment already existing words, e.g. French
       <i>
        coudre
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        cucire
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        coser
       </i>
       "to sew", from
       <i>
        cōnsuere
       </i>
       "to sew up", from
       <i>
        suere
       </i>
       "to sew", with total loss of the bare stem. Many prepositions and commonly became compounded, e.g.
       <i>
        de ex
       </i>
       &gt; French
       <i>
        dès
       </i>
       "as of",
       <i>
        ab ante
       </i>
       &gt; Italian
       <i>
        avanti
       </i>
       "forward". Some words derived from phrases, e.g. Portuguese
       <i>
        agora
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        ahora
       </i>
       "now" &lt;
       <i>
        hāc hōrā
       </i>
       "at this hour"; French
       <i>
        avec
       </i>
       "with" (prep.) &lt; Old French
       <i>
        avuec
       </i>
       (adv.) &lt;
       <i>
        apud hoc
       </i>
       ("near that"); Spanish
       <i>
        tamaño
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        tamanho
       </i>
       "size" &lt;
       <i>
        tam magnum
       </i>
       "so big"; Italian
       <i>
        codesto
       </i>
       "this, that" (near you) &lt; Old Italian
       <i>
        cotevesto
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        eccum tibi istum
       </i>
       approx. "here's that thing of yours"; Portuguese
       <i>
        você
       </i>
       "you"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       &lt;
       <i>
        vosmecê
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        vossemecê
       </i>
       &lt; Galician-Portuguese
       <i>
        vossa mercee
       </i>
       "your mercy".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A number of common Latin words that have disappeared in many or most Romance languages have survived either in the periphery or in remote corners (especially Sardinia and Romania), or as secondary terms, sometimes differing in meaning. For example, Latin
       <i>
        caseum
       </i>
       "cheese" in the more outer places (Portuguese
       <i>
        queijo
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        queso
       </i>
       , Romansh
       <i>
        caschiel
       </i>
       , Sardinian
       <i>
        càsu
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        caş
       </i>
       ), but in the central areas has been replaced by
       <i>
        formāticum
       </i>
       , originally "moulded (cheese)" (French
       <i>
        fromage
       </i>
       , Occitan/Catalan
       <i>
        formatge
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        formaggio
       </i>
       , with, however,
       <i>
        cacio
       </i>
       also available; similarly
       <i>
        (com)edere
       </i>
       "to eat (up)", which survives as Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        comer
       </i>
       but elsewhere is replaced by
       <i>
        mandūcāre
       </i>
       , originally "to chew" (French
       <i>
        manger
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        mangiare
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        menjar
       </i>
       , but Spanish/Portuguese noun
       <i>
        manjar
       </i>
       "food" or "uplifting meal"). In some cases, one language happens to preserve a word displaced elsewhere, e.g. Italian
       <i>
        ogni
       </i>
       "each, every" &lt;
       <i>
        omnes
       </i>
       , displaced elsewhere by
       <i>
        tōtum
       </i>
       , originally "whole" or by a reflex of Greek
       <i>
        κατά
       </i>
       (e.g. Italian
       <i>
        ognuno
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        tothom
       </i>
       "everyone"; Italian
       <i>
        ogni giorno
       </i>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        cada día
       </i>
       "every day"); Friulan
       <i>
        vaî
       </i>
       "to cry" &lt;
       <i>
        flere
       </i>
       "to weep";
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vegliote" title="Vegliote">
        Vegliote
       </a>
       <i>
        otijemna
       </i>
       "fishing pole" &lt;
       <i>
        antenna
       </i>
       "yardarm"; Aromanian "sprunã" (warm ashes) &lt; pruna (burning coal). Sardinian even preserves some words that were already archaic in Classical Latin, e.g.
       <i>
        àchina
       </i>
       "grape" &lt;
       <i>
        acinam
       </i>
       , also found in Sicilian
       <i>
        ràcina
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Latinisms">
        Latinisms
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Latinisms">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       During the Middle Ages, scores of words were borrowed directly from Classical Latin (so-called
       <a href="/wiki/Latinism" title="Latinism">
        Latinisms
       </a>
       ), either in their original form (
       <i>
        learned loans
       </i>
       ) or in a somewhat nativized form (
       <i>
        semi-learned loans
       </i>
       ). These resulted in many
       <a href="/wiki/Doublet_(linguistics)" title="Doublet (linguistics)">
        doublets
       </a>
       —pairs of inherited and learned words—such as those in the table below:
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <th>
         Latin
        </th>
        <th>
         Romance
        </th>
        <th>
         Inherited
        </th>
        <th>
         Latinism
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          fragilis
         </i>
         "fragile"
        </td>
        <td>
         French
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          frêle
         </i>
         "frail"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          fragile
         </i>
         "fragile"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          fabrica
         </i>
         "craft, manufacture"
        </td>
        <td>
         French
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          forge
         </i>
         "forge"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          fabrique
         </i>
         "factory"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          fabrica
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         Spanish
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          fragua
         </i>
         "forge"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          fábrica
         </i>
         "factory"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          fabrica
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         Romanian
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          făură
         </i>
         "blacksmith (archaic)"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          fabrică
         </i>
         "factory"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          lēgālis
         </i>
         "legal"
        </td>
        <td>
         French
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          loyal
         </i>
         "loyal"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          légal
         </i>
         "legal"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          lēgālis
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         Spanish
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          leal
         </i>
         "loyal"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          legal
         </i>
         "legal"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          advōcātus
         </i>
         "advocate (noun)"
        </td>
        <td>
         French
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          avoué
         </i>
         "solicitor (attorney)"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          avocat
         </i>
         "barrister (attorney)"
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          polīre
         </i>
         "to polish"
        </td>
        <td>
         Portuguese
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          puir
         </i>
         "to wear thin"
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          polir
         </i>
         "to polish"
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Sometimes triplets arise: Latin
       <i>
        articulus
       </i>
       "joint" &gt; Portuguese
       <i>
        artículo
       </i>
       "joint, knuckle" (learned),
       <i>
        artigo
       </i>
       "article" (semi-learned),
       <i>
        artelho
       </i>
       "ankle" (inherited; archaic and dialectal). In many cases, the learned word simply displaced the original popular word: e.g. Spanish
       <i>
        crudo
       </i>
       "crude, raw" (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Spanish" title="Old Spanish">
        Old Spanish
       </a>
       <i>
        cruo
       </i>
       ); French
       <i>
        légume
       </i>
       "vegetable" (
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       <i>
        leüm
       </i>
       ); Portuguese
       <i>
        flor
       </i>
       "flower" (Galician-Portuguese
       <i>
        chor
       </i>
       ). The learned loan always looks more like the original than the inherited word does, because regular
       <a href="/wiki/Sound_change" title="Sound change">
        sound change
       </a>
       has been bypassed; and likewise, the learned word usually has a meaning closer to that of the original. In French, however, the stress of the learned loan may be on the "wrong" syllable, whereas the stress of the inherited word always corresponds to the Latin stress: e.g. Latin
       <i>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vipera#Latin" title="wikt:vipera">
         vipera
        </a>
       </i>
       vs. French
       <i>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vip%C3%A8re#French" title="wikt:vipère">
         vipère
        </a>
       </i>
       , learned loan, and
       <i>
        guivre/
        <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vouivre#French" title="wikt:vouivre">
         vouivre
        </a>
       </i>
       , inherited.
      </p>
      <p>
       Borrowing from Classical Latin has produced a large number of suffix doublets. Examples from Spanish (learned form first):
       <i>
        -ción
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        -zon
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        -cia
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        -za
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        -ificar
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        -iguar
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        -izar
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        -ear
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        -mento
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        -miento
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        -tud
       </i>
       (&lt; nominative
       <i>
        -tūdō
       </i>
       ) vs.
       <i>
        -dumbre
       </i>
       (&lt; accusative
       <i>
        -tūdine
       </i>
       );
       <i>
        -ículo
       </i>
       vs.
       <i>
        -ejo
       </i>
       ; etc. Similar examples can be found in all the other Romance languages.
      </p>
      <p>
       This borrowing also introduced large numbers of classical prefixes in their original form (
       <i>
        dis-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        ex-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        post-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        trans
       </i>
       -) and reinforced many others (
       <i>
        re-
       </i>
       , popular Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        des-
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        dis-
       </i>
       , popular French
       <i>
        dé-
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        dis-
       </i>
       , popular Italian
       <i>
        s-
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        ex-
       </i>
       ). Many Greek prefixes and suffixes (
       <a href="/wiki/Hellenism_(neoclassicism)" title="Hellenism (neoclassicism)">
        hellenisms
       </a>
       ) also found their way into the lexicon:
       <i>
        tele-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        poli-/poly-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        meta-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        pseudo-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -scope/scopo
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -logie/logia/logía
       </i>
       , etc.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sound_changes">
        Sound changes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Sound changes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          <img alt="[]" data-file-height="100" data-file-width="75" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/30px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/45px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/60px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png 2x" width="30"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;">
         <b>
          This article contains
          <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
           IPA
          </a>
          phonetic symbols.
         </b>
         Without proper
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Fonts" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          rendering support
         </a>
         , you may see
         <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">
          question marks, boxes, or other symbols
         </a>
         instead of
         <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
          Unicode
         </a>
         characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">
          Help:IPA
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Consonants_2">
        Consonants
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Consonants">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Significant
       <a href="/wiki/Sound_change" title="Sound change">
        sound changes
       </a>
       affected the consonants of the Romance languages.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Apocope">
        Apocope
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Apocope">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       There was a tendency to eliminate final consonants in Vulgar Latin, either by dropping them (
       <a href="/wiki/Apocope" title="Apocope">
        apocope
       </a>
       ) or adding a vowel after them (
       <a href="/wiki/Epenthesis" title="Epenthesis">
        epenthesis
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Many final consonants were rare, occurring only in certain prepositions (e.g.
       <i>
        ad
       </i>
       "towards",
       <i>
        apud
       </i>
       "at, near (a person)"), conjunctions (
       <i>
        sed
       </i>
       "but"), demonstratives (e.g.
       <i>
        illud
       </i>
       "that (over there)",
       <i>
        hoc
       </i>
       "this"), and nominative singular noun forms, especially of neuter nouns (e.g.
       <i>
        lac
       </i>
       "milk",
       <i>
        mel
       </i>
       "honey",
       <i>
        cor
       </i>
       "heart"). Many of these prepositions and conjunctions were replaced by others, while the nouns were regularized into forms based on their oblique stems that avoided the final consonants (e.g. *
       <i>
        lacte
       </i>
       , *
       <i>
        mele
       </i>
       , *
       <i>
        core
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Final
       <i>
        -m
       </i>
       was dropped in Vulgar Latin. Even in
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
        Classical Latin
       </a>
       , final
       <i>
        -am
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -em
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Suffix#Inflectional_suffixes" title="Suffix">
        inflectional suffixes
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Accusative_case" title="Accusative case">
        accusative case
       </a>
       ) were often
       <a href="/wiki/Elision" title="Elision">
        elided
       </a>
       in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meter_(poetry)" title="Meter (poetry)">
        poetic meter
       </a>
       , suggesting the
       <i>
        m
       </i>
       was weakly pronounced, probably marking the
       <a href="/wiki/Nasal_vowel" title="Nasal vowel">
        nasalisation
       </a>
       of the vowel before it. This nasal vowel lost its nasalization in the Romance languages except in monosyllables, where it became
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /n/
       </span>
       e.g. Spanish
       <i>
        quien
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        quem
       </i>
       "whom", French
       <i>
        rien
       </i>
       "anything" &lt;
       <i>
        rem
       </i>
       "thing"; note especially French and Catalan
       <i>
        mon
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        meum
       </i>
       "my (m.sg.)" pronounced as one syllable (
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /meu̯m/
       </span>
       &gt; *
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /meu̯n/, /mun/
       </span>
       ) but Spanish
       <i>
        mío
       </i>
       and Portuguese and Catalan
       <i>
        meu
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        meum
       </i>
       pronounced as two (
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈme.um/
       </span>
       &gt; *
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈme.o/
       </span>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       As a result, only the following final consonants occurred in Vulgar Latin:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Final
        <i>
         -t
        </i>
        in third-person singular verb forms, and
        <i>
         -nt
        </i>
        (later reduced in many languages to
        <i>
         -n
        </i>
        ) in third-person plural verb forms.
       </li>
       <li>
        Final
        <i>
         -s
        </i>
        (including
        <i>
         -x
        </i>
        ) in a large number of morphological endings (verb endings
        <i>
         -ās/-ēs/-īs/-is
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         -mus
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         -tis
        </i>
        ; nominative singular
        <i>
         -us/-is
        </i>
        ; plural
        <i>
         -ās/-ōs/-ēs
        </i>
        ) and certain other words (
        <i>
         trēs
        </i>
        "three",
        <i>
         sex
        </i>
        "six",
        <i>
         crās
        </i>
        "tomorrow", etc.).
       </li>
       <li>
        Final
        <i>
         -n
        </i>
        in some monosyllables (from earlier
        <i>
         -m
        </i>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        Final
        <i>
         -r
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         -d
        </i>
        in some prepositions (e.g.
        <i>
         ad
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         per
        </i>
        ), which were
        <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
         clitics
        </a>
        that attached phonologically to the following word.
       </li>
       <li>
        Very occasionally, final
        <i>
         -c
        </i>
        , e.g.
        <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
         Occitan
        </a>
        <i>
         oc
        </i>
        "yes" &lt;
        <i>
         hoc
        </i>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
         Old French
        </a>
        <i>
         avuec
        </i>
        "with" &lt;
        <i>
         apud hoc
        </i>
        (although these instances were possibly protected by a final
        <a href="/wiki/Epenthesis" title="Epenthesis">
         epenthetic
        </a>
        vowel at one point).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       Final
       <i>
        -t
       </i>
       was eventually dropped in many languages, although this often occurred several centuries after the Vulgar Latin period. For example, the reflex of
       <i>
        -t
       </i>
       was dropped in
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Old_Spanish_language" title="Old Spanish language">
        Old Spanish
       </a>
       only around 1100. In Old French, this occurred only when a vowel still preceded the
       <i>
        t
       </i>
       (generally
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ə/
       </span>
       &lt; Latin
       <i>
        a
       </i>
       ). Hence
       <i>
        amat
       </i>
       "he loves" &gt; Old French
       <i>
        aime
       </i>
       but
       <i>
        venit
       </i>
       "he comes" &gt; Old French
       <i>
        vient
       </i>
       : the
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /t/
       </span>
       was never dropped and survives into Modern French in
       <a href="/wiki/Liaison_(French)" title="Liaison (French)">
        liaison
       </a>
       , e.g.
       <i>
        vient-il?
       </i>
       "is he coming?"
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /vjɛ̃ti(l)/
       </span>
       (the corresponding
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /t/
       </span>
       in
       <i>
        aime-t-il?
       </i>
       is analogical, not inherited). Old French also kept the third-person plural ending
       <i>
        -nt
       </i>
       intact.
      </p>
      <p>
       In Italo-Romance and the
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Romance_languages" title="Eastern Romance languages">
        Eastern Romance languages
       </a>
       , eventually
       <i>
        all
       </i>
       final consonants were either dropped or protected by an epenthetic vowel, except in clitic forms (e.g. prepositions
       <i>
        con
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        per
       </i>
       ). Modern Standard Italian still has almost no consonant-final words, although Romanian has resurfaced them through later loss of final
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       . For example,
       <i>
        amās
       </i>
       "you love" &gt;
       <i>
        ame
       </i>
       &gt; Italian
       <i>
        ami
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        amant
       </i>
       "they love" &gt; *
       <i>
        aman
       </i>
       &gt; Ital.
       <i>
        amano
       </i>
       . On the evidence of "sloppily written"
       <a href="/wiki/Lombardic_language" title="Lombardic language">
        Lombardic language
       </a>
       documents, however, the loss of final
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /s/
       </span>
       in Italy did not occur until the 7th or 8th century, after the Vulgar Latin period, and the presence of many former final consonants is betrayed by the
       <a href="/wiki/Syntactic_gemination" title="Syntactic gemination">
        syntactic gemination
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        raddoppiamento sintattico
       </i>
       ) that they trigger. It is also thought that after a long vowel
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /s/
       </span>
       became
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       rather than simply disappearing:
       <i>
        nōs
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        noi
       </i>
       "we",
       <i>
        se(d)ēs
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        sei
       </i>
       "you are",
       <i>
        crās
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        crai
       </i>
       "tomorrow" (southern Italian). In unstressed syllables, the resulting diphthongs were simplified:
       <i>
        canēs
       </i>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈkanej/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <i>
        cani
       </i>
       "dogs";
       <i>
        amīcās
       </i>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /aˈmikaj/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <i>
        amiche
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /aˈmike/
       </span>
       "(female) friends", where nominative
       <i>
        amīcae
       </i>
       should produce
       <i>
        **amice
       </i>
       rather than
       <i>
        amiche
       </i>
       (note masculine
       <i>
        amīcī
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        amici
       </i>
       not
       <i>
        **amichi
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Central
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Romance_languages" title="Western Romance languages">
        Western Romance languages
       </a>
       eventually regained a large number of final consonants through the general loss of final
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       , e.g. Catalan
       <i>
        llet
       </i>
       "milk" &lt;
       <i>
        lactem
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        foc
       </i>
       "fire" &lt;
       <i>
        focum
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        peix
       </i>
       "fish" &lt;
       <i>
        piscem
       </i>
       . In French, most of these secondary final consonants (as well as primary ones) were lost before around 1700, but tertiary final consonants later arose through the loss of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ə/
       </span>
       &lt;
       <i>
        -a
       </i>
       . Hence masculine
       <i>
        frīgidum
       </i>
       "cold" &gt; Old French
       <i>
        freit
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /frwεt/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <i>
        froid
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fʁwa/
       </span>
       , feminine
       <i>
        frigidam
       </i>
       &gt; Old French
       <i>
        freide
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /frwεdə/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <i>
        froide
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fʁwad/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Palatalization">
        Palatalization
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Palatalization">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       For a table of examples of palatalized n and l in the Romance languages, see
       <a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)#Mouillé" title="Palatalization (sound change)">
        Palatalization (sound change) § Mouillé
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)" title="Palatalization (sound change)">
        Palatalization
       </a>
       was one of the most important processes affecting consonants in Vulgar Latin. This eventually resulted in a whole series of "
       <a href="/wiki/Palatal_consonant" title="Palatal consonant">
        palatal
       </a>
       " and
       <a href="/wiki/Postalveolar_consonant" title="Postalveolar consonant">
        postalveolar
       </a>
       consonants in most Romance languages, e.g. Italian
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʃ/, /ʒ/, /tʃ/, /dʒ/, /ts/, /dz/, /ɲ/, /ʎ/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The following historical stages occurred:
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center">
       <tr>
        <th>
         Stage
        </th>
        <th>
         Environment
        </th>
        <th>
         Consonants affected
        </th>
        <th>
         Result
        </th>
        <th>
         Languages affected
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         1
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         before
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /j/
         </span>
         (from
         <i>
          e
         </i>
         ,
         <i>
          i
         </i>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Hiatus_(linguistics)" title="Hiatus (linguistics)">
          hiatus
         </a>
         )
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /t/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /d/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /tsʲ/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /jj~dzʲ~ddʒʲ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         all
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         2
        </td>
        <td>
         all remaining, except
         <a href="/wiki/Labial_consonant" title="Labial consonant">
          labial consonants
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ttʃʲ~ttsʲ/
         </span>
         &lt;
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /kj/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /jj~ddʒʲ/
         </span>
         &lt;
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɡj/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɲɲ/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ʎʎ/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /Cʲ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         all except
         <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
          Sardinian
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         3
        </td>
        <td>
         before
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="3">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /k/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɡ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /tʃʲ~tsʲ/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /j~dʒʲ/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         4
        </td>
        <td>
         before
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         all except Sardinian and
         <a href="/wiki/Dalmatian_language" title="Dalmatian language">
          Dalmatian
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         5
        </td>
        <td>
         before
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /au/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /tɕ~tʃʲ/
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /dʑ~dʒʲ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         north-central
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance" title="Gallo-Romance">
          Gallo-Romance
         </a>
         (e.g.
         <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
          French
         </a>
         , northern
         <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
          Occitan
         </a>
         );
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance" title="Rhaeto-Romance">
          Rhaeto-Romance
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Note how the environments become progressively less "palatal", and the languages affected become progressively fewer.
      </p>
      <p>
       The outcomes of palatalization depended on the historical stage, the consonants involved, and the languages involved. The primary division is between the Western Romance languages, with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ts/
       </span>
       resulting from palatalization of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /k/
       </span>
       , and the remaining languages (Italo-Dalmatian and Eastern Romance), with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       resulting. It is often suggested that
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       was the original result in all languages, with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ts/
       </span>
       a later innovation in the Western Romance languages. Evidence of this is the fact that Italian has both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ttʃ/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tts/
       </span>
       as outcomes of palatalization in different environments, while Western Romance has only
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /(t)ts/
       </span>
       . Even more suggestive is the fact that the
       <a href="/wiki/Mozarabic_language" title="Mozarabic language">
        Mozarabic language
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">
        al-Andalus
       </a>
       (modern southern Spain) had
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       as the outcome despite being in the "Western Romance" area and geographically disconnected from the remaining
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       areas; this suggests that Mozarabic was an outlying "relic" area where the change
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ts/
       </span>
       failed to reach. (Northern French dialects, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Norman_language" title="Norman language">
        Norman
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Picard_language" title="Picard language">
        Picard
       </a>
       , also had
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       , but this may be a secondary development, i.e. due to a later sound change
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ts/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       .) Note that
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ts, dz, dʒ/
       </span>
       eventually became /s, z, ʒ/ in most Western Romance languages. Thus Latin
       <i>
        caelum
       </i>
       (sky, heaven), pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈkai̯lu(m)]
       </span>
       with an initial
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k]
       </span>
       , became Italian
       <i>
        cielo
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈtʃɛlo]
       </span>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        cer
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [tʃer]
       </span>
       , Spanish
       <i>
        cielo
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈθjelo]
       </span>
       /
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈsjelo]
       </span>
       , French
       <i>
        ciel
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [sjɛl]
       </span>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        cel
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈsɛɫ]
       </span>
       , and Portuguese
       <i>
        céu
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈsɛw]
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The outcome of palatalized
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /d/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɡ/
       </span>
       is less clear:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Original
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /j/
        </span>
        has the same outcome as palatalized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɡ/
        </span>
        everywhere.
       </li>
       <li>
        Romanian fairly consistently has
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /z/
        </span>
        &lt;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dz/
        </span>
        from palatalized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /d/
        </span>
        , but
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dʒ/
        </span>
        from palatalized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɡ/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Italian inconsistently has
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ddz~ddʒ/
        </span>
        from palatalized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /d/
        </span>
        , and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ddʒ/
        </span>
        from palatalized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɡ/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Most other languages have the same results for palatalized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /d/
        </span>
        and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɡ/
        </span>
        : consistent
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dʒ/
        </span>
        initially, but either
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /j/
        </span>
        or
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /dʒ/
        </span>
        medially (depending on language and exact context). But
        <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
         Spanish
        </a>
        has
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /j/
        </span>
        (phonetically
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ɟ͡ʝ]
        </span>
        ) initially except before
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /o/
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /u/
        </span>
        ; nearby
        <a href="/wiki/Gascon_language" title="Gascon language">
         Gascon
        </a>
        is similar.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       This suggests that palatalized
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /d/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /dʲ/
       </span>
       &gt; either
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       or
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /dz/
       </span>
       depending on location, while palatalized
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɡ/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       ; after this,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /(d)dʒ/
       </span>
       in most areas, but Spanish and Gascon (originating from isolated districts behind the western
       <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">
        Pyrenees
       </a>
       ) were relic areas unaffected by this change.
      </p>
      <p>
       In French, the outcomes of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /k, ɡ/
       </span>
       palatalized by
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e, i, j/
       </span>
       and by
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /a, au/
       </span>
       were different:
       <i>
        centum
       </i>
       "hundred" &gt;
       <i>
        cent
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /sɑ̃/
       </span>
       but
       <i>
        cantum
       </i>
       "song" &gt;
       <i>
        chant
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʃɑ̃/
       </span>
       . French also underwent palatalization of labials before
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       : Vulgar Latin
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /pj, bj~vj, mj/
       </span>
       &gt; Old French
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ, dʒ, ndʒ/
       </span>
       (
       <i>
        sēpia
       </i>
       "cuttlefish" &gt;
       <i>
        seiche
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        rubeus
       </i>
       "red" &gt;
       <i>
        rouge
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        sīmia
       </i>
       "monkey" &gt;
       <i>
        singe
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       The original outcomes of palatalization must have continued to be phonetically palatalized even after they had developed into
       <a href="/wiki/Alveolar_consonant" title="Alveolar consonant">
        alveolar
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/Postalveolar_consonant" title="Postalveolar consonant">
        postalveolar
       </a>
       /etc. consonants. This is clear from French, where all originally palatalized consonants triggered the development of a following glide
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       in certain circumstances (most visible in the endings
       <i>
        -āre
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -ātum/ātam
       </i>
       ). In some cases this
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /j/
       </span>
       came from a consonant palatalized by an adjoining consonant after the late loss of a separating vowel. For example,
       <i>
        mansiōnātam
       </i>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /masʲoˈnata/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        masʲˈnada/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /masʲˈnʲæðə/
       </span>
       &gt; early
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       <i>
        maisnieḍe
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /maisˈniɛðə/
       </span>
       "household". Similarly,
       <i>
        mediētātem
       </i>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mejeˈtate/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mejˈtade/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mejˈtæðe/
       </span>
       &gt; early
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       <i>
        meitieḍ
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mejˈtʲɛθ/
       </span>
       &gt; modern French
       <i>
        moitié
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mwaˈtje/
       </span>
       "half". In both cases, phonetic palatalization must have remained in primitive Old French at least through the time when unstressed
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Intertonic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Intertonic (page does not exist)">
        intertonic
       </a>
       vowels were lost (?
       <abbr title="circa">
        c.
       </abbr>
       8th century), well after the fragmentation of the Romance languages.
      </p>
      <p>
       The effect of palatalization is indicated in the writing systems of almost all Romance languages, where the letters have the "hard" pronunciation
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [k, ɡ]
       </span>
       in most situations, but a "soft" pronunciation (e.g. French/Portuguese
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [s, ʒ]
       </span>
       , Italian/Romanian
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [tʃ, dʒ]
       </span>
       ) before ⟨e, i, y⟩. (This orthographic trait has passed into Modern English through
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_French" title="Norman French">
        Norman French
       </a>
       -speaking scribes writing
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">
        Middle English
       </a>
       ; this replaced the earlier system of
       <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">
        Old English
       </a>
       , which had developed its own hard-soft distinction with the soft ⟨c, g⟩ representing
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [tʃ, j~dʒ]
       </span>
       .) This has the effect of keeping the modern spelling similar to the original Latin spelling, but complicates the relationship between sound and letter. In particular, the hard sounds must be written differently before ⟨e, i, y⟩ (e.g. Italian ⟨ch, gh⟩, Portuguese ⟨qu, gu⟩), and likewise for the soft sounds when not before these letters (e.g. Italian ⟨ci, gi⟩, Portuguese ⟨ç, j⟩). Furthermore, in Spanish, Catalan, Occitan and Brazilian Portuguese, the use of digraphs containing ⟨u⟩ to signal the hard pronunciation before ⟨e, i, y⟩ means that a different spelling is also needed to signal the sounds
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /kw, ɡw/
       </span>
       before these vowels (Spanish ⟨cu, gü⟩, Catalan, Occitan and Brazilian Portuguese ⟨qü, gü⟩).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This produces a number of orthographic alternations in verbs whose pronunciation is entirely regular. The following are examples of corresponding first-person plural indicative and subjunctive in a number of regular Portuguese verbs:
       <i>
        marcamos, marquemos
       </i>
       "we mark";
       <i>
        caçamos, cacemos
       </i>
       "we hunt";
       <i>
        chegamos, cheguemos
       </i>
       "we arrive";
       <i>
        averiguamos, averigüemos
       </i>
       "we verify";
       <i>
        adequamos, adeqüemos
       </i>
       "we adapt";
       <i>
        oferecemos, ofereçamos
       </i>
       "we offer";
       <i>
        dirigimos, dirijamos
       </i>
       "we drive"
       <i>
        erguemos, ergamos
       </i>
       "we raise";
       <i>
        delinquimos, delincamos
       </i>
       "we commit a crime". In the case of Italian, the convention of digraphs &lt;ch&gt; and &lt;gh&gt; to represent /k/ and /g/ before written &lt;e, i&gt; results in similar orthographic alternations, such as
       <i>
        dimentico
       </i>
       'I forget',
       <i>
        dimentichi
       </i>
       'you forget',
       <i>
        baco
       </i>
       'worm',
       <i>
        bachi
       </i>
       'worms' with [k] or
       <i>
        pago
       </i>
       'I pay',
       <i>
        paghi
       </i>
       'you pay' and
       <i>
        lago
       </i>
       'lake',
       <i>
        laghi
       </i>
       'lakes' with [g]. The use in Italian of &lt;ci&gt; and &lt;gi&gt; to represent /tʃ/ or /dʒ/ before vowels written &lt;a,o,u&gt; neatly distinguishes
       <i>
        dico
       </i>
       'I say' with /k/ from
       <i>
        dici
       </i>
       'you say' with /tʃ/ or
       <i>
        ghiro
       </i>
       'dormouse' /g/ and
       <i>
        giro
       </i>
       'turn, revolution' /dʒ/, but with orthographic &lt;ci&gt; and &lt;gi&gt; also representing the sequence of /tʃ/ or /dʒ/ and the actual vowel /i/ (/ditʃi/
       <i>
        dici
       </i>
       , /dʒiro/
       <i>
        giro
       </i>
       ), and no generally observed convention of indicating stress position, the status of
       <i>
        i
       </i>
       when followed by another vowel in spelling can be unrecognizable. For example, the written forms offer no indication that &lt;cia&gt; in
       <i>
        camicia
       </i>
       'shirt' represents a single unstressed syllable /tʃa/ with no /i/ at any level (/kaˈmitʃa/ → [kaˈmiːtʃa] ~ [kaˈmiːʃa]), but that underlying the same spelling &lt;cia&gt; in
       <i>
        farmacia
       </i>
       'pharmacy' is a bisyllabic sequence of /tʃ/ and stressed /i/ (/farmaˈtʃia/ → [farmaˈtʃiːa] ~ [farmaˈʃiːa]).
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lenition">
        Lenition
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Lenition">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Stop_consonant" title="Stop consonant">
        Stop consonants
       </a>
       shifted by
       <a href="/wiki/Lenition" title="Lenition">
        lenition
       </a>
       in Vulgar Latin.
      </p>
      <p>
       The voiced
       <a href="/wiki/Labial_consonant" title="Labial consonant">
        labial consonants
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /b/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /w/
       </span>
       (represented by ⟨b⟩ and ⟨v⟩, respectively) both developed a
       <a href="/wiki/Voiced_bilabial_fricative" title="Voiced bilabial fricative">
        fricative
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [β]
       </span>
       as an intervocalic allophone.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This is clear from the orthography; in medieval times, the spelling of a consonantal ⟨v⟩ is often used for what had been a ⟨b⟩ in Classical Latin, or the two spellings were used interchangeably. In many Romance languages (Italian, French, Portuguese, Romanian, etc.), this fricative later developed into a
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /v/
       </span>
       ; but in others (Spanish, Galician, some Catalan and Occitan dialects, etc.) reflexes of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /b/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /w/
       </span>
       simply merged into a single phoneme.
      </p>
      <p>
       Several other consonants were "softened" in intervocalic position in Western Romance (Spanish, Portuguese, French, Northern Italian), but normally not phonemically in the rest of Italy (except some cases of "elegant" or Ecclesiastical words), nor apparently at all in Romanian. The dividing line between the two sets of dialects is called the
       <a href="/wiki/La_Spezia%E2%80%93Rimini_Line" title="La Spezia–Rimini Line">
        La Spezia–Rimini Line
       </a>
       and is one of the most important
       <a href="/wiki/Isogloss" title="Isogloss">
        isoglosses
       </a>
       of the Romance dialects. The changes (instances of diachronic lenition) are as follows:
      </p>
      <p>
       Single voiceless plosives became
       <a href="/wiki/Voice_(phonetics)" title="Voice (phonetics)">
        voiced
       </a>
       :
       <i>
        -p-, -t-, -c-
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        -b-, -d-, -g-
       </i>
       . Subsequently, in some languages they were further weakened, either becoming
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fricative" title="Fricative">
        fricatives
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Approximant_consonant" title="Approximant consonant">
        approximants
       </a>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [β̞], [ð̞], [ɣ˕]
       </span>
       (as in Spanish) or disappearing entirely (as
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /t/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /k/
       </span>
       , but not
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /p/
       </span>
       , in French). The following example shows progressive weakening of original /t/: e.g.
       <i>
        vītam
       </i>
       &gt; Italian
       <i>
        vita
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈvita]
       </span>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        vida
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈvidɐ]
       </span>
       (European Portuguese
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈviðɐ]
       </span>
       ), Spanish
       <i>
        vida
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈbiða]
       </span>
       (Southern Peninsular Spanish
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈbia]
       </span>
       ), and French
       <i>
        vie
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [vi]
       </span>
       . Some have speculated that these sound changes may be due in part to the influence of
       <a href="/wiki/Continental_Celtic_languages" title="Continental Celtic languages">
        Continental Celtic languages
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The voiced plosives
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /d/
        </span>
        and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɡ/
        </span>
        tended to disappear.
       </li>
       <li>
        The plain
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sibilant_consonant" title="Sibilant consonant">
         sibilant
        </a>
        <i>
         -s-
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [s]
        </span>
        was also voiced to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [z]
        </span>
        between vowels, although in many languages its spelling has not changed. (In Spanish, intervocalic
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [z]
        </span>
        was later devoiced back to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [s]
        </span>
        ;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [z]
        </span>
        is only found as an
        <a href="/wiki/Allophone" title="Allophone">
         allophone
        </a>
        of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /s/
        </span>
        before voiced consonants in Modern Spanish.)
       </li>
       <li>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geminate_consonant" title="Geminate consonant">
         double
        </a>
        plosives became single:
        <i>
         -pp-, -tt-, -cc-, -bb-, -dd-, -gg-
        </i>
        &gt;
        <i>
         -p-, -t-, -c-, -b-, -d-, -g-
        </i>
        in most languages. In French spelling, double consonants are merely etymological, except for -ll- after -i (pronounced [ij]), in most cases.
       </li>
       <li>
        The double sibilant
        <i>
         -ss-
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [sː]
        </span>
        also became phonetically single
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [s]
        </span>
        , although in many languages its spelling has not changed.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geminate_consonant" title="Geminate consonant">
        Consonant length
       </a>
       is no longer phonemically distinctive in most Romance languages. However some
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Italy" title="Languages of Italy">
        languages of Italy
       </a>
       (Italian,
       <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
        Sardinian
       </a>
       , Sicilian, and numerous other varieties of central and southern Italy) do have long consonants like
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɡɡ/, /dd/, /bb/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /kk/, /tt/, /pp/, /ll/, /mm/, /nn/, /ss/, /rr/
       </span>
       , etc., where the doubling indicates either actual length or, in the case of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plosive_consonants" title="Plosive consonants">
        plosives
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Affricates" title="Affricates">
        affricates
       </a>
       , a short hold before the consonant is released, in many cases with distinctive lexical value: e.g.
       <i>
        note
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈnɔ.te/
       </span>
       (notes) vs.
       <i>
        notte
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈnɔt.te/
       </span>
       (night),
       <i>
        cade
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈka.de/
       </span>
       (s/he, it falls) vs.
       <i>
        cadde
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈkad.de/
       </span>
       (s/he, it fell),
       <i>
        caro
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈka.ro/
       </span>
       (dear, expensive) vs.
       <i>
        carro
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈkar.ro/
       </span>
       (cart). They may even occur at the beginning of words in
       <a href="/wiki/Romanesco_dialect" title="Romanesco dialect">
        Romanesco
       </a>
       , Neapolitan, Sicilian and other southern varieties, and are occasionally indicated in writing, e.g. Sicilian
       <i>
        cchiù
       </i>
       (more), and
       <i>
        ccà
       </i>
       (here). In general, the consonants
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /b/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ts/
       </span>
       , and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /dz/
       </span>
       are long at the start of a word, while the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archiphoneme" title="Archiphoneme">
        archiphoneme
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        |R|
       </span>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute">
          <span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (May 2017)">
           dubious
          </span>
         </a>
         <span class="metadata">
          –
          <a href="/wiki/Talk:Romance_languages#Dubious" title="Talk:Romance languages">
           discuss
          </a>
         </span>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       is realised as a
       <a href="/wiki/Trill_consonant" title="Trill consonant">
        trill
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /r/
       </span>
       in the same position. In much of central and southern Italy, the affricates /t͡ʃ/ and /d͡ʒ/ weaken synchronically to fricative [ʃ] and [ʒ] between vowels, while their geminate congeners do not, e.g.
       <i>
        cacio
       </i>
