       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈka.t͡ʃo/ → [ˈkaːʃo]
       </span>
       (cheese) vs.
       <i>
        caccio
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈkat.t͡ʃo/ → [ˈkat.t͡ʃo]
       </span>
       (I chase).
      </p>
      <p>
       A few languages have regained secondary geminate consonants. The double consonants of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Piedmontese" title="Piedmontese">
        Piedmontese
       </a>
       exist only after stressed
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ə/
       </span>
       , written
       <i>
        ë
       </i>
       , and are not etymological:
       <i>
        vëdde
       </i>
       (Latin
       <i>
        vidēre
       </i>
       , to see),
       <i>
        sëcca
       </i>
       (Latin
       <i>
        sicca
       </i>
       , dry, feminine of
       <i>
        sech
       </i>
       ). In standard Catalan and Occitan, there exists a geminate sound
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /lː/
       </span>
       written
       <i>
        ŀl
       </i>
       (Catalan) or
       <i>
        ll
       </i>
       (Occitan), but it is usually pronounced as a simple sound in colloquial (and even some formal) speech in both languages.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prosthesis">
        Prosthesis
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Prosthesis">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Romance" title="Western Romance">
        Western Romance
       </a>
       , an
       <a href="/wiki/Epenthesis" title="Epenthesis">
        epenthetic
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Prosthesis" title="Prosthesis">
        prosthetic
       </a>
       vowel was inserted at the beginning of any word that began with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /s/
       </span>
       and another consonant:
       <i>
        spatha
       </i>
       "sword" &gt; Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        espada
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        espasa
       </i>
       , Old French
       <i>
        espeḍe
       </i>
       &gt; modern
       <i>
        épée
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        Stephanum
       </i>
       "Stephen" &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        Esteban
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        Esteve
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        Estêvão
       </i>
       , Old French
       <i>
        Estievne
       </i>
       &gt; modern
       <i>
        Étienne
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        status
       </i>
       "state" &gt; Spanish/Portuguese
       <i>
        estado
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        estat
       </i>
       , Old French
       <i>
        estat
       </i>
       &gt; modern
       <i>
        état
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        spiritus
       </i>
       "spirit" &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        espíritu
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        espírito
       </i>
       , Catalan
       <i>
        esperit
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        esprit
       </i>
       . Epenthetic /e/ in Western Romance languages was also probably influenced by Continental Celtic languages.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       While Western Romance words undergo word-initial epenthesis (prothesis), cognates in Italian do not:
       <i>
        spatha
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        spada
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        Stephanum
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        Stefano
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        status
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        stato
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        spiritus
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        spirito
       </i>
       . In Italian, syllabification rules were preserved instead by vowel-final articles, thus feminine
       <i>
        spada
       </i>
       as
       <i>
        la spada
       </i>
       , but instead of rendering the masculine
       <i>
        *il spaghetto
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        lo spaghetto
       </i>
       came to be the norm. Though receding at present, Italian once had an epenthetic
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       if a consonant preceded such clusters, so that 'in Switzerland' was
       <i>
        in
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [i]
       </span>
       <i>
        Svizzera
       </i>
       . Some speakers still use the prothetic
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [i]
       </span>
       productively, and it is fossilized in a few set phrases as
       <i>
        per iscritto
       </i>
       'in writing' (although in this case its survival may be due partly to the influence of the separate word
       <i>
        iscritto
       </i>
       &lt; Latin
       <i>
        īnscrīptus
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Stressed_vowels">
        Stressed vowels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Stressed vowels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span id="Loss_of_vowel_length.2C_reorientation">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Loss_of_vowel_length,_reorientation">
        Loss of vowel length, reorientation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Loss of vowel length, reorientation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <table cellspacing="1" class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; text-align:center;">
       <tr>
        <th colspan="9">

       </tr>
       <tr>

         <sup>

         </sup>
        </th>

        </th>
        <th colspan="2">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">

        </th>

         <i>

         </span>

         </span>
        </td>

         <b>

         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">

         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="6">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ȳ
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         long
         <i>

         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /yː/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          i (ĭ)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         short
         <i>

         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/ [ɪ]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɪ/ [ɪ(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         <b>
          ẹ
         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="4">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          y (y̆)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         short
         <i>
          y
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /y/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ē
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         long
         <i>
          e
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /eː/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/ [e(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          œ
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          oe
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /oj/
         </span>
         &gt;
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /eː/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          e (ĕ)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         short
         <i>
          e
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/ [ɛ]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɛ/ [ɛ(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <b>
          ę
         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɛ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɛ/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          æ
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          ae
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aj/
         </span>
         &gt;
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          [ɛː]
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ā
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         long
         <i>
          a
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aː/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/ [a(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <b>
          a
         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="4" rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          a (ă)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         short
         <i>
          a
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /a/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          o (ŏ)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         short
         <i>
          o
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/ [ɔ]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɔ/ [ɔ(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <b>
          ǫ
         </b>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɔ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="3">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɔ/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ō
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         long
         <i>
          o
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /oː/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/ [o(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="3">
         <b>
          ọ
         </b>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="3">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="4">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          au
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          (a few words)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          au
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aw/
         </span>
         &gt;
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /oː/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          u (ŭ)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         short
         <i>
          u
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/ [ʊ]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ʊ/ [ʊ(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ū
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         long
         <i>
          u
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /uː/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/ [u(ː)]
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <b>
          u
         </b>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          au
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          (most words)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <i>
          au
         </i>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aw/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <b>
          au
         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="4">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aw/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="9">
         <sup>
          1
         </sup>
         Traditional academic transcription in Latin and
         <a href="/wiki/Romance_studies" title="Romance studies">
          Romance studies
         </a>
         , respectively.
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       One profound change that affected Vulgar Latin was the reorganisation of its
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel" title="Vowel">
        vowel
       </a>
       system. Classical Latin had five short vowels,
       <i>
        ă, ĕ, ĭ, ŏ, ŭ
       </i>
       , and five
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel_length" title="Vowel length">
        long vowels
       </a>
       ,
       <i>
        ā, ē, ī, ō, ū
       </i>
       , each of which was an individual
       <a href="/wiki/Phoneme" title="Phoneme">
        phoneme
       </a>
       (see the table in the right, for their likely pronunciation in IPA), and four
       <a href="/wiki/Diphthong" title="Diphthong">
        diphthongs
       </a>
       ,
       <i>
        ae
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        oe
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        au
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        eu
       </i>
       (five according to some authors, including
       <i>
        ui
       </i>
       ). There were also long and short versions of
       <i>
        y
       </i>
       , representing the
       <a href="/wiki/Close_front_rounded_vowel" title="Close front rounded vowel">
        rounded vowel
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /y(ː)/
       </span>
       in Greek borrowings, which however probably came to be pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i(ː)/
       </span>
       even before Romance vowel changes started.
      </p>
      <p>
       There is evidence that in the imperial period all the short vowels except
       <i>
        a
       </i>
       differed by quality as well as by length from their long counterparts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       So, for example
       <i>
        ē
       </i>
       was pronounced
       <a href="/wiki/Close-mid_vowel" title="Close-mid vowel">
        close-mid
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /eː/
       </span>
       while
       <i>
        ĕ
       </i>
       was pronounced
       <a href="/wiki/Open-mid_vowel" title="Open-mid vowel">
        open-mid
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ/
       </span>
       , and
       <i>
        ī
       </i>
       was pronounced
       <a href="/wiki/Close_vowel" title="Close vowel">
        close
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /iː/
       </span>
       while
       <i>
        ĭ
       </i>
       was pronounced
       <a href="/wiki/Near-close_vowel" title="Near-close vowel">
        near-close
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɪ/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       During the Proto-Romance period, phonemic length distinctions were lost. Vowels came to be automatically pronounced long in stressed,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_syllable" title="Open syllable">
        open syllables
       </a>
       (i.e. when followed by only one consonant), and pronounced short everywhere else. This situation is still maintained in modern Italian:
       <i>
        cade
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈkaːde]
       </span>
       "he falls" vs.
       <i>
        cadde
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ˈkadde]
       </span>
       "he fell".
      </p>
      <p>
       The Proto-Romance loss of phonemic length originally produced a system with nine different quality distinctions in monophthongs, where only original
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ă ā/
       </span>
       had merged. Soon, however, many of these vowels coalesced:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The simplest outcome was in
        <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
         Sardinian
        </a>
        ,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
         <a href="#cite_note-58">
          [58]
         </a>
        </sup>
        where the former long and short vowels in Latin simply coalesced, e.g.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ĕ ē/
        </span>
        &gt;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e/
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ĭ ī/
        </span>
        &gt;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /i/
        </span>
        : This produced a simple five-vowel system
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e i o u/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        In most areas, however (technically, the
        <a href="/wiki/Italo-Western_languages" title="Italo-Western languages">
         Italo-Western languages
        </a>
        ), the near-close vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɪ ʊ/
        </span>
        lowered and merged into the high-mid vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e o/
        </span>
        . As a result, Latin
        <i>
         pira
        </i>
        "pear" and
        <i>
         vēra
        </i>
        "true", came to rhyme (e.g. Italian and Spanish
        <i>
         pera, vera
        </i>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
         Old French
        </a>
        <i>
         poire, voire
        </i>
        ). Similarly, Latin
        <i>
         nucem
        </i>
        (from
        <i>
         nux
        </i>
        "nut") and
        <i>
         vōcem
        </i>
        (from
        <i>
         vōx
        </i>
        "voice") become Italian
        <i>
         noce, voce
        </i>
        , Portuguese
        <i>
         noz, voz
        </i>
        , and French
        <i>
         noix, voix
        </i>
        . This produced a seven-vowel system
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a ɛ e i ɔ o u/
        </span>
        , still maintained in conservative languages such as Italian and Portuguese, and lightly transformed in Spanish (where
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ/ &gt; /je/, /ɔ/ &gt; /we/
        </span>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        In the
        <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Romance_languages" title="Eastern Romance languages">
         Eastern Romance languages
        </a>
        (particularly,
        <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
         Romanian
        </a>
        ), the front vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ĕ ē ĭ ī/
        </span>
        evolved as in the majority of languages, but the back vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ŏ ō ŭ ū/
        </span>
        evolved as in Sardinian. This produced an unbalanced six-vowel system:
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a ɛ e i o u/
        </span>
        . In modern Romanian, this system has been significantly transformed, with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ/ &gt; /je/
        </span>
        and with new vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ə ɨ/
        </span>
        evolving, leading to a balanced seven-vowel system with central as well as front and back vowels:
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e i ə ɨ o u/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Sicilian_language" title="Sicilian language">
         Sicilian
        </a>
        is sometimes described as having its own distinct vowel system. In fact, Sicilian passed through the same developments as the main bulk of Italo-Western languages. Subsequently, however, high-mid vowels (but not low-mid vowels) were raised in all syllables, stressed and unstressed; i.e.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e o/ &gt; /i u/
        </span>
        . The result is a five-vowel
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a ɛ i ɔ u/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       The Proto-Romance allophonic vowel-length system was rephonemicized in the
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
        Gallo-Romance languages
       </a>
       as a result of the loss of many final vowels. Some northern Italian languages (e.g.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Friulan_language" title="Friulan language">
        Friulan
       </a>
       ) still maintain this secondary phonemic length, but most languages dropped it by either diphthongizing or shortening the new long vowels.
      </p>
      <p>
       French phonemicized a third vowel length system around AD 1300 as a result of the sound change /VsC/ &gt; /VhC/ &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /VːC/
       </span>
       (where
       <i>
        V
       </i>
       is any vowel and
       <i>
        C
       </i>
       any consonant). This vowel length was eventually lost by around AD 1700, but the former long vowels are still marked with a circumflex. A fourth vowel length system, still non-phonemic, has now arisen: All nasal vowels as well as the oral vowels
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɑ o ø/
       </span>
       (which mostly derive from former long vowels) are pronounced long in all stressed
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Closed_syllable" title="Closed syllable">
        closed syllables
       </a>
       , and all vowels are pronounced long in syllables closed by the voiced fricatives
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /v z ʒ ʁ vʁ/
       </span>
       . This system in turn has been phonemicized in some non-standard dialects (e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/Haitian_Creole" title="Haitian Creole">
        Haitian Creole
       </a>
       ), as a result of the loss of final
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʁ/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Latin_diphthongs">
        Latin diphthongs
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Latin diphthongs">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Latin diphthongs
       <i>
        ae
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        oe
       </i>
       , pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ai/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /oi/
       </span>
       in earlier Latin, were early on monophthongized.
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        ae
       </i>
       became
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛː/
       </span>
       by the 1st century
       <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
        a.d.
       </span>
       at the latest. Although this sound was still distinct from all existing vowels, the neutralization of Latin vowel length eventually caused its merger with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ/
       </span>
       &lt; short
       <i>
        e
       </i>
       : e.g.
       <i>
        caelum
       </i>
       "sky" &gt; French
       <i>
        ciel
       </i>
       , Spanish/Italian
       <i>
        cielo
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        céu
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /sɛw/
       </span>
       , with the same vowel as in
       <i>
        mele
       </i>
       "honey" &gt; French/Spanish
       <i>
        miel
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        miele
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        mel
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mɛl/
       </span>
       . Some words show an early merger of
       <i>
        ae
       </i>
       with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /eː/
       </span>
       , as in
       <i>
        praeda
       </i>
       "booty" &gt; *
       <i>
        prēda
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /preːda/
       </span>
       &gt; French
       <i>
        proie
       </i>
       (vs. expected **
       <i>
        priée
       </i>
       ), Italian
       <i>
        preda
       </i>
       (not **
       <i>
        prieda
       </i>
       ) "prey"; or
       <i>
        faenum
       </i>
       "hay" &gt; *
       <i>
        fēnum
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [feːnũ]
       </span>
       &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        heno
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        foin
       </i>
       (but Italian
       <i>
        fieno
       </i>
       /fjɛno/).
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        oe
       </i>
       generally merged with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /eː/
       </span>
       :
       <i>
        poenam
       </i>
       "punishment" &gt; Romance *
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /pena/
       </span>
       &gt; Spanish/Italian
       <i>
        pena
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        peine
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        foedus
       </i>
       "ugly" &gt; Romance *
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fedo/
       </span>
       &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        feo
       </i>
       , Portuguese
       <i>
        feio
       </i>
       . There are relatively few such outcomes, since
       <i>
        oe
       </i>
       was rare in Classical Latin (most original instances had become Classical
       <i>
        ū
       </i>
       , as in Old Latin
       <i>
        oinos
       </i>
       "one" &gt; Classical
       <i>
        ūnus
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Palmer_59-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Palmer-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ) and so
       <i>
        oe
       </i>
       was mostly limited to Greek loanwords, which were typically learned (high-register) terms.
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        au
       </i>
       merged with
       <i>
        ō
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /oː/
       </span>
       in the popular speech of Rome already by the 1st century
       <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
        b.c
       </span>
       . A number of authors remarked on this explicitly, e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/Cicero" title="Cicero">
        Cicero
       </a>
       's taunt that the populist politician
       <a href="/wiki/Publius_Clodius_Pulcher" title="Publius Clodius Pulcher">
        Publius Clodius Pulcher
       </a>
       had changed his name from
       <i>
        Claudius
       </i>
       to ingratiate himself with the masses. This change never penetrated far from Rome, however, and the pronunciation /au/ was maintained for centuries in the vast majority of Latin-speaking areas, although it eventually developed into some variety of
       <i>
        o
       </i>
       in many languages. For example, Italian and French have
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɔ/
       </span>
       as the usual reflex, but this post-dates diphthongization of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɔ/
       </span>
       and the French-specific palatalization
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ka/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃa/
       </span>
       (hence
       <i>
        causa
       </i>
       &gt; French
       <i>
        chose
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        cosa
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /kɔza/
       </span>
       not **
       <i>
        cuosa
       </i>
       ). Spanish has
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       , but Portuguese spelling maintains ⟨ou⟩, which has developed to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       (and still remains as
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ou/
       </span>
       in some dialects, and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /oi/
       </span>
       in others). Occitan, Romanian, southern Italian languages, and many other minority Romance languages still have
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /au/
       </span>
       . A few common words, however, show an early merger with
       <i>
        ō
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /oː/
       </span>
       , evidently reflecting a generalization of the popular Roman pronunciation: e.g. French
       <i>
        queue
       </i>
       , Italian
       <i>
        coda
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /koda/
       </span>
       , Occitan
       <i>
        co(d)a
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        coadă
       </i>
       (all meaning "tail") must all derive from
       <i>
        cōda
       </i>
       rather than Classical
       <i>
        cauda
       </i>
       (but notice Portuguese
       <i>
        cauda
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Similarly, Portuguese
       <i>
        orelha
       </i>
       , French
       <i>
        oreille
       </i>
       , Romanian
       <i>
        ureche
       </i>
       , and Sardinian
       <i>
        olícra
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        orícla
       </i>
       "ear" must derive from
       <i>
        ōric(u)la
       </i>
       rather than Classical
       <i>
        auris
       </i>
       (Occitan
       <i>
        aurelha
       </i>
       was probably influenced by the unrelated
       <i>
        ausir
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        audīre
       </i>
       "to hear"), and the form
       <i>
        oricla
       </i>
       is in fact reflected in the
       <a href="/wiki/Appendix_Probi" title="Appendix Probi">
        Appendix Probi
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_developments">
        Further developments
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Further developments">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Metaphony">
        Metaphony
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Metaphony">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Metaphony_(Romance_languages)" title="Metaphony (Romance languages)">
        Metaphony (Romance languages)
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       An early process that operated in all Romance languages to varying degrees was
       <a href="/wiki/Metaphony" title="Metaphony">
        metaphony
       </a>
       (vowel mutation), conceptually similar to the
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_umlaut" title="Germanic umlaut">
        umlaut
       </a>
       process so characteristic of the
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic languages
       </a>
       . Depending on the language, certain stressed vowels were raised (or sometimes diphthongized) either by a final /i/ or /u/ or by a directly following /j/. Metaphony is most extensive in the Italo-Romance languages, and applies to nearly all languages in Italy; however, it is absent from Tuscan, and hence from standard Italian. In many languages affected by metaphony, a distinction exists between final /u/ (from most cases of Latin
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       ) and final /o/ (from Latin
       <i>
        -ō
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -ud
       </i>
       and some cases of
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       , esp. masculine "mass" nouns), and only the former triggers metaphony.
      </p>
      <p>
       Some examples:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        In
        <a href="/wiki/Servigliano" title="Servigliano">
         Servigliano
        </a>
        in the
        <a href="/wiki/Marche" title="Marche">
         Marche
        </a>
        of Italy, stressed
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ e ɔ o/
        </span>
        are raised to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e i o u/
        </span>
        before final /i/ or /u/:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kaze1991_61-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-kaze1991-61">
          [61]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈmetto/
        </span>
        "I put" vs.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈmitti/
        </span>
        "you put" (&lt; *metti &lt; *mettes &lt; Latin
        <i>
         mittis
        </i>
        );
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /moˈdɛsta/
        </span>
        "modest (fem.)" vs.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /moˈdestu/
        </span>
        "modest (masc.)";
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈkwesto/
        </span>
        "this (neut.)" (&lt; Latin
        <i>
         eccum istud
        </i>
        ) vs.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈkwistu/
        </span>
        "this (masc.)" (&lt; Latin
        <i>
         eccum istum
        </i>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        Calvallo in
        <a href="/wiki/Basilicata" title="Basilicata">
         Basilicata
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">
         southern Italy
        </a>
        , is similar, but the low-mid vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ ɔ/
        </span>
        are diphthongized to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /je wo/
        </span>
        rather than raised:
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
         <a href="#cite_note-62">
          [62]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈmette/
        </span>
        "he puts" vs.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈmitti/
        </span>
        "you put", but
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈpɛnʒo/
        </span>
        "I think" vs.
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈpjenʒi/
        </span>
        "you think".
       </li>
       <li>
        Metaphony also occurs in most northern Italian dialects, but only by (usually lost) final *i; apparently, final *u was lowered to *o (usually lost) before metaphony could take effect.
       </li>
       <li>
        Some of the
        <a href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese_languages" title="Astur-Leonese languages">
         Astur-Leonese languages
        </a>
        in northern Spain have the same distinction between final /o/ and /u/
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
         <a href="#cite_note-63">
          [63]
         </a>
        </sup>
        as in the Central-Southern Italian languages,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-penny1994_64-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-penny1994-64">
          [64]
         </a>
        </sup>
        with /u/ triggering metaphony.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AAC_65-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-AAC-65">
          [65]
         </a>
        </sup>
        The plural of masculine nouns in these dialects ends in
        <i>
         -os
        </i>
        , which does not trigger metaphony, unlike in the singular (vs. Italian plural
        <i>
         -i
        </i>
        , which does trigger metaphony).
       </li>
       <li>
        Sardinian has allophonic raising of mid vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ ɔ/
        </span>
        to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [e o]
        </span>
        before final /i/ or /u/. This has been phonemicized in the
        <a href="/wiki/Campidanese_dialect" title="Campidanese dialect">
         Campidanese dialect
        </a>
        as a result of the raising of final /e o/ to /i u/.
       </li>
       <li>
        Raising of
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɔ/
        </span>
        to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /o/
        </span>
        occurs sporadically in Portuguese in the masculine singular, e.g.
        <i>
         porco
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈporku/
        </span>
        "pig" vs.
        <i>
         porcos
        </i>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ˈpɔrkus/
        </span>
        "pig". It is thought that Galician-Portuguese at one point had singular /u/ vs. plural /os/, exactly as in modern Astur-Leonese.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-penny1994_64-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-penny1994-64">
          [64]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        In all of the Western Romance languages, final /i/ (primarily occurring in the first-person singular of the
        <a href="/wiki/Preterite" title="Preterite">
         preterite
        </a>
        ) raised mid-high
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e o/
        </span>
        to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /i u/
        </span>
        , e.g. Portuguese
        <i>
         fiz
        </i>
        "I did" (&lt; *fidzi &lt; *fedzi &lt; Latin
        <i>
         fēcī
        </i>
        ) vs.
        <i>
         fez
        </i>
        "he did" (&lt; *fedze &lt; Latin
        <i>
         fēcit
        </i>
        ). Old Spanish similarly had
        <i>
         fize
        </i>
        "I did" vs.
        <i>
         fezo
        </i>
        "he did" (
        <i>
         -o
        </i>
        by analogy with
        <i>
         amó
        </i>
        "he loved"), but subsequently generalized stressed /i/, producing modern
        <i>
         hice
        </i>
        "I did" vs.
        <i>
         hizo
        </i>
        "he did". The same thing happened prehistorically in Old French, yielding
        <i>
         fis
        </i>
        "I did",
        <i>
         fist
        </i>
        "he did" (&lt; *feist &lt; Latin
        <i>
         fēcit
        </i>
        ).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Diphthongization">
        Diphthongization
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Diphthongization">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       A number of languages
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diphthongization" title="Diphthongization">
        diphthongized
       </a>
       some of the free vowels, especially the open-mid vowels
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ ɔ/
       </span>
       :
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Spanish consistently diphthongized all open-mid vowels
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ ɔ/ &gt; /je we/
        </span>
        except for before certain palatal consonants (which raised the vowels to close-mid before diphthongization took place).
       </li>
       <li>
        Romanian similarly diphthongized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ/
        </span>
        to
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /je/
        </span>
        (the corresponding vowel
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɔ/
        </span>
        did not develop from Proto-Romance).
       </li>
       <li>
        Italian diphthongized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ/ &gt; /jɛ/
        </span>
        and
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɔ/ &gt; /wɔ/
        </span>
        in open syllables (in the situations where vowels were lengthened in Proto-Romance), the most salient exception being /ˈbɛne/
        <i>
         bene
        </i>
        'well', perhaps due to the high frequency of
        <a href="/wiki/Apocope" title="Apocope">
         apocopated
        </a>
        <i>
         ben
        </i>
        (e.g.
        <i>
         ben difficile
        </i>
        'quite difficult',
        <i>
         ben fatto
        </i>
        'well made',
        <i>
         ben due
        </i>
        'a good two', etc.).
       </li>
       <li>
        French similarly diphthongized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ ɔ/
        </span>
        in open syllables (when lengthened), along with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /a e o/
        </span>
        :
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /aː ɛː eː ɔː oː/
        </span>
        &gt;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /aɛ iɛ ei uɔ ou/
        </span>
        &gt; middle OF
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e je ɔi we eu/
        </span>
        &gt; modern
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /e je wa œ ~ ø œ ~ ø/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        French also diphthongized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ ɔ/
        </span>
        before palatalized consonants, especially /j/. Further development was as follows:
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛj/ &gt; /iej/ &gt; /i/
        </span>
        ;
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɔj/
        </span>
        &gt; /uoj/ &gt; early OF /uj/ &gt; modern /ɥi/.
       </li>
       <li>
        Catalan diphthongized
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛ ɔ/
        </span>
        before /j/ from palatalized consonants, just like French, with similar results:
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɛj/ &gt; /i/
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ɔj/ &gt; /uj/
        </span>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       These diphthongizations had the effect of reducing or eliminating the distinctions between open-mid and close-mid vowels in many languages. In Spanish and Romanian, all open-mid vowels were diphthongized, and the distinction disappeared entirely. Portuguese is the most conservative in this respect, keeping the seven-vowel system more or less unchanged (but with changes in particular circumstances, e.g. due to
       <a href="#Metaphony">
        metaphony
       </a>
       ). Other than before palatalized consonants, Catalan keeps
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɔ o/
       </span>
       intact, but
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ e/
       </span>
       split in a complex fashion into
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ e ə/
       </span>
       and then coalesced again in the standard dialect (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Catalan" title="Eastern Catalan">
        Eastern Catalan
       </a>
       ) in such a way that most original
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ e/
       </span>
       have reversed their quality to become
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e ɛ/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In French and Italian, the distinction between open-mid and close-mid vowels occurred only in closed syllables. Standard Italian more or less maintains this. In French, /e/ and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ/
       </span>
       merged by the twelfth century or so, and the distinction between
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɔ/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       was eliminated without merging by the sound changes
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/ &gt; /y/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/ &gt; /u/
       </span>
       . Generally this led to a situation where both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [e,o]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [ɛ,ɔ]
       </span>
       occur allophonically, with the close-mid vowels in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_syllable" title="Open syllable">
        open syllables
       </a>
       and the open-mid vowels in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Closed_syllable" title="Closed syllable">
        closed syllables
       </a>
       . This is still the situation in modern Spanish, for example.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In French, however, both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [e/ɛ]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [o/ɔ]
       </span>
       were partly rephonemicized: Both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ/
       </span>
       occur in open syllables as a result of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /aj/ &gt; /ɛ/
       </span>
       , and both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɔ/
       </span>
       occur in closed syllables as a result of
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /al/ &gt; /au/ &gt; /o/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Old French also had numerous falling diphthongs resulting from diphthongization before palatal consonants or from a fronted /j/ originally following palatal consonants in Proto-Romance or later: e.g.
       <i>
        pācem
       </i>
       /patsʲe/ "peace" &gt; PWR */padzʲe/ (lenition) &gt; OF
       <i>
        paiz
       </i>
       /pajts/; *
       <i>
        punctum
       </i>
       "point" &gt; Gallo-Romance */ponʲto/ &gt; */pojɲto/ (fronting) &gt; OF
       <i>
        point
       </i>
       /põjnt/. During the Old French period, preconsonantal /l/ [ɫ] vocalized to /w/, producing many new falling diphthongs: e.g.
       <i>
        dulcem
       </i>
       "sweet" &gt; PWR */doltsʲe/ &gt; OF
       <i>
        dolz
       </i>
       /duɫts/ &gt;
       <i>
        douz
       </i>
       /duts/;
       <i>
        fallet
       </i>
       "fails, is deficient" &gt; OF
       <i>
        falt
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        faut
       </i>
       "is needed";
       <i>
        bellus
       </i>
       "beautiful" &gt; OF
       <i>
        bels
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [bɛɫs]
       </span>
       &gt;
       <i>
        beaus
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [bɛaws]
       </span>
       . By the end of the Middle French period,
       <i>
        all
       </i>
       falling diphthongs either monophthongized or switched to rising diphthongs: proto-OF
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /aj ɛj jɛj ej jej wɔj oj uj al ɛl el il ɔl ol ul/
       </span>
       &gt; early OF
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /aj ɛj i ej yj oj yj aw ɛaw ew i ɔw ow y/
       </span>
       &gt; modern spelling ⟨ai ei i oi ui oi ui au eau eu i ou ou u⟩ &gt; mod. French
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ ɛ i wa ɥi wa ɥi o o ø i u u y/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Nasalization">
        Nasalization
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Nasalization">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       In both French and Portuguese,
       <a href="/wiki/Nasal_vowel" title="Nasal vowel">
        nasal vowels
       </a>
       eventually developed from sequences of a vowel followed by a nasal consonant (/m/ or /n/). Originally, all vowels in both languages were nasalized before any nasal consonants, and nasal consonants not immediately followed by a vowel were eventually dropped. In French, nasal vowels before remaining nasal consonants were subsequently denasalized, but not before causing the vowels to lower somewhat, e.g.
       <i>
        dōnat
       </i>
       "he gives" &gt; OF
       <i>
        dune
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /dunə/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <i>
        donne
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /dɔn/
       </span>
       ,
       <i>
        fēminam
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        femme
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fam/
       </span>
       . Other vowels remained diphthongized, and were dramatically lowered:
       <i>
        fīnem
       </i>
       "end" &gt;
       <i>
        fin
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fɛ̃/
       </span>
       (often pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [fæ̃]
       </span>
       );
       <i>
        linguam
       </i>
       "tongue" &gt;
       <i>
        langue
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /lɑ̃ɡ/
       </span>
       ;
       <i>
        ūnum
       </i>
       "one" &gt;
       <i>
        un
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /œ̃/, /ɛ̃/
       </span>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In Portuguese, /n/ between vowels was dropped, and the resulting
       <a href="/wiki/Hiatus_(linguistics)" title="Hiatus (linguistics)">
        hiatus
       </a>
       eliminated through vowel contraction of various sorts, often producing diphthongs:
       <i>
        manum, *manōs
       </i>
       &gt; PWR *
       <i>
        manu, ˈmanos
       </i>
       "hand(s)" &gt;
       <i>
        mão, mãos
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /mɐ̃w̃, mɐ̃w̃s/
       </span>
       ;
       <i>
        canem, canēs
       </i>
       "dog(s)" &gt; PWR *
       <i>
        kane, ˈkanes
       </i>
       &gt; *
       <i>
        can, ˈcanes
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        cão, cães
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /kɐ̃w̃, kɐ̃j̃s/
       </span>
       ;
       <i>
        ratiōnem, ratiōnēs
       </i>
       "reason(s)" &gt; PWR *
       <i>
        raˈdʲzʲone, raˈdʲzʲones
       </i>
       &gt; *
       <i>
        raˈdzon, raˈdzones
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        razão, razões
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /χaˈzɐ̃w̃, χaˈzõj̃s/
       </span>
       (Brazil),
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʁaˈzɐ̃ũ, ʁɐˈzõj̃ʃ/
       </span>
       (Portugal). Sometimes the nasalization was eliminated:
       <i>
        lūna
       </i>
       "moon" &gt; Galician-Portuguese
       <i>
        lũa
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        lua
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        vēna
       </i>
       "vein" &gt; Galician-Portuguese
       <i>
        vẽa
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        veia
       </i>
       . Nasal vowels that remained actually tend to be raised (rather than lowered, as in French):
       <i>
        fīnem
       </i>
       "end" &gt;
       <i>
        fim
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /fĩ/
       </span>
       ;
       <i>
        centum
       </i>
       "hundred" &gt; PWR
       <i>
        tʲsʲɛnto
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        cento
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈsẽtu/
       </span>
       ;
       <i>
        pontem
       </i>
       "bridge" &gt; PWR
       <i>
        pɔnte
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        ponte
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈpõtʃi/
       </span>
       (Brazil),
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈpõtɨ/
       </span>
       (Portugal). In Portugal, vowels before a nasal consonant have become denasalized, but in Brazil they remain heavily nasalized.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Front-rounded_vowels">
        Front-rounded vowels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Front-rounded vowels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Characteristic of the
       <a href="/wiki/Gallo-Romance_languages" title="Gallo-Romance languages">
        Gallo-Romance languages
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance_languages" title="Rhaeto-Romance languages">
        Rhaeto-Romance languages
       </a>
       are the
       <a href="/wiki/Front_rounded_vowel" title="Front rounded vowel">
        front rounded vowels
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /y ø œ/
       </span>
       . All of these languages show an unconditional change /u/ &gt; /y/, e.g.
       <i>
        lūnam
       </i>
       &gt; French
       <i>
        lune
       </i>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /lyn/
       </span>
       , Occitan
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ˈlyno/
       </span>
       . Many of the languages in Switzerland and Italy show the further change /y/ &gt; /i/. Also very common is some variation of the French development
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɔː oː/
       </span>
       (lengthened in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_syllable" title="Open syllable">
        open syllables
       </a>
       ) &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /we ew/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /œ œ/
       </span>
       , with mid back vowels diphthongizing in some circumstances and then re-monophthongizing into mid-front rounded vowels. (French has both
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ø/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /œ/
       </span>
       , with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ø/
       </span>
       developing from
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /œ/
       </span>
       in certain circumstances.)
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Unstressed_vowels">
        Unstressed vowels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Unstressed vowels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table cellspacing="1" class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:1em; text-align:center;">

         </span>
        </td>

         </b>

         </span>

        <td rowspan="3">

          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" rowspan="3">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">

         </span>

         </span>

         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">

         </span>
         (prop)
        </td>
        <td rowspan="8">

         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ə/
         </span>
         (prop)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ē,oe
         </i>
        </th>

         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">

         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">

         </b>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /e/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          i,y
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɪ/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ī,ȳ
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>

         </b>

         </span>

        <td colspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /i/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>

         </i>

          /ɔ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>

          ǫ
         </b>
        </td>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ɔ/
         </span>

        <td rowspan="3">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>

        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>

         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ō,(au)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <b>
          ọ
         </b>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /o/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          u
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /ʊ/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          ū
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <b>
          u
         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /u/
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         <i>
          au
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          (most words)
         </i>
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aw/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td>
         <b>
          au
         </b>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2">
         <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
          /aw/
         </span>
        </td>
        <td colspan="5">
         N/A
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="10">
         <sup>
          1
         </sup>
         Traditional academic transcription in Romance studies.
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       There was more variability in the result of the unstressed vowels. Originally in Proto-Romance, the same nine vowels developed in unstressed as stressed syllables, and in Sardinian, they coalesced into the same five vowels in the same way.
      </p>
      <p>
       In Italo-Western Romance, however, vowels in unstressed syllables were significantly different from stressed vowels, with yet a third outcome for final unstressed syllables. In non-final unstressed syllables, the seven-vowel system of stressed syllables developed, but then the low-mid vowels
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɛ ɔ/
       </span>
       merged into the high-mid vowels
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e o/
       </span>
       . This system is still preserved, largely or completely, in all of the conservative Romance languages (e.g. Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Catalan).
      </p>
      <p>
       In final unstressed syllables, results were somewhat complex. One of the more difficult issues is the development of final short
       <i>
        -u
       </i>
       , which appears to have been raised to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       rather than lowered to
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       , as happened in all other syllables. However, it is possible that in reality, final
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       comes from
       <i>
        long
       </i>
       *
       <i>
        -ū
       </i>
       &lt;
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       , where original final
       <i>
        -m
       </i>
       caused vowel lengthening as well as nasalization. Evidence of this comes from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhaeto-Romance" title="Rhaeto-Romance">
        Rhaeto-Romance
       </a>
       , in particular
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sursilvan" title="Sursilvan">
        Sursilvan
       </a>
       , which preserves reflexes of both final
       <i>
        -us
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       , and where the latter, but not the former, triggers
       <a href="#Metaphony">
        metaphony
       </a>
       . This suggests the development
       <i>
        -us
       </i>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʊs/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /os/
       </span>
       , but
       <i>
        -um
       </i>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ũː/
       </span>
       &gt;
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table cellspacing="1" class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin:1em;">
       <caption>
        Examples of evolution of final unstressed vowels:
        <br/>

        <td>
         peace
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          pācem
         </i>
        </td>

         ˈpatʃe
        </td>
        <td>
         pace
        </td>
        <td>
         pace
        </td>
        <td>
         paz
        </td>
        <td>
         pau
        </td>

         paiz
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         part
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          partem
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         ˈparte
        </td>
        <td>
         parte
        </td>
        <td>
         parte
        </td>
        <td>
         parte
        </td>
        <td>
         part
        </td>
        <td>
         part
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         mother
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          mātrem
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         ˈmatre
        </td>
        <td>
         matre
        </td>
        <td>
         madre
        </td>
        <td>
         madre
        </td>
        <td>
         mare
        </td>
        <td>
         meḍre
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         twenty
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          vīgintī
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         veˈenti
        </td>
        <td>
         vinti
        </td>
        <td>
         venti
        </td>
        <td>
         veinte
        </td>
        <td>
         vint
        </td>
        <td>
         vint
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         four
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          quattuor
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         ˈkwattro
        </td>
        <td>
         quattro
        </td>
        <td>
         quattro
        </td>
        <td>
         cuatro
        </td>
        <td>
         quatre
        </td>
        <td>
         quatre
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         eight
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          octō
         </i>
        </td>
