       <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_minuscule" title="Carolingian minuscule">
        Carolingian writing
       </a>
       and Medieval
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quill_pen" title="Quill pen">
        quill pen
       </a>
       handwriting which were later adapted by printers in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.
      </p>
      <p>
       In particular, all Romance languages capitalize (use uppercase for the first letter of) the following words: the first word of each complete
       <a href="/wiki/Sentence_(linguistics)" title="Sentence (linguistics)">
        sentence
       </a>
       , most words in names of people, places, and organizations, and most words in titles of books. The Romance languages do not follow the German practice of capitalizing all nouns including common ones. Unlike English, the names of months, days of the weeks, and derivatives of proper nouns are usually not capitalized: thus, in Italian one capitalizes
       <i>
        Francia
       </i>
       ("France") and
       <i>
        Francesco
       </i>
       ("Francis"), but not
       <i>
        francese
       </i>
       ("French") or
       <i>
        francescano
       </i>
       ("Franciscan"). However, each language has some exceptions to this general rule.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Vocabulary_comparison">
        Vocabulary comparison
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=61" title="Edit section: Vocabulary comparison">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The tables below provide a vocabulary comparison that illustrates a number of examples of sound shifts that have occurred between Latin and Romance languages, along with a selection of minority languages. Words are given in their conventional spellings. In addition, for French the actual pronunciation is given, due to the dramatic differences between spelling and pronunciation. (French spelling approximately reflects the pronunciation of
       <a href="/wiki/Old_French" title="Old French">
        Old French
       </a>
       , c. 1200 AD.)
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="font-size: 85%">
       <tr>

        </td>

        </td>

       <tr>
        <td>
         rain
        </td>

         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         próida
        </td>
        <td>
         ploaie
        </td>
        <td>
         chiuvuta
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
          <a href="#cite_note-81">
           [81]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
        <td>
         pioggia
        </td>
        <td>
         pioggia
        </td>
        <td>
         pióva
        </td>
        <td>
         pioeuva
        </td>
        <td>
         piöa
        </td>
        <td>
         pieuva
        </td>
        <td>

           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Vulgar+Latin&amp;rft.pub=Penn+State+Press&amp;rft.date=2010-11-01&amp;rft.isbn=0-271-04177-3&amp;rft.aulast=Herman&amp;rft.aufirst=Jozsef&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DRJco4ioXigYC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          , pp. 108–115
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-price-13">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-price_13-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-price_13-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-price_13-2">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              c
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-price_13-3">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              d
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-price_13-4">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              e
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Price, Glanville (1984).
           <i>
            The French language: past and present
           </i>
           . London: Grant and Cutler Ltd.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+French+language%3A+past+and+present&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=Grant+and+Cutler+Ltd&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.aulast=Price&amp;rft.aufirst=Glanville&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-14">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-14">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          "Na" is a
          <a href="/wiki/Contraction_(grammar)" title="Contraction (grammar)">
           contraction
          </a>
          of "em" (in) + "a" (the), the form "em a" is never used, it is always replaced by "na". The same happens with other prepositions: "de" (of) + o/a/os/as (singular and plural forms for "the" in masculine and feminine) = do, da, dos, das; etc.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-15">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-15">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Verb; literally means "to put in mouth"
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-16">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-16">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          See
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_in_Africa" title="Portuguese in Africa">
           Portuguese in Africa
          </a>
          .
         </span>
        </li>

            ^

          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

            "Romance languages"
           </a>
           .

            Encyclopædia Britannica
           </i>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             2 December
            </span>
            2014
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Romance+languages&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F508379%2FRomance-languages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-24">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-24">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <i>
           Sardos etiam, qui non Latii sunt sed Latiis associandi videntur, eiciamus, quoniam soli sine proprio vulgari esse videntur, gramaticam tanquam simie homines imitantes: nam domus nova et dominus meus locuntur.
          </i>
          ["As for the Sardinians, who are not Italian but may be associated with Italians for our purposes, out they must go, because they alone seem to lack a vernacular of their own, instead imitating
          <i>
           gramatica
          </i>
          as apes do humans: for they say
          <i>
           domus nova
          </i>
          [my house] and
          <i>
           dominus meus
          </i>
          [my master]." (
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.danteonline.it/english/opere2.asp?idcod=000&amp;idope=3&amp;idliv1=1&amp;idliv2=11&amp;idliv3=1&amp;idlang=UK" rel="nofollow">
           English translation provided by Dante Online, De Vulgari Eloquentia, I-xi
          </a>
          )] It is unclear whether this
          <abbr title="indicative mood">
           indic.
          </abbr>
          tes that Sardinian still had a two-case system at the time; modern Sardinian lacks grammatical case.
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-29">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

           Henrik Theiling (2007-10-28).
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.kunstsprachen.de/s17/s_02.html" rel="nofollow">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%C3%9Erj%C3%B3trunn%3A+A+North+Romance+Language%3A+History&amp;rft.pub=Kunstsprachen.de&amp;rft.date=2007-10-28&amp;rft.au=Henrik+Theiling&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.kunstsprachen.de%2Fs17%2Fs_02.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">

        <li id="cite_note-30">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-30">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://steen.free.fr/relay10/jelbazech.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Relay 10/R – Jelbazech"
           </a>
           . Steen.free.fr. 2004-08-28
           <span class="reference-accessdate">

            </span>
           </span>

          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Relay+10%2FR+%E2%80%93+Jelbazech&amp;rft.pub=Steen.free.fr&amp;rft.date=2004-08-28&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsteen.free.fr%2Frelay10%2Fjelbazech.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-:1-31">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-:1_31-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-:1_31-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Cordin, Patrizia (2011). "From verbal prefixes to direction/result markers in Romance".
           <i>
            Linguistica
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            51
           </b>
           (1).
           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.4312%2Flinguistica.51.1.201-216" rel="nofollow">
            10.4312/linguistica.51.1.201-216
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Linguistica&amp;rft.atitle=From+verbal+prefixes+to+direction%2Fresult+markers+in+Romance&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.4312%2Flinguistica.51.1.201-216&amp;rft.aulast=Cordin&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrizia&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-32">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-32">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /ə/
          </span>
          can occur only in unstressed syllables, and it tends to be rounded
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           [ɵ̞]
          </span>
          ; it is replaced by
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           [ø]
          </span>
          when stressed.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-33">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-33">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /ɐ/
          </span>
          developed as the allophone of
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /a/
          </span>
          before nasals and under low stress, and the two are still nearly in complementary distribution. A few minimal pairs like
          <i>
           falamos
          </i>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /fɐˈlɐmuʃ/
          </span>
          "we speak" vs.
          <i>
           falámos
          </i>
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /fɐˈlamuʃ/
          </span>
          "we spoke" seem to clearly indicate that
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /ɐ/
          </span>
          must be a phoneme, but other analyses are possible.
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /ɨ/
          </span>
          , which developed from earlier
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /e/
          </span>
          in unstressed syllables, is even more doubtful.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-34">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-34">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Haase, Martin. 2000. "Reorganization of a gender system: The Central Italian neuters". in
          <i>
           Gender in Grammar and Cognition
          </i>
          , ed. by Barbara Unterbeck et al., pp. 221–236. Berlin: Mouton De Gruyter
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-harris-vincent-35">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-2">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              c
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-harris-vincent_35-3">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              d
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Harris, Martin; Vincent, Nigel (1988).
           <i>
            The Romance Languages
           </i>
           . London: Routledge.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Romance+Languages&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=1988&amp;rft.aulast=Harris&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.au=Vincent%2C+Nigel&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-kibler-36">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-kibler_36-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Kibler, William W. (1984).
           <i>
            An introduction to Old French
           </i>
           . New York: Modern Language Association of America.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+introduction+to+Old+French&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Modern+Language+Association+of+America&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.aulast=Kibler&amp;rft.aufirst=William+W.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">

         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-37">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-37">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a href="/wiki/Henri_Wittmann" title="Henri Wittmann">
           Henri Wittmann
          </a>
          .
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.nou-la.org/ling/1998a-fpparis.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "
            <span style="padding-left:0.2em;">
             "
            </span>
            Le français de Paris dans le français des Amériques.
            <span style="padding-right:0.2em;">
             "
            </span>
            "
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%22Le+fran%C3%A7ais+de+Paris+dans+le+fran%C3%A7ais+des+Am%C3%A9riques.%22&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nou-la.org%2Fling%2F1998a-fpparis.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          <small>
           (52.1 KB)
          </small>
          ,
          <i>
           Proceedings of the International Congress of Linguists
          </i>
          16.0416 (Paris, 20–25 juillet 1997). Oxford: Pergamon (CD edition).
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-38">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-38">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Nanbakhsh, Golnaz (2012).
           <a class="external text" href="https://revije.ff.uni-lj.si/linguistica/article/view/123/496" rel="nofollow">
            "Moving beyond T/V pronouns of power and solidarity in interaction : Persian agreement mismatch construction"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Linguistica
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            52
           </b>
           (1).
           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.4312%2Flinguistica.52.1.253-266" rel="nofollow">
            10.4312/linguistica.52.1.253-266
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Linguistica&amp;rft.atitle=Moving+beyond+T%2FV+pronouns+of+power+and+solidarity+in+interaction+%3A+Persian+agreement+mismatch+construction&amp;rft.volume=52&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.4312%2Flinguistica.52.1.253-266&amp;rft.aulast=Nanbakhsh&amp;rft.aufirst=Golnaz&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Frevije.ff.uni-lj.si%2Flinguistica%2Farticle%2Fview%2F123%2F496&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-39">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-39">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <i>
           ipse
          </i>
          originally meant "self", as in
          <i>
           ego
          </i>
          <i>
           ipse
          </i>
          or
          <i>
           egomet
          </i>
          <i>
           ipse
          </i>
          "I myself".
          <i>
           ipse
          </i>
          later shifted to mean "the" (still reflected in Sardinian and in the Catalan spoken in the
          <a href="/wiki/Balearic_Islands" title="Balearic Islands">
           Balearic Islands
          </a>
          ), and still later came to be a demonstrative pronoun. From
          <i>
           -met
          </i>
          <i>
           ipse
          </i>
          the emphatic (
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superlative" title="Superlative">
           superlative
          </a>
          ) form
          <i>
           metipsimum
          </i>
          was created, later evolving into
          <i>
           medisimum
          </i>
          and eventually Spanish
          <i>
           mismo
          </i>
          , French
          <i>
           même
          </i>
          , Italian
          <i>
           medesimo
          </i>
          , which replaced both Latin
          <i>
           ipse
          </i>
          "self" and
          <i>
           idem
          </i>
          "same". The alternative form
          <i>
           metipse
          </i>
          eventually produced Catalan
          <i>
           mateix
          </i>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Galician-Portuguese" title="Galician-Portuguese">
           Galician-Portuguese
          </a>
          <i>
           medês
          </i>
          . The more frequent Italian equivalent, however, is
          <i>
           stesso
          </i>
          , derived from the combination
          <i>
           istum
          </i>
          -
          <i>
           ipsum
          </i>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-accademiadellacrusca.it-40">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-accademiadellacrusca.it_40-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-accademiadellacrusca.it_40-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/faq/faq_risp.php?id=4697&amp;ctg_id=93" rel="nofollow">
           Accademia della Crusca
           <i>
            On the use of the passato remoto
           </i>
           (in Italian)
          </a>
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060607220030/http://www.accademiadellacrusca.it/faq/faq_risp.php?id=4697&amp;ctg_id=93" rel="nofollow">
           Archived
          </a>
          June 7, 2006, at the
          <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
           Wayback Machine
          </a>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-41">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-41">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Used sometimes a past conditional; also used in an apodosis (then-clause) when the protasis (if-clause) is in the imperfect subjunctive. Frede Jensen,
          <i>
           Syntaxe de l'ancien occitan
          </i>
          (Tübingen: Niemeyer, 1994), 244–5; Povl Skårup,
          <i>
           Morphologie synchronique de l'ancien français
          </i>
          (Copenhagen: Stougaard Jensen, 1994), 121–2.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-42">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-42">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Cf.
          <i>
           auret
          </i>
          "she had" &lt; Latin
          <i>
           habuerat
          </i>
          ,
          <i>
           voldrent
          </i>
          "they wanted" &lt; Latin
          <i>
           voluerant
          </i>
          . Not clearly distinct in meaning from the first (normal) preterite, cf. the parallel lines
          <i>
           por o fut presentede
          </i>
          "for this reason she was presented" (
          <i>
           fut
          </i>
          = first preterite, from Latin
          <i>
           fuit
          </i>
          ) vs.
          <i>
           por o's furet morte
          </i>
          "for these reasons she was killed" (
          <i>
           furet
          </i>
          = second preterite, from Latin
          <i>
           fuerat
          </i>
          ) in the same poem.
         </span>
        </li>

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          </a>

          </a>
          . (NEED PAGE NUMBER)
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-51">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-51">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Harper, Douglas.
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.etymonline.com/?term=-ist" rel="nofollow">
            "-ist"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Online_Etymology_Dictionary" title="Online Etymology Dictionary">
             Online Etymology Dictionary
            </a>
           </i>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Online+Etymology+Dictionary&amp;rft.atitle=-ist&amp;rft.au=Harper%2C+Douglas&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.etymonline.com%2F%3Fterm%3D-ist&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-52">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-52">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Wolf Dietrich, "Griechisch und Romanisch",
          <i>
           Lexikon der romanistischen Linguistik
          </i>
          , vol 7:
          <i>
           Kontakt, Migration und Kunstsprachen: Kontrastivität, Klassifikation und Typologie
          </i>
          , eds. Günter Holtus, Michael Metzeltin &amp; Christian Schmitt (Tübingen: Max Niemeyer, 1998), 121–34:123–4.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-53">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-53">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Originally formal, now equalizing or informal.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-54">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-54">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Likewise Spanish
          <i>
           usted
          </i>
          &lt;
          <i>
           vuestra merced
          </i>
          , Catalan
          <i>
           vostè
          </i>
          &lt;
          <i>
           vostra mercè
          </i>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-55">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-55">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Note that the current Portuguese spelling (
          <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Language_Orthographic_Agreement_of_1990" title="Portuguese Language Orthographic Agreement of 1990">
           Portuguese Language Orthographic Agreement of 1990
          </a>
          ) abolished the use of the diaeresis for this purpose.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-56">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-56">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Pope (1934).
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-57">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-57">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Allen (2003) states: "There appears to have been no great difference in quality between long and short
          <i>
           a
          </i>
          , but in the case of the close and mid vowels (
          <i>
           i
          </i>
          and
          <i>
           u
          </i>
          ,
          <i>
           e
          </i>
          and
          <i>
           o
          </i>
          ) the long appear to have been appreciably closer than the short." He then goes on to the historical development, quotations from various authors (from around the second century AD), as well as evidence from older inscriptions where "e" stands for normally short
          <i>
           i
          </i>
          , and "i" for long
          <i>
           e
          </i>
          , etc.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-58">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-58">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Technically, Sardinian is one of the
          <a href="/wiki/Southern_Romance_languages" title="Southern Romance languages">
           Southern Romance languages
          </a>
          . The same vowel outcome occurred in a small strip running across southern Italy (the
          <i>
           Lausberg Zone
          </i>
          ), and is thought to have occurred in the Romance languages of northern Africa.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Palmer-59">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Palmer_59-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Palmer (1954).
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-60">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-60">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <i>
           cauda
          </i>
          would produce French **
          <i>
           choue
          </i>
          , Italian
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           */kɔda/
          </span>
          , Occitan **
          <i>
           cauda
          </i>
          , Romanian **
          <i>
           caudă
          </i>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-kaze1991-61">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-kaze1991_61-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Kaze, Jeffery W. (1991). "Metaphony and Two Models for the Description of Vowel Systems".
           <i>
            Phonology
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            8
           </b>
           (1): 163–170.
           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1017%2Fs0952675700001329" rel="nofollow">
            10.1017/s0952675700001329
           </a>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/JSTOR" title="JSTOR">
            JSTOR
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/4420029" rel="nofollow">
            4420029
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Phonology&amp;rft.atitle=Metaphony+and+Two+Models+for+the+Description+of+Vowel+Systems&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=163-170&amp;rft.date=1991&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2Fs0952675700001329&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F4420029&amp;rft.aulast=Kaze&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeffery+W.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-62">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-62">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Calabrese, Andrea.
           <a class="external text" href="http://homepages.uconn.edu/~anc02008/Papers/METAPHONY.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "Metaphony"
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             2012-05-15
            </span>
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Metaphony&amp;rft.aulast=Calabrese&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrea&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fhomepages.uconn.edu%2F~anc02008%2FPapers%2FMETAPHONY.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-63">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-63">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="external text" href="http://personales.uniovi.es/web/ariasal/" rel="nofollow">
           Álvaro Arias.
           <i>
            El morfema de ‘neutro de materia’ en asturiano.
           </i>
           Santiago de Compostela, Universidade de Santiago de Compostela, 1999, I Premio «Dámaso Alonso» de Investigación Filológica.
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-penny1994-64">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-penny1994_64-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-penny1994_64-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Penny, Ralph (1994). "Continuity and Innovation in Romance: Metaphony and Mass-Noun Reference in Spain and Italy".
           <i>
            The Modern Language Review
           </i>
           .
           <b>
            89
           </b>
           (2): 273–281.
           <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
            doi
           </a>
           :
           <a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.2307%2F3735232" rel="nofollow">
            10.2307/3735232
           </a>
           .
           <a href="/wiki/JSTOR" title="JSTOR">
            JSTOR
           </a>
           <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/3735232" rel="nofollow">
            3735232
           </a>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Modern+Language+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Continuity+and+Innovation+in+Romance%3A+Metaphony+and+Mass-Noun+Reference+in+Spain+and+Italy&amp;rft.volume=89&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=273-281&amp;rft.date=1994&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F3735232&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F3735232&amp;rft.aulast=Penny&amp;rft.aufirst=Ralph&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-AAC-65">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-AAC_65-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Álvaro Arias. "
          <a class="external text" href="https://minerva.usc.es/xmlui/bitstream/handle/10347/5730/pg_113-142_moenia11.pdf?sequence=1" rel="nofollow">
           La armonización vocálica en fonología funcional (de lo sintagmático en fonología a propósito de dos casos de metafonía hispánica)
          </a>
          ",
          <i>
           Moenia
          </i>
          11 (2006): 111–139.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-66">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-66">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Note that the outcome of
          <i>
           -am -em -om
          </i>
          would be the same regardless of whether lengthening occurred, and that
          <i>
           -im
          </i>
          was already rare in Classical Latin, and appears to have barely survived in Proto-Romance. The only likely survival is in "-teen" numerals such as
          <i>
           trēdecim
          </i>
          "thirteen" &gt; Italian
          <i>
           tredici
          </i>
          . This favors the vowel-lengthening hypothesis
          <i>
           -im
          </i>
          &gt;
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /ĩː/
          </span>
          &gt;
          <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
           /i/
          </span>
          ; but notice unexpected
          <i>
           decem
          </i>
          &gt; Italian
          <i>
           dieci
          </i>
          (rather than expected
          <i>
           *diece
          </i>
          ). It is possible that
          <i>
           dieci
          </i>
          comes from *
          <i>
           decim
          </i>
          , which analogically replaced
          <i>
           decem
          </i>
          based on the
          <i>
           -decim
          </i>
          ending; but it is also possible that the final /i/ in
          <i>
           dieci
          </i>
          represents an irregular development of some other sort and that the process of analogy worked in the other direction.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-67">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-67">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The Latin forms are attested;
          <i>
           metipsissimus
          </i>
          is the superlative of the formative -
          <i>
           metipse
          </i>
          , found for example in
          <i>
           egometipse
          </i>
          "myself in person"
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-68">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-68">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Ralph Penny,
          <i>
           A History of the Spanish Language
          </i>
          , 2nd edn. (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2002), 144.
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-80">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-80">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://en.glosbe.com/en/ast" rel="nofollow">
            "English Asturian Dictionary Online"
           </a>
           . Glosbe
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             2013-09-18
            </span>
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=English+Asturian+Dictionary+Online&amp;rft.pub=Glosbe&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fen.glosbe.com%2Fen%2Fast&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARomance+languages">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-81">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-81">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Developed from *
          <i>
           pluviūtam
          </i>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-82">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-82">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Initial
          <i>
           h-
          </i>
          due to contamination of Germanic
          <i>
           *hauh
          </i>
          "high". Although no longer pronounced, it reveals its former presence by inhibiting
          <a href="/wiki/Elision_(French)" title="Elision (French)">
           elision
          </a>
          of a preceding
          <a href="/wiki/Schwa" title="Schwa">
           schwa
          </a>
          , e.g.
          <i>
           le haut
          </i>
          "the high" vs.
          <i>
           l'eau
          </i>
          "the water".
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-latinme-83">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-latinme_83-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-latinme_83-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-latinme_83-2">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              c
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-latinme_83-3">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              d
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Cognate with Latin
          <i>
           mē
          </i>
          , not
          <i>
           ego
          </i>
          . Note that this parallels the state of affairs in Celtic, where the cognate of
          <i>
           ego
          </i>
          is not attested anywhere, and the use of the accusative form cognate to
          <i>
           mē
          </i>
          has been extended to cover the nominative, as well.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-nosso-84">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-nosso_84-0">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              a
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
          <a href="#cite_ref-nosso_84-1">
           <sup>
            <i>
             <b>
              b
             </b>
            </i>
           </sup>
          </a>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Developed from an assimilated form *
          <i>
           nossum
          </i>
          rather than from
          <i>
           nostrum
          </i>
          .
         </span>
        </li>
       </ol>
      </div>

        </span>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       <i>
        <b>
         Rhaeto-Romance:
        </b>
       </i>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        John Haiman &amp; Paola Benincà, eds.,
        <i>
         The Rhaeto-Romance Languages
        </i>
        . London: Routledge, 1992.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">
        External links
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romance_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;section=65" title="Edit section: External links">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130617111122/http://iedo.brillonline.nl/dictionaries/content/latin/index.html" rel="nofollow">
         Michael de Vaan,
         <i>
          Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the other Italic Languages,
         </i>
         Brill, 2008, 826pp. (part available freely online)
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.reference-global.com/series/lrl" rel="nofollow">
         <i>
          Lexikon der Romanistischen Linguistik (LRL),
         </i>
         edd. Holtus / Metzeltin / Schmitt
        </a>
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template">
         <span style="white-space: nowrap;">
          [
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot">
            <span title=" Dead link since November 2017">
             permanent dead link
            </span>
           </a>
          </i>
          ]
         </span>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LRumIF1TLVkC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=Las+lenguas+rom%C3%A1nicas+est%C3%A1ndar.+Historia+de+su+formaci%C3%B3n+y+de+su+uso&amp;cd=1#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
         Michael Metzeltin,
         <i>
          Las lenguas románicas estándar. Historia de su formación y de su uso
         </i>
         , Oviedo, 2004
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.orbilat.com/" rel="nofollow">
         Orbis Latinus, site on Romance languages
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110501100652/http://www6.ocn.ne.jp/~wil/" rel="nofollow">
         Hugh Wilkinson's papers on Romance Languages
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://hotword.dictionary.com/romance/" rel="nofollow">
         Spanish is a Romance language, but what does that have to do with the type of romance between lovers?
        </a>
        , dictionary.com
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.nativlang.com/romance-languages/" rel="nofollow">
         Comparative Grammar of the Romance Languages
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="external text" href="http://neise.0rq.in/180-comparative-list-of-some-computer-terms-in-romance-language" rel="nofollow">
         Comparison of the computer terms in Romance languages
        </a>
       </li>
      </ul>

        <tr>
         <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
          <div>
           <div class="hlist hlist-separated">
            <ul>
             <li>
              <i>
               Italics
              </i>
              indicate
              <a href="/wiki/Language_death" title="Language death">
               extinct languages
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <b>
               Bold
              </b>
              indicates
              <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
               languages with more than 5 million speakers
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              Languages between parentheses are
              <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">
               varieties
              </a>
              of the language on their left.
             </li>
            </ul>
           </div>
          </div>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>

        <tr>
         <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
          <a href="/wiki/Help:Authority_control" title="Help:Authority control">
           Authority control
          </a>
         </th>
         <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
          <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
           <ul>
            <li>
             <span class="nowrap">
              <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Authority_File" title="Integrated Authority File">
               GND
              </a>
              :
              <span class="uid">
               <a class="external text" href="https://d-nb.info/gnd/4115788-6" rel="nofollow">
                4115788-6
               </a>
              </span>
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <span class="nowrap">
              <a href="/wiki/Syst%C3%A8me_universitaire_de_documentation" title="Système universitaire de documentation">
               SUDOC
              </a>
              :
              <span class="uid">
               <a class="external text" href="https://www.idref.fr/027471187" rel="nofollow">
                027471187
               </a>
              </span>
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <span class="nowrap">
              <a href="/wiki/National_Diet_Library" title="National Diet Library">
               NDL
              </a>
              :
              <span class="uid">
               <a class="external text" href="https://id.ndl.go.jp/auth/ndlna/00569674" rel="nofollow">
                00569674
               </a>
              </span>
             </span>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </div>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
